headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2014 Quarter 4 Earnings and 2015 Capital Budget Conference Call. My name is Vivian, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will no
componenttext:
Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2014 Quarter 4 Earnings and 2015 Capital Budget Conference Call. 
My name is Vivian, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Mr. Zack Dailey. Mr. Daley, you may begin.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings and 2015 Capital Budget Conference Call. I'm Zach Dailey, Director of Investor Relations. Also joining me on the call this morning are Lee Tillman,
componenttext:
Thanks. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings and 2015 Capital Budget Conference Call. I'm Zach Dailey, Director of Investor Relations. Also joining me on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, President and CEO; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Mitch Little, Vice President, International and Offshore E&P Operations; and Lance Robertson, Vice President, North America Production Operations. As has become our custom, we released prepared remarks last night in connection with the earnings release. You can find those remarks and the associated slides at marathonoil.com. We'll begin this morning with additional prepared remarks discussing our 2015 capital investment and exploration budget. We issued a separate press release detailing our 2015 capital program last evening, and we posted a second slide presentation to our website earlier today that accompanies this morning's prepared remarks. This morning's slide deck can be found under the Quarterly Earnings or Events tab tabs on the Investor center page of our website and is titled 2015 Capital Budget Slide Deck. 
After our remarks, the remainder of the call will be available for Q&A. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. 
Slide 2 contains a discussion of forward-looking statements and other information included in this presentation. Our remarks and answers to questions will contain forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. In accordance with the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, Marathon Oil Corporation has included in its annual report on Form 10-K for the year-ended December 31, 2013, and other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission cautionary language identifying important factors although not necessarily all such factors that could cause future outcomes to differ materially from those set forth in the forward-looking statements. With that, I'll turn the presentation to [indiscernible]  President and CEO, who will begin on Slide 3.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, thank you, Zach,  and good morning to all. I will say Zach is for Chris Phillips here today who is a bit under the weather today, and we hope Chris is back with us soon. As Zach mentioned, yesterday afternoon, we released our fourth quart
componenttext:
All right. Well, thank you, Zach,  and good morning to all. I will say Zach is for Chris Phillips here today who is a bit under the weather today, and we hope Chris is back with us soon. As Zach mentioned, yesterday afternoon, we released our fourth quarter and full year 2014 earnings, as well as announcing our 2015 capital budget. 
What we really want to accomplish this morning is to spend the bulk of our time on the 2015 capital budget and then turn to your questions. But before I do that, I'd like to share just a few thoughts on our full year 2014 results. I think I would summarize by saying, we delivered against our 2014 performance commitments. Investing in our 3 high-return U.S. resource plays, which yielded a 35% increase in production. We successfully closed on really 2 significant strategic disposition of over $4 billion in proceeds, and we're also be able to return value to our shareholders through an increased dividend and $1 billion in share repurchases. 
We also had proved reserve replacement ratio of 183% x dispositions and that was at a very competitive $20 per barrel oil equivalent and finding and development costs. And we also recorded 97% operational availability across our company-operated assets, and of course, these are our most economic barrels. I think we could say that by any measure, it was an outstanding year, but the second half of the year brought us a bit of a new reality, a bit of a gut check. Commodity prices corrected significantly downward, and I think we were harshly reminded yet again of our inability to predict pricing. Our business plans for 2015 as with others were being essentially adjusted in real time as the market continue to search for some sense of stability. in December, we felt that it was critical to at least advise our shareholders us to our view of 2015 capital budget guidance at that particular point in time with the caveat that we were prepared to respond to further downward movement in pricing. Our foreshadowing, unfortunately, was quite accurate and prices fell more as we move into the new year. This morning, what we're sharing is our updated plan and budget based on today's view of the pricing environment. But it has the same caveat that flexibility is going to be essential in a volatile commodity market. We will admit there were no more clairvoyant on pricing that we were in December. So with that a little bit of our preamp, that did go ahead and turn into 2015, were $3.5 billion budget really emphasizes investment selectivity and return, balance sheet flexibility and positions us for price recovery. It is a further 20% reduction since our December update. We've significantly reduced exploration spending by half, and we are moderating activity levels in the U.S. in alignment with good cash flow management. We'll end up directing about 70% or $2.4 billion of our budget toward our 3-core U.S. resource plays and these continue to be among our highest return investment opportunities. Our objective is simple. It's to deliver high returns in the current pricing environment while we protect our financial flexibility through prudent management of cash flows. Today, we're also releasing updated single well economics for the resource plays. And these new single well economics reflect  our 2015 inventory hydrating along with the service cost reduction that we've already captured and have in hand. 
Suffice to say, we are not opportunity-limited. Furthermore we're continuing to pursue all means to expand our margins. We're going to do this through capital efficiency, expense management and operational reliability. Those things that we can control. Marathon Oil clearly benefits from a deep multiyear inventory that is robust across a broad range of pricing scenarios. Given this portfolio, we're fortunate to have the opportunity to adjust our short-cycle investment in line with commodity prices. As we continue to focus on our 3 high-quality U.S. resource plays in 2015, our budget and activity plans will support high-return investments that will in turn generate a total company production growth rate x Libya, a 5% to 7% year-over-year. And specifically for our resource plays, a growth rate of about 20% year-over-year admittedly benefiting from the 2014 carry-on effect. 
Bottom line is that we're going to be driven by returns and cash flow management with growth as an outcome while we retain the ability to flex on pricing. With that, I'll turn over to Lance Robertson, our Vice President of North America Production Operations, and he'll take us through our newly plans for the resource plays. Lance?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lee. I'll begin on Slide 4. In the context of the current environment, we are prudently reducing development activity and commensurate capital expenditures across all 3 of the resource plays. Having the flexibility within our existing commercial a
componenttext:
Thanks, Lee. I'll begin on Slide 4. In the context of the current environment, we are prudently reducing development activity and commensurate capital expenditures across all 3 of the resource plays. Having the flexibility within our existing commercial agreements allows us to make these adjustments readily and at little to no cost. As reflected by the table on the top right of the slide, activity will be reduced from 33 active rigs at the end of 2014 to 18 by the end of the first quarter, with a further reduction to 14 rigs by the end of the second quarter. 
We anticipate continuing at the 14-rig pace across the balance of 2015 but retain significant flexibility to scale up or down as market conditions warrant. In addition to rig reductions, we're optimizing completions activity to match our inventory of wells with a focus on maintaining the execution efficiency of full frac fleets. In addition to driving operational efficiencies, we have focused extensively on service cost reductions in this environment, securing today a minimum of $225 million in savings across the 2015 activity. 
Importantly, substantially all of these initial savings were effective in January, benefiting our returns early in the cycle. We continue to see opportunity for additional savings throughout the year further protecting our cash margins. Our North America opportunities for investment remain compelling at current commodity pricing. Referencing the plot in the bottom right, our 2015 investments will focus on inventory that can deliver strong returns in each of Eagle Ford, Bakken and the Oklahoma resource basins. In addition, we have multiple years of inventory that can deliver a similar returns at today's pricing. 
With our core position in 3 key basins and a relentless focus on continuing to drive efficiencies and cost savings, we can continue to provide Marathon Oil with opportunities to deliver value to our shareholders. The 2015 development spend and activity in the resource basins will resort in the production increase of approximately 20% year-on-year with fourth quarter 2015 exit rates up from the same quarter of 2014. 
Turning to Slide 5. We will focus initially on the Eagle Ford, where we have allocated approximately 40% of total 2015 capital on our high-return inventory. Our quality core acreage provides opportunity to drive tremendous value at this scale. We continue to realize this value through highly effective execution. With these efficiencies and recently secured service cost reductions, our cost have fallen by $1.3 million a well to an average of $6.3 million of wells in 2015.. Maintaining our position as one of the most cost efficient operators in the basin. Over the past year, completions optimization has resulted in a 25% increase in 180-day cumulative production across wells to sales. This incremental early life production materially improves well margins, and as this group matures, we anticipate adding further value with an increasing in ultimate volumes recover. Taking into account cost savings and improvements in well performance, we anticipate drilling approximately 215 to 225 wells this in South Texas, with returns ranging from 40% to 60% at $60 flat WTI pricing. This group includes Eagle Ford condensate wells, hygiene oil wells with the remaining 25% of wells to develop and further delineate the Austin Chalk. In all cases, the Austin Chalk is co-developed with the Lower Eagle Ford, leveraging the existing gathering networks and the facilities. Focusing  on the table on the upper left, we're illustrating for the first time single-well metrics for the Austin Chalk. From the data, you can see that the initial production and estimated ultimate recovery compared favorably to the Eagle Ford condensate and higher oil wells. The currently delineated core area, the Austin Chalk was delivered the highest returns driven by higher early life community production relative to other horizons in the Eagle Ford portfolio. 
Continuing with our co-development efforts, the first 4 Upper Eagle Ford wells were placed on sale in the fourth quarter. 
Their co-developed above high Lower Eagle Ford oil wells in this pilot consistent with the Austin Chalk co-development effort. Same zone spacing is 40-acre equivalent, with spacing between the horizons at a 20-acre equivalent. These wells were early on flow but initial rates and pressures are encouraging  for both horizons. 
We will continue this testing throughout the year much in the way the Austin Chalk has been and will continue to be identified, evaluated and developed. In addition, we also spotted the first stack-and-frac co-development pilot in the fourth quarter, including Austin Chalk, Upper Eagle Ford and 2 wells in the Lower Eagle Ford. We'll provide  an update on these efforts later in the year. 
Focusing on Bakken on Slide 6. The initial completion trials are mostly finished, with 42 of the wells completed and flowing to sales. Of these wells, the first 18 in Myrmidon and Hector had yielded more than 30% increase of community production over to for 60 days. This material change in early production is clearly very encouraging, and we anticipate further updates as the production histories mature. In aggregate, the incremental spend on more intensive completions is yielding a return on investment at or above 100% in all areas and zones. As a result, a strong early production response in our focus on driving value, we have adopted the updated practice is more intensive into the base program. These changes are effective across Myrmidon and Hector in Middle Bakken and Three Forks intervals. Reflecting the success, we will continue to test and optimize completions moving forward. 
Directing your attention to the single-well returns stable on the upper left of the slide. We illustrated updated gross completed well cost of $6.2 million to $6.6 million a well, reflecting a reduction of almost $1 million a well thus far. 
These costs include incremental spend for more intensive stimulations for each area, but the full performance benefits of enhanced completions on EUR is not yet reflected. In addition to the completion pilots, we have concluded drilling on the first 2 spacing pilots with 6 wells per horizon in Hector and Myrmidon. These pilots will move to completions over the coming weeks with the third spacing pilot currently drilling. We anticipate the combination of the proved stimulation designs coupled with increasing spacing density to drive towards the highest value, incremental improving go over efficiency across the drilling unit. With improved well costs and higher initial production, our investments in the Williston basin will deliver competitive returns of 20% to 30% in the current commodity environment. As we continue to focus on highest returns and value, the majority of our activity in 2015 will incur in the Myrmidon area. On slide 7, Oklahoma resource activity will focus on protecting core leasehold in the SCOOP and stack areas. With more than 70% of our Oklahoma acreage held by  production, our 2015 activity will allow us to manage lease expirees with moderate spend of approximately $225 million and 2 rigs after the first quarter. Our focus for the year will include high-value SCOOP and stack wells, including our first operating spacing pilot in the SCOOP Woodford, but we are targeting 6 wells and a 640-acre unit, effectively testing same zone spacing of approximately 105 acres. This spacing pilot was spud in the fourth quarter. We anticipate moving to completions by the middle of 2015. In addition, we will spud our first operated springer  well in the SCOOP area later in the year to complement the 17 outside operated springer wells in which we currently participate. We continue to grow our leaseholds in Oklahoma adding 10,000 net acres focused on the SCOOP and Springer areas in the fourth quarters. 
Drawing your attention to the table in the upper left, SCOOP while estimated ultimate recoveries continue to be among the highest available with a high liquids content. Having secured an initial cost reduction of more than $0.5 million, we can confidently deliver wells with 30% to 40% internal rates of return in the current commodity market. With the lower activity in Oklahoma, we'll turn our focus on developing the spacing pilots, driving efficiency, securing additional cost reductions and delivering higher ultimate value. With the longest wells from spud to total depth in our resource portfolio of today, we see ample opportunity for cycle time improvements in 2015 and with price recovery, we'll be ready to move to scale at the lowest cost. 
Slide 8 brings together all 3 U.S. resource plays and demonstrates the strength of our resource and inventory. Our 2015 capital development of program is one that is appropriately scaled to today's commodity price environment. As Lee mentioned at the beginning, we expect these basins to achieve an approximate 20% increase in production 2015 over 2014, taking into account our spending plans and moderated activity levels. 
Next, I'll hand it off to my counterpart, Mitch Little, Vice President of International and Offshore E&P Operations. Mitch will describe 2015 activity for his business.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lance. Switching now to our international and offshore activities, which begin on Slide 9. Our 2015 development activities are focused on high return, previously sanctioned long cycle commitments and selected by the projects that offer superior
componenttext:
Thank you, Lance. Switching now to our international and offshore activities, which begin on Slide 9. Our 2015 development activities are focused on high return, previously sanctioned long cycle commitments and selected by the projects that offer superior risk-adjusted returns, including targeted activities in Equatorial Guinea, the region of Iraq; U.S. Gulf of Mexico and U.K. North Sea. Within EG, we're progressing the B3 compression project, which adds important infrastructure, allowing us to access the field's proven reserve base by significantly lowering field pressure. The project is approximately 60% complete, remains within budget and on track for a 2016 start up. Combined with the addition of the C21 infill producer, the project is expected to maintain field production plateau for an additional 2 years while extending field life by as much as 8 years. 
Our investment activities in EG also include a second near-field wildcat well, testing an oil prone amplitude supported prospect at Rodo, which is located within subarea B of the  block. While the recently drilled well did not encounter commercial hydrocarbon quantities, we were encouraged by the presence of high-quality oil in multiple STACK sands. Our upcoming well is targeting a younger reservoir section, and we have several additional prospects across our more than 120,000 net acres under contract in EG. 
Our U.K. investment program is concentrated on the addition of 3 infill producers that add high return, incremental barrels to our existing operations. The first well, in the producer of Southbury, will be online in the first quarter and follows on the success of 2 previous wells that were brought online in late 2014 and continued to outperform predrill expectations. Activities also include drilling and completion of 2 subsea infill producers within our operated West Bayfield, the first of these wells is expected to be online by the end of February with the second coming online around midyear. Moving onto our plans for 2015 Kurdistan investment program, which includes the development activities highlighted here as well as exploration activities, which will be discussed on the subsequent slides. Within the outside operated Block, construction and installation of the phase 1 production facilities continues with the first production currently forecast for late 2015. Appraisal and testing activities also continue in the eastern portions of the field and results from those activities will be integrated with existing data to inform a future decision regarding the applicability of additional development phases. The outside-operated block is currently producing around 4,000 gross barrels of oil a day from a single-well facility within the field. A phased field development plan is under review within the Kurdistan Ministry of Natural Resources, and we anticipate approval and associated development activities in 2015. 
Finally, in the Gulf of Mexico, we're participating in the 2-well subsea development project at the outside operated Gunflint with first production expected in 2016. 
Moving now to Slide 10.  We have materially reduced our global exploration spending in 2015 with activities focused towards ongoing appraisal activities and/or prior commitments. The majority of this spending is tightly focused within 2 geographic areas. Within the Gulf of Mexico, we continue evaluation and testing of our prospect inventory within the inboard Paleogene play. Several discoveries have been announced within the play over the past few years, including the outside-operated Shenandoah field, where Marathon Oil hold 10% working interest. An appraisal well is expected to spud at Shenandoah in the second quarter. 
Additionally, the and drillship will be back for our second operated well slot sometime during the second quarter of 2015. Moving over to Kurdistan. We are currently drilling the 2 appraisal well within the company-operated block. The well is a follow-up to the 2013 discovery well and will further define the resource base in advance of a commerciality decision, which is due later this year. In addition, within the outside-operated block, the East exploration well is currently being sidetracked to an updated location. Well results are expected to be announced later in 2015. With that, I'd like to turn the call back to Lee for his concluding comments.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, thank you, Mitch, and thank you to Lance as well. As our budget and activity plans demonstrate, Marathon Oil is focused on delivering long-term shareholder value regardless of the commodity price cycle. We have a keen eye on returns and f
componenttext:
All right. Well, thank you, Mitch, and thank you to Lance as well. As our budget and activity plans demonstrate, Marathon Oil is focused on delivering long-term shareholder value regardless of the commodity price cycle. We have a keen eye on returns and financial flexibility. We're committed to exercising capital discipline that will protect our optionality and position us to be a stronger E&P and not only 2015 and '16 but beyond. Our 3 U.S. resource plays have exceptional subsurface quality and strong single-well economics that will deliver solid returns across a broad range of price scenarios. Even after high grading our opportunities for this low-price environment, our deep portfolio affords us a multiyear drilling inventory, with pace and spending levels ultimately moderated based on pricing and cash flows. We are exercising every means available to expand our margins, including significant contributions that you've heard about from enhanced completions and service cost reductions. But we're also mindful of driving the fundamentals of expense management, including organizational capacity, which must match the current environment and activity levels, and finally, operational reliability. Our commitment to our previously stated 7 strategic imperatives is durable regardless of the commodity cycle. Though we're rightly focused on prudent near-term actions, we've laid the groundwork for the future, and we'll continue building on our resource base. 
In 2015, our asset teams will be aggressively testing co-development, stack and frac, downspacing, enhanced completion designs and new horizons. All strategic opportunities to expand our unconventional resource for the future. We are well prepared for the current low-price environment, and our 2015 investment program is based on achieving the highest returns at today's commodity prices while prudently managing cash flows. We will also continue to protect optionality to flex our spend up or down, and we'll insure of our outstanding as the team prepared to take full advantage of a sustained recovery. That really concludes our prepared remarks. So operator, we'll now open up the call for questions.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess a question on the 2015 and then 2016 shale growth. I mean, you mentioned that you have inventory, and you can see consider in the numbers if you look up well completions and then wells to sales, which obviously full less. As you will forward into
componenttext: I guess a question on the 2015 and then 2016 shale growth. I mean, you mentioned that you have inventory, and you can see consider in the numbers if you look up well completions and then wells to sales, which obviously full less. As you will forward into 2016, if you just kept the same sort of level of activity, what sort of production growth do you think you'd get from each of your plays? It feels like you should sort of flat or even decline if we carried on at this level of well completions?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me address that one, Ed. First, maybe it's useful for us to reflect on kind of how we develop this year's plan, and it was really looking at kind of the near-term pricing environment, the returns that we could generate, high-grading the inventory
componenttext: Yes. Let me address that one, Ed. First, maybe it's useful for us to reflect on kind of how we develop this year's plan, and it was really looking at kind of the near-term pricing environment, the returns that we could generate, high-grading the inventory and then testing that against our cash flow management objectives. And really when we did that, growth became an outcome,  if you will, from that process. And we tested that, of course, against numerous pricing scenarios. If we look at 2015, as we stated in the prepared material, Ed, we're looking at overall growth on average of 5% to 7% for the portfolio but we also believe the resource plays will deliver approximately 20% in growth. If we think about that in terms of exit rates, the exit rates 4Q '14 to 4Q '15 and the resource plays will actually be up and overall portfolio will eventually be flat on exit rates with the resource plays eventually offsetting our more mature properties. Now looking forward into 2016 and as you might imagine, Ed, we ran numerous scenarios looking at not only '15 but also '16 under many, many price decks over the last few months. But when we think about '16 and we think about a moderate level of recovery in '16, we think that we could go over budget essentially at current levels, '15 like levels around the $3.5 billion and keep our overall average for the portfolio essentially flat with likely exit rates increasing a bit year-on-year as we see a little bit more activity because we're seeing some improvement cash flows.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful and probably more guidance than we'll get from other companies at this stage. And then on the cost side, $225 million across your budget, I mean, that's sort of 5%, 6% people are thinking service cost deflation is going to be 20% or mo
componenttext: That's very helpful and probably more guidance than we'll get from other companies at this stage. And then on the cost side, $225 million across your budget, I mean, that's sort of 5%, 6% people are thinking service cost deflation is going to be 20% or more. I'm just worried if you -- I'm sorry, I'd like to ask whether you think 20% is realistic? Or is it just a function of where you are in the year?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ed. Good question. I think I would encourage everyone to think of that initial cost savings of $225 million as the minimum. Those are effectively savings we've already accomplished. They're in the rearview mirror from our perspective. We're working
componenttext: Sure, Ed. Good question. I think I would encourage everyone to think of that initial cost savings of $225 million as the minimum. Those are effectively savings we've already accomplished. They're in the rearview mirror from our perspective. We're working on the next level. We've built those into our budget plans, so they're included in there. We're already working on several areas of next cost savings. So we fully anticipate that savings to grow throughout the year. We're confident in what we've already achieved, and we're confident to achieve further savings throughout the year, Ed.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Lee, I guess my question was one of your competitors this morning is also a very large operator in the Eagle Ford. basically said, we're just going to give this stuff away in this oil price environment, especially when you haven't had the costs coming dow
componenttext: Lee, I guess my question was one of your competitors this morning is also a very large operator in the Eagle Ford. basically said, we're just going to give this stuff away in this oil price environment, especially when you haven't had the costs coming down yet. And if I read your interpretation correctly, what you're basically saying is we're going to try and get the best returns in the current oil price environment. Why complete the wells at all when you have not the cost reductions to the scale that most people are expecting? I think by your on words, you anticipated the oil price will ultimately recover. So why not store it on the ground as opposed to just keep on growing at this stage? And I've got a follow-up please.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll address that one, Doug. First of all, we feel very confident that as Lance has already stated, that we have already captured significant cost savings. So we're not sitting here waiting to capture cost savings. We've already got cost savings in
componenttext: Okay. I'll address that one, Doug. First of all, we feel very confident that as Lance has already stated, that we have already captured significant cost savings. So we're not sitting here waiting to capture cost savings. We've already got cost savings in the bank essentially back through the January timeframe. So we feel very comfortable that we are already on that path of capturing cost reduction. We also continue, of course, to improve the overall productivity of the wells. and if you look at the returns that we're able to generate, we feel very confident that the shareholder is benefiting from those investments. I will say though that we are optimizing our completion program. We're not simply just driving forward with our backlog of inventory. As Lance mentioned, we're going to be judicious about pacing our completion activity in 2015 to ensure that we: one, capture full cost reduction savings at scale; but 2, also capture the executions efficiency of running full frac crews. So my answer would be is we feel very confident in the returns that we're generating. That's a little bit of a bet on the future, I guess, in terms of what you see the go in the future, but we're very comfortable with our investment program.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

And maybe perhaps the level of cash flow that you anticipate in your current budget including the dividend spend? And I'll leave it at that.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me maybe address the dividend question, and perhaps I'll ask JR to comment a little bit on cash flow and out spends because I know that's a topic of interest. We are committed to our dividend. When we talk about how we allocate capital, we looke
componenttext: Okay. Let me maybe address the dividend question, and perhaps I'll ask JR to comment a little bit on cash flow and out spends because I know that's a topic of interest. We are committed to our dividend. When we talk about how we allocate capital, we looked at the buckets to initially allocate capital. Our financial obligations, which on our view into the dividend are at the top of that list. And we've already said, we'll scale any movement in the dividend according to the health of the business. But I want to be very clear that we remain committed to our dividends. That's the way that we return to our shareholders it needs to be looked at in the  full context of the dividend plus organic growth that we're generating in our business. With that, maybe I'll just ask JR to comment a bit on cash flows and our view of out spend going forward?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Lee. Doug, good to hear from you this morning. I think Lee's indicated earlier today we really did design the capital budget to reflect the spend that we believe is appropriate even in the current environment. And it was really approached qu
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Lee. Doug, good to hear from you this morning. I think Lee's indicated earlier today we really did design the capital budget to reflect the spend that we believe is appropriate even in the current environment. And it was really approached quite carefully to balance between this ongoing capital investment and what we believe are attractive returns in our U.S. unconventional resources and high returns quite candidly with our ability in our commitment to continue to maintain appropriate financial flexibility during this time frame. I think also let's keep in mind, I am seating on nearly $5 billion of liquidity today, and I think that puts us in a good position as we start in the 2015. But honestly, that said, we're going to continue to monitor our level of cash flows based on not only the current price environment but expectations in later part of '15 and 2016 and look at our cash flow profile accordingly to make sure that we're maintaining that flexibility. And if conditions change, we've got a great deal of flexibility to either decrease if they get worse, or equally important, to increase if we see a strengthening environment, our level of capital spend really much of increasing cash flows as well. So -- and then finally, I'd say, Doug, I think Lee highlighted pretty well that we're going to continue to address those matters that really within our control of the business, operating costs, G&A and those sorts of matters. So at this point in time, there's no doubt that we are investing a significant portion of our Norway proceeds this year but I think we're investing them in an organic program that's delivering solid returns for our shareholders.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ryan Todd of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ryan Todd of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could follow up a little bit on that last point. I mean, you're maintaining attractive level operationally and you still have on the balance sheet lots of dry powder in 2015. I mean, if you think about that cash management going forward, what w
componenttext: Maybe if I could follow up a little bit on that last point. I mean, you're maintaining attractive level operationally and you still have on the balance sheet lots of dry powder in 2015. I mean, if you think about that cash management going forward, what would you need to see to put money and rigs back to work? Is it a certain level in the oil price? Is it the cash flow relative to spending outlook? Is it securing a level of cost reduction? What puts money and rigs back to work?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Ryan, the answer to that is probably a bit multidimensional. It's -- first, it starts with seeing, I think, a sustained recovery in pricing. One with certainly less volatility but also yields us enhanced cash flows that we can redeploy into
componenttext: Yes, I think, Ryan, the answer to that is probably a bit multidimensional. It's -- first, it starts with seeing, I think, a sustained recovery in pricing. One with certainly less volatility but also yields us enhanced cash flows that we can redeploy into the business. Again, we've stated we're not opportunity-constrained tts obvious from our single-well economics in our inventory. So as that incremental cash flow becomes available, we would certainly be looking to invest more. And in our current plans, again, we're not just looking at 2015. We are looking at 2016 and beyond. And then 2016, we are assuming a moderate recovery in pricing that we think will support some uplift in actively going forward. And we're well prepared to do that. We have the execution capacity to gear up or down in the resource plays quite readily.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe one other on opportunities that going forward. I mean, in the recent years, you've been a big -- you've been a large seller of assets with the exceptional  maybe building the to put the position and scoop and the stack area. When you
componenttext: Great. And then maybe one other on opportunities that going forward. I mean, in the recent years, you've been a big -- you've been a large seller of assets with the exceptional  maybe building the to put the position and scoop and the stack area. When you think about that going forward, do you see yourselves more likely still trying to rationalize the portfolio a little bit? Or would you look to be more opportunistic and deploying your balance sheet going forward?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, let me  first maybe, Ryan, address the portfolio management question. The portfolio management for us is an evergreen process. It's just part of a healthy E&P company does. We're going to continually test our asset set to ensure that it compete
componenttext: Yes. Well, let me  first maybe, Ryan, address the portfolio management question. The portfolio management for us is an evergreen process. It's just part of a healthy E&P company does. We're going to continually test our asset set to ensure that it competes for capital allocation within our portfolio. So you're going to see portfolio management feature in our business model going forward in time. Now let's be honest, it's a tough market right now to go out and dispose of an asset and capture true value for the shareholders, but we're going to continue to test the market when we think that it makes sense for the shareholder. Back on your other question though maybe more along the lines of the M&A, the acquisitive side. I would maybe characterized that the rates are the focus for us today when you think about the bid spreads that are still out there, there's probably still a bit of a gap. But then thing that we would evaluate has to compete against our already very strong organic inventory. It would have to come in and compete for capital allocation, which in overview is a relatively high bar from a quality and scale standpoint. So that would be I think the limiting factor to us is really finding the quality of asset.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from John Herrlin from Societe Generale.
componenttext: And our next question comes from John Herrlin from Societe Generale.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Three unrelated ones. With the cost savings, is it just discount from book? Or changes in procurement as well as efficiencies and well designs? Things like that?
componenttext: Three unrelated ones. With the cost savings, is it just discount from book? Or changes in procurement as well as efficiencies and well designs? Things like that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. John, it's actually kind of a number of things, all of which you included and more. So there is efficiency savings in there. We realized over the last quarter that we're reflecting in those updated single well metric stable. We certainly have gone ou
componenttext: Yes. John, it's actually kind of a number of things, all of which you included and more. So there is efficiency savings in there. We realized over the last quarter that we're reflecting in those updated single well metric stable. We certainly have gone out and renegotiated our contracts in some cases taken on new contracts or negotiated new pricing within existing structures, reflecting the market and taking every means necessary in that. I think we looked at that and I say we looked at the context on the single-well metrics on Slide 13, and we feel confident -- we're confident enough in those savings that we've already reflected new cost per well in those tables, and we think that's the beginning or the minimum for this year, and we anticipate additional savings. And it isn't clear with ultimate savings will be throughout the year. We think it's more than what we've already achieved but we wanted to achieve those early in that cycle so we can continue to invest with confidence and we are. I also think of those well cost reflect in a very competitive in each of those basins.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I agree. I just you might get more cost savings going forward. Next question from is on the stack-and-frac. From the time you spud your initial well to the time you complete the formations, about how long is that in duration?
componenttext: I agree. I just you might get more cost savings going forward. Next question from is on the stack-and-frac. From the time you spud your initial well to the time you complete the formations, about how long is that in duration?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, it depends on how big the pad size is. So it could vary from but as little as 90 days, could be 120 days. And we're -- in this case, the stack-and-frac going to have 4 zone vertically, 2 in the Lower Eagle Ford, 1 in the Upper Eagle Ford and then in
componenttext: John, it depends on how big the pad size is. So it could vary from but as little as 90 days, could be 120 days. And we're -- in this case, the stack-and-frac going to have 4 zone vertically, 2 in the Lower Eagle Ford, 1 in the Upper Eagle Ford and then in the Austin Chalk. Generally, those pilots maybe even larger than it may be 7 or  8 wells as we expand that horizontally, but it's the same vertical stacking. So it's diverse in time depending on how many are on the pad quite frankly.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fine. The last one for me is on Oklahoma. Any acreage retention issues at all?
componenttext: Okay, that's fine. The last one for me is on Oklahoma. Any acreage retention issues at all?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think we're quite confident. We have 70% of our total acreage, HBP today, John, and then reflecting those lease expires over the next several years, not just this year, we can maintain those leases with about 2 rigs moving forward. Ideally, we'd lik
componenttext: No. I think we're quite confident. We have 70% of our total acreage, HBP today, John, and then reflecting those lease expires over the next several years, not just this year, we can maintain those leases with about 2 rigs moving forward. Ideally, we'd like to see in a commodity price recovery more active so we can test other things, but we're confident we can retain all of the value of that lease position within the business plan we've presented.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comps from Guy Baber from Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comps from Guy Baber from Simmons & Company.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had a follow-up on the comment that the unconventional production is expected to rise exit rates '15 versus exit rates '14, which is different than what we've heard from others in the industry work at the capital to degree. So I was just hoping to bette
componenttext: I had a follow-up on the comment that the unconventional production is expected to rise exit rates '15 versus exit rates '14, which is different than what we've heard from others in the industry work at the capital to degree. So I was just hoping to better understand a little bit more specifically how you think you're driving that? And if there's anything that you would point out differentiated production expectation from one basin to another? Or if you have any other comments on that front? And I'd have some follow-up as well.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Guy. Maybe I'll just kind of talk generically a bit about the resource plays. I think the reason that again we're able to be very capital efficient and 2015 is, again, several fold: one, we've the ability to high-grade our inventory even within
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Guy. Maybe I'll just kind of talk generically a bit about the resource plays. I think the reason that again we're able to be very capital efficient and 2015 is, again, several fold: one, we've the ability to high-grade our inventory even within our extremely strong core areas. So you've got a high grading effect or you're bringing the best opportunities forward, not only within a basin but across all 3 basins; secondly, were able to do that at lower cost for the reasons that Lance has already enumerated. We captured those cost savings very early in the cycle and certainly we're chasing even more throughout the year. And so -- and then at the asset teams continue to drive things like enhanced completion performance, as well as some of the co-development work, the downspacing work, all of those are tending to improve the overall productivity of the wells also. So it's kind of lifting all boats, if I can put it that way. So when you consider all those factors, I think it positions us very, very strongly to continue to drive that kind of exit rate to exit rate growth. Now again, we are still benefiting from some pretty strong carry-on effects from 2014 as well, but as we look across the year and optimize our completion program, we're going to be able to again keep that production relatively steady throughout the year with, again, a little bit of uptick in the exit rates for '15.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then my follow-up was on exploration, but you made obviously very significant cuts to the capital allocated there. I was hoping to get some strategic commentary on that front. Does that reflect a permanent shift in the exploration stra
componenttext: That's helpful. And then my follow-up was on exploration, but you made obviously very significant cuts to the capital allocated there. I was hoping to get some strategic commentary on that front. Does that reflect a permanent shift in the exploration strategy going forward? Or is it more of a specific adjustment you are making this year to better balance cash flow? I'm just trying to better understand whether for exploration that we accrete back towards $500 million a year to $600 million a year? Just wanted to get the latest thoughts on how that has evolved as you've tested out some of the new acreage you've been building up over the last few years?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great question. Exploration remains attractive to us for obvious reasons because of the strong multiples that it can generate, again, when we're successful at exploration. To be very frank, we're not satisfied with our historical performance and explorati
componenttext: Great question. Exploration remains attractive to us for obvious reasons because of the strong multiples that it can generate, again, when we're successful at exploration. To be very frank, we're not satisfied with our historical performance and exploration and under Mitch's leadership, we feel we need to improve in that area. And while we're searching for the enhanced approach that will drive those improve results, we are reducing spend materially. A lot of that reduction quite frankly, was in place in a basis before a commodity price correction though. So it was largely driven by I would say scheduling and commitments that we had in the 2015 time period. I would end this by saying that exploration must compete for capital allocation like every other aspect of our business. And so this year,, your spend would be materially reduced. And as we look forward in time, opportunities in exploration will have to go head-to-head with the other investment opportunities that we have in our portfolio.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeoffrey Lambujon from Tudor, Pickering, Holt.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeoffrey Lambujon from Tudor, Pickering, Holt.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just trying to think about future potential cost savings. On the $225  million we've factored in so far, is there a breakout you have in terms of North America versus international? If it's primarily U.S. resource plays, implied closer to 8% to 10% in cos
componenttext: Just trying to think about future potential cost savings. On the $225  million we've factored in so far, is there a breakout you have in terms of North America versus international? If it's primarily U.S. resource plays, implied closer to 8% to 10% in cost savings? Is that the right way to think about it? Or is it more of a balanced split?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a great question, Jeff. I would say that $225 million is specific to North American and really specific to the 3 resource plays underneath it. And so it's built into the development cost we've already captured today, primarily in Oklahoma, Bakken and
componenttext: It's a great question, Jeff. I would say that $225 million is specific to North American and really specific to the 3 resource plays underneath it. And so it's built into the development cost we've already captured today, primarily in Oklahoma, Bakken and Eagle Ford. So I think -- so I think I think the way you're describing it is accurate on that and that's our minimum floor with the -- we expect that to grow materially over the balance of the year.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, and this  is Mitch Little. I'll just add a little bit to that from the international and offshore side. We are seeing some modest reductions across a number of suppliers. We've got specific plans in place at each asset. But keep in mind that a lot o
componenttext: Jeff, and this  is Mitch Little. I'll just add a little bit to that from the international and offshore side. We are seeing some modest reductions across a number of suppliers. We've got specific plans in place at each asset. But keep in mind that a lot of the projects we're executing in that space are long cycle prior commitments, executed long cycle contracts, which aren't going to be subject to the same volatility, which we are seeing in the North America and onshore business.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then last question from me. In regards to ongoing optimization and completions, how do you view that kind of power testing going forward for increased end loading, additional completion changes, just given low commodity prices and increme
componenttext: Okay, great. And then last question from me. In regards to ongoing optimization and completions, how do you view that kind of power testing going forward for increased end loading, additional completion changes, just given low commodity prices and incremental capital required upfront there?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you'll see us continue, Jeff, with completions optimization on an ongoing basis effectively and definitely. We're always going to look at that better well productivity at the lowest cost possible, particularly as we look at Bakken and Oklahom
componenttext: Yes. I think you'll see us continue, Jeff, with completions optimization on an ongoing basis effectively and definitely. We're always going to look at that better well productivity at the lowest cost possible, particularly as we look at Bakken and Oklahoma, where we have lower productivity for the year. We see this as a great opportunity to drive well productivity as well as test spacing so that as prices do recover in the future, we are very well-positioned to grow to full field development scale quickly and at the highest value for the company. I think we're confident we'll continue to see improvements on that and working at all 3 of those basins and any new basins in the future on optimization is just going to be a natural cycle of our business.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: You've always talked about share buyback  as flex variable, and I suppose now that you've got CapEx by 40%, if oil prices were to recover, what's going to be the kind of decision variables between allocating increased CapEx versus perhaps resuming buyback
componenttext: You've always talked about share buyback  as flex variable, and I suppose now that you've got CapEx by 40%, if oil prices were to recover, what's going to be the kind of decision variables between allocating increased CapEx versus perhaps resuming buyback?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Pavel, this is JR. I think that's a fair question. We talked a lot about how share buybacks have got to compete against organic capital reinvestments, and I think we've demonstrated that in 2014. You recall back when we sold Angola, the thought proce
componenttext: Yes. Pavel, this is JR. I think that's a fair question. We talked a lot about how share buybacks have got to compete against organic capital reinvestments, and I think we've demonstrated that in 2014. You recall back when we sold Angola, the thought process was what was the next best highest use of capital. And in that point of time, it's a little bit of history, we just significantly ramped up activity across North America. And in that point in time, we were not ready to make that next incremental investment in North America, given our desire to see us operating at that higher scale. So really the next highest and best use from an allocation standpoint is share repurchase. Now fast forward, not only did buy doses of this volatile commodity price environment, but we find ourselves with a level of capital spend that really isn't funding a large portion of our organic investment opportunities and are still higher earnings. So it is a much different conversation regarding what is the risk-adjusted return of that organic reinvestment versus the share repurchases. But I got to tell you though, Pavel, until we see a bit more clarity around the depth and duration of the commodity price correction that we're in right now, I feel like the balance sheet is probably the best place for any incremental capital at this point in time until we see a strengthening in of cash flow. But again, at the appropriate time, share repurchases is going to be a consideration for capital allocation. It's just going to have to continue to compete on a risk-adjusted basis.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just kind of a small housekeeping item about the production guidance. Are you giving credit to any volumes this year from your first development in Kurdistan?
componenttext: Okay. And just kind of a small housekeeping item about the production guidance. Are you giving credit to any volumes this year from your first development in Kurdistan?

componenttextpreview: We -- as I mentioned in my comments, we are currently forecasting first production from the nonoperated phase 1 block late this year. We also have very small production from the block, which is about 4,000 gross barrels of oil a day.
componenttext: We -- as I mentioned in my comments, we are currently forecasting first production from the nonoperated phase 1 block late this year. We also have very small production from the block, which is about 4,000 gross barrels of oil a day.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very small, very small.
componenttext: Very small, very small.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jason Gammel from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason Gammel from Jefferies.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to come back to Jerry's comment about the balance sheet. Do you have any -- as you think about capital allocations, upper limits on, let's say, a leverage ratio that you'd be willing to go to as we have continued low prices? Net debt-to-cap ra
componenttext: Just wanted to come back to Jerry's comment about the balance sheet. Do you have any -- as you think about capital allocations, upper limits on, let's say, a leverage ratio that you'd be willing to go to as we have continued low prices? Net debt-to-cap ratio? Or something along those lines?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Jason, I think, that's a fair question. One that I've always try to maintain the most flexibility and not necessarily commit myself to a ceiling. But that said, first and foremost, I want to make sure it's clear that we are committed to maintaining t
componenttext: Yes. Jason, I think, that's a fair question. One that I've always try to maintain the most flexibility and not necessarily commit myself to a ceiling. But that said, first and foremost, I want to make sure it's clear that we are committed to maintaining that strong balance sheet, and we'll continue to get that commitment throughout this commodity price cycle. I think I said earlier we today, we've got nearly -- or at year-end  we got nearly $5 billion of liquidity, $2.4 billion of that in cash. And the way I look at our investment-grade rating, and I think it's a solid investment-grade rating, is it does reflect: one, that we would expect to maintain throughout this commodity price cycle. And so -- and I think the rating agencies have always historically rated our sector based on a commodity price cycle approach and not just on the environment that they're in. And finally, I think as we've done that, Jason, we've taken that into consideration in designing a 2015 capital program. It does reflect that balance between the need to continue the ongoing investment at high returns while at the same time maintaining that balance sheet. That said, and I think I mentioned it earlier, we're going to continue to watch the current environment and ensure that our capital profile and our operating cash flow profile are appropriately taken into consideration depending on that environment.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful actually. One more, if I could, please. And I apologize if this is a bit in the weeds. But this is the first time I've really seen the data on the Austin Chalk type curves. Trying to understand how it's giving a better IRR than an E
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful actually. One more, if I could, please. And I apologize if this is a bit in the weeds. But this is the first time I've really seen the data on the Austin Chalk type curves. Trying to understand how it's giving a better IRR than an Eagle Ford condensate  well given that the IT is lower, the EUR is lower and the completed well cost is higher but it's about the same level of liquids production?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jason. Great question. So I would encourage everybody to think that the IP of a Lower Eagle Ford well and an Austin Chalk well are similar  with the Lower Eagle Ford being a little bit better. But what really happens is really by the third month, th
componenttext: Sure, Jason. Great question. So I would encourage everybody to think that the IP of a Lower Eagle Ford well and an Austin Chalk well are similar  with the Lower Eagle Ford being a little bit better. But what really happens is really by the third month, those 2 have equalized and then the Austin Chalk well declines are a little bit slower rate. So when you look towards, say, 180-day cumulative production, the Austin Chalk is just higher than the Lower Eagle Ford well in that early life production, particularly the first and second year that drive the value by bringing forth the cash flows from those extra barrels. And as a result, you'll see those attractive return metrics for the Eagle Ford.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Jason, I think, you've already this is the first time, as Lance said in his prepared remarks, that we've actually showed standalone single-well economics for the Austin Chalk. So I appreciate you pointing that out on the call.
componenttext: Yes. Jason, I think, you've already this is the first time, as Lance said in his prepared remarks, that we've actually showed standalone single-well economics for the Austin Chalk. So I appreciate you pointing that out on the call.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Would you be able to share what the first year decline is on the Austin Chalk relative to the Eagle Ford condensate?
componenttext: Would you be able to share what the first year decline is on the Austin Chalk relative to the Eagle Ford condensate?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jason, I don't know that I've actually scrutinized them in that detail. I think that the Eagle Ford range is depending on type curve from 70% to 78%, and it's just a few percent lower, but it -- those incremental barrels make a difference in the Austin Ch
componenttext: Jason, I don't know that I've actually scrutinized them in that detail. I think that the Eagle Ford range is depending on type curve from 70% to 78%, and it's just a few percent lower, but it -- those incremental barrels make a difference in the Austin Chalk. I do think I'd like to reiterate we've said several times before, we can only afford to co-develop Austin Chalk if it would compete favorably with economics. So we're quite pleased to be able to show these and demonstrate that co-developing those horizons is the right choice today because they have very favorable returns together.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell from Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell from Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd like to go back to the cost reductions and just ask a little bit different question. One concern that I think people are talking about is when oil prices were covered in so your costs are going to rise again as well. So I'm wondering how sticky can ma
componenttext: I'd like to go back to the cost reductions and just ask a little bit different question. One concern that I think people are talking about is when oil prices were covered in so your costs are going to rise again as well. So I'm wondering how sticky can margin enhancement based on cost reduction remain?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, it's a good question. I think first and foremost, our current -- in the current market, our focus is with margins compressed by lower commodity prices, it's incumbent upon us to be aggressive in pushing those service costs and tangible good costs do
componenttext: Jeff, it's a good question. I think first and foremost, our current -- in the current market, our focus is with margins compressed by lower commodity prices, it's incumbent upon us to be aggressive in pushing those service costs and tangible good costs down so that we can protect our margins and our short-cycle investments as early as possible. I think -- I hope we've demonstrated that we're doing that. And then it will be up to us to do it. I think even as commodity prices rise, you would see pressure on those. We will obviously work to defend those to the extent we can and push on that. It's not all just cost savings though. We continue to focus on cycle time reductions and efficiencies. And so the efficiencies we can achieve in the market, those will be very sticky and stay with us in a perpetuity basis. Obviously, just like commodity pricing, we will have to some extent less control over service costs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Jeffrey, maybe I would just add too that we have to look at those elements of our cost structure too that would be durable irrespective of where the pricing environment. And I mentioned to you the things that we can pursue, and we're looking at e
componenttext: Yes. And Jeffrey, maybe I would just add too that we have to look at those elements of our cost structure too that would be durable irrespective of where the pricing environment. And I mentioned to you the things that we can pursue, and we're looking at every means available to us. And an obvious one for us is our response to the commodity prices and the commensurate, I would say, reduction in activity, we're taking a -- of course, a hard look on the organizational capacity. And of course, on that front, we're in the midst of implementing an organizational capacity that's going to take some 350 to 400 positions out of our cost structure going forward. So I want to make it very clear that we're doing the things necessary to put in place cost reduction initiatives that will be durable throughout the cycle.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. Some of your peers say that the Springer shale produces the best returns in the Oklahoma resource plays. You have a lot of non-op data, but you appear to be moving into operated Springer drilling at a deliberate pace. I'm just wonderi
componenttext: That's very helpful. Some of your peers say that the Springer shale produces the best returns in the Oklahoma resource plays. You have a lot of non-op data, but you appear to be moving into operated Springer drilling at a deliberate pace. I'm just wondering what's your forward views on the Springer? And that can be both 2015 and beyond?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, we also see the Springer as a potentially a very viable  and maybe among the most viable investments we could make in Oklahoma. We plan to be more active quite frankly, in 2015 in the Springer to test it earlier. As we've gone through the cycle and
componenttext: Jeff, we also see the Springer as a potentially a very viable  and maybe among the most viable investments we could make in Oklahoma. We plan to be more active quite frankly, in 2015 in the Springer to test it earlier. As we've gone through the cycle and looked at where our prudent activity is, we've reduced our forecast activity in Oklahoma. And as a result -- and our need to make sure we're maintaining our very variable SCOOP and stack leases in the area, we found it necessary to start our own operated Springer activity later in the year than possible. That does not reflect the lack of confidence on our part. It really reflects some constraints on the amount of activity we'll have in Oklahoma during the year. By way of having a diverse and large portfolio, particularly in the SCOOP area, which is overlain by the Springer, we've had the benefit of participating -- and I think nearly 3/4 of all Springer wells drilled to date, so we do have a lot of data, and we're advancing our understanding of the reservoir performance early. But of course, we're excited to get our own operated activity later this year.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I can ask just one last quick one. Where are the current Infuser Upper Eagle Ford locations relative to Lower Eagle Ford and the Austin Chalk? And really what I'm thinking of is this Slide 5 that talks about the stack and the frac?
componenttext: Okay. If I can ask just one last quick one. Where are the current Infuser Upper Eagle Ford locations relative to Lower Eagle Ford and the Austin Chalk? And really what I'm thinking of is this Slide 5 that talks about the stack and the frac?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right now, we're early in the Upper Eagle Ford and the stack-and-frac, really bringing on our first pilot group at the Eagle Ford. And so I'd start with that group. We have some places where we're delineating  Austin Chalk, and in some of those areas, we
componenttext: Right now, we're early in the Upper Eagle Ford and the stack-and-frac, really bringing on our first pilot group at the Eagle Ford. And so I'd start with that group. We have some places where we're delineating  Austin Chalk, and in some of those areas, we recognize that the reservoir quality in the Upper Eagle Ford may actually be superior to the Austin Chalk. And so we may develop the Upper Eagle Ford and the Lower Eagle Ford together and so we're testing that now, and it will be sometime before we understand the delineated area. And then on the stack-and-frac, we have some areas within our acreage where we see a very perspective Austin Chalk, Upper Eagle Ford and Lower Eagle Ford and that's about us testing all 3 of those together. And in some cases, we're actually have 2 wells in the Lower Eagle Ford like this first pilot. Again with the first one drilling and not on completions, I think, we have an idea of where that performance is but it's early days and we just -- we need to see that performance before we can talk about how delineated it can be.

componenttext: Thanks. I'd like to thank everyone again for their participation this morning. Please contact me if you have any additional follow-up questions. In conclusion, Marathon Oil is well prepared for the current low-price environment with a 2015 capital program focused on our highest-return investment opportunities and prudent management of cash flows. Combined with maintaining financial flexibility, we're positioning the company to be a stronger E&P in the future. This concludes today's call.
