headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2015 Q1 Conference Call. My name is Vivian, and I will be operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Mr. Chris Phillips. Y
componenttext: Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2015 Q1 Conference Call. My name is Vivian, and I will be operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Mr. Chris Phillips. You may begin, sir.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil  Corporation's first  quarter 2015 earnings call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also, on the call this morning CEO are Lee Tillman, CEO and President; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President an
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil  Corporation's first  quarter 2015 earnings call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. 
Also, on the call this morning CEO are Lee Tillman, CEO and President; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Mitch Little, vice President International and offshore Exploration and Production Operations; and Lance Robertson Vice President, North America production operations and Zach Dailey Director of Investor Relations. As has become our custom, we release prepared remarks last night in conjunction with the earnings release. 
You can find those remarks and the associated slides at marathon oil.com. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. And our comments announces contain forward-looking summation subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. I refer pay you back to the slides, we can find our full Safe Harbor statement. With that, I will turn the call over to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris, and glad to have you back on the call. Let me add my good morning to everyone. I would like to open with just a few comments regarding the elements of over business that we control. Cost of efficiencies and execution. And discuss how our ac
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris, and glad to have you back on the call. Let me add my good morning to everyone. I would like to open with just a few comments regarding the elements of over business that we control. Cost of efficiencies and execution. And discuss how our actions will enhance return and have us well-positioned for the environment as well as when commodity prices show a sustained improvement.
Rigorous cost control across all areas of our business is at the forefront of what we do each and everyday. And the first quarter was no exception. We reduced our North America E&P production cost, per equivalent oil barrel $7.94, down 17% from fourth quarter 2014 and 28% below the year-ago quarter. 
Operating cost reduction is hard work, and our teams had taken on the challenge. There is no one magic bullet, but rather there is a the first range of drivers within these savings. A few examples include more coordinated deployment of contract labor, focus on compressor utilization, aggregating water production in the gathering systems and optimizing our chemical program. 
These types of savings are durable in natue and resilient to the commodity cycle. In, we continue to work with our vendor base and Supply Chain experts to take full advantage of our scale to drive commercial savings.
On the service cost side, we increased our year-to-date captured U.S. unconventional D&C service cost by an additional $25 million, bringing that total to $250 million. That represents a 17% reduction from our revised activity level and we fully expect to secure more saving as the year progresses. 
And finally on G&A. We have taken necessary steps to scale our organizational capacity to match our activity level. And our first quarter workforce reductions are expected to generate annualized net savings of approximately $100 million. 
During the first quarter, we have also made significant progress enhancing our returns  through efficiency gains. Our high specification rigs in the Eagle Ford are a prime example. And delivered pacesetter spud-to-TD of under 7 days, drilling 2,800 feet per day, significantly above the quarterly average of about 1,600 feet per day. In the Eagle Ford, our EUR uplift was 26% for condensate wells and 79% for high GOR wells, relative to fall of last year, while completed well cost have fallen about 15%.
Finally, we are reallocating more than $25 million of capital to the Oklahoma Resource Basin to further advance our understanding of the resource potential, which already stands at over $1 billion oil equivalent barrels on a 2P basis. We are complementing our 2 rig program with incremental high-value non-operated activity, which is a very efficient way to maximize the benefits of our capital dollars.
From an execution standpoint, our team had a great first quarter. We grew production from our 3 U.S. resource plays 11% over the prior quarter and 49% year-over-year. 
Our total E&P net production excluding Libya also posted strong results growing 4% and 20% respectively. All this was accomplished within our plan first quarter capital budget. 
We recorded 98% average operational availability for company operated assets during the first quarter are most economic barrels. Yesterday, we announced a further optimization of our 2015 capital investment and exploration budget to $3.3 billion. This reduction is driven by a relentless focus on capital discipline and maintaining financial flexibility in this period of ongoing price uncertainty. 
We're adjusting activity levels to manage cash flows, while still delivering on our strategic objective and our 3 U.S. resource plays. And with no change to full year E&P production guidance.
In addition, we are continuing our commitment to ongoing portfolio management regardless of commodity cycle. And are targeting non-core asset sales to generate at least $500 million in proceeds. Portfolio management is simply part of what we do as an independent E&P company. 
At quarter end, cash and cash equivalents were approximately $1.1 billion, which combined with our revolving credit facility resulted in a total liquidity of $3.6 billion. 
And in May, we amended the revolving credit facility to increase the available capacity from $2.5 billion to $3 billion and extended the maturity date to 2020. 
Our 2015 capital program was always designed to be front end loaded and the first quarter of 2015 has been a quarter of transition. We are efficiently ramping down to lower activity levels in our U.S. resource plays and will achieve our target of 10 rigs by the end of second quarter. 
Our current plan is to hold that activity level relatively flat for the remainder of the year, averaging a mid-teens rig count for the full year. But just to reiterate, our guidance of 5% to 7% year-over-year production growth for the total company excluding Libya and 20% growth for the U.S. unconventional plays has not changed. 
With the enablers of lower cost, improved efficiencies and strong execution are strategic objectives in the 3 U.S. resource plays remain in full force, even at an overall reduced budget level. We will continue our successful Eagle Ford co-development, expanding beyond the Austin Chalk to the Upper Eagle Ford and our stack-and-frac pilot. Our first quarter stack-and-frac pilot, Which include 1 Austin Chalk, 1 Upper Eagle Ford and 2 lower Eagle Ford wells is online and early performance is encouraging. 
We also placed 5 Upper Eagle Ford wells online in the quarter.
In Oklahoma, we're executing our 2 rig operating program and brought 5 gross opeated wells to sales this quarter all in the SKU. We're also continuing to leverage the benefit of our high-value outside operated program and plan to participate in approximately 50 of those wells this year in that SCOOP Woodford, SCOOP Springer and STACK areas, thanks to reallocation of budget to one of oru most perspective areas.
The capital we reallocated to Oklahoma is primarily focused on increasing our non-operated gross well exposure. This increase in capital demonstrates our belief  that Oklahoma an represents exciting growth opportunity for Marathon Oil that compete very favorably with our existing portfolio. 
We continue to advance our technical work here to be position to step up our activity and prices improve.
And finally in the Bakken, we concluded our enhanced completion pilots and have incorporated the improved design into all wells drilled this quarter. Additionally, initial results from the first of our 4 downspacing pilots are encouraging. The second pilot is currently online, but with fewer 30 days, and the third just completed drilling. Our ultimate objective is to fully integrate the downspacing pilot results with the now concluded completion design trials into our future development plans.
Before we open the call up to questions, I'd like to reiterate that our strong operational execution, cost reductions continued efficiency gains and capital discipline are enhancing our returns today, have us well-positioned for the current price environment and well prepared for sustain commodity price recovery. With that, I'll hand it back to Chris to begin the Q&A.

componenttext: Ed, it's a very good question. And I think you should look at in both of the things you're referencing are important. And first and foremost, the ongoing completions optimization we're doing is clearly driving EUR enhancement. It's a work on state density, profit unloading, fluid loading and active divergent. We continue to see improvements on that side. There is an impact as we focus in this year particularly 2015, on a more focused area to deliver the highest returns in a lower commodity environment. So we are seeing some uplift from that, but I'd encourage to say it's principally driven by the completions efficacy we're pushing all across those basins. That's what driving the real EUR enhancement. And I think that's reflected, if you even look at early IPs again driving that.

I don't think we've seen enough run time yet to say that sustainable, but the signs are encouraging from our perspective. We really like the focus on operating expense. And we have more steps plan to work on that this year. Certainly, the production is a sign that in fact this is the fourth strong quarter in a row of production deliverability out of the business. So I think we're on that road to improvement that we haven't been able to you before Again, I'd like to see more run time. But I'm certainly encouraged by the past quarter and actually the past four quarters that trend is headed in the right direction. And it needs to in this environment.

And we're seeing similar strong results in the stack-and-frac of which the Upper Eagle Ford is a component part. Maybe I'll let Lance just comment on the completion design aspect of that.

componenttext: Doug, I think, Lee actually highlighted it very well. We're testing Upper Eagle Ford more -- in a more full some way spread out over a fairly large area. So we're going to see some desperate result of that as we make sure we fully delineate it. I'd say those results are very much in line with lower Eagle Ford and Austin Chalk in the same respective areas. I would say what's most encouraging to us is Upper Eagle Ford is working well in the areas, where the Austin Chalk has worked a little bit less effectively. And so we see those 2 is increasingly interchangeable. So we can codevelop in a broader area. And very encouraged thus far on the Upper Eagle Ford, both in the Northern in as well as in stack-and-frac. I think to be more clear, we brought 5 Upper Eagle Ford wells that are we announced that are distinctive. And then the stack-and-frac pilot that came on line also includes a 6th or one more incremental  Upper Eagle Ford well that's performing similarly.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. Lee, you obviously had -- my follow-up is on the cost. You clearly are a very strong cost performers. And I think that should we characterize your tenure, since you have been CEO. But I guess my question is assuming we do get a recovery
componenttext: I appreciate that. Lee, you obviously had -- my follow-up is on the cost. You clearly are a very strong cost performers. And I think that should we characterize your tenure, since you have been CEO. But I guess my question is assuming we do get a recovery in the oil price, so I should 70s or something like that. How sustainable that these cost reductions. Is it dynamic with an oil price recovery or you -- do you expect to be able to hang on to lot of these gains. And I'll leave it there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks. We are very focused on cost and I give a lot of credit to our asset teams. As I mentioned in my opening remarks, operating cost is just hard work. It's many things coming together to contribute to driving that unit cost lower, it's both the n
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks. We are very focused on cost and I give a lot of credit to our asset teams. As I mentioned in my opening remarks, operating cost is just hard work. It's many things coming together to contribute to driving that unit cost lower, it's both the numerator as well as the denominator, it's working your absolute cost as well as making sure you're keeping your barrels online and the teams did outstanding job at that this quarter. 
Many of those things, I think operating cost side though are structural in nature. When you think about things around provident maintenance and our ability to efficiently deploy contractors, when you think about efficiently using our installed compression horsepower. When you think about our optimizing of our chemical programs in the oil fill, all of these things in our mine are independent of the commodity price environment. We will carry those forward in time. 
In parallel with that though, we're not turning a blind eye to our scale and our ability to leverage that scale in commercial dialogue as well. And some of those will be more sticky than others in some cases. But we do expect that we'll retain even an element of those commercial gain as we move forward in time. 
But those will have a much closer correlation with the pricing environment that we find ourselves. On the capital side, when you think about the cost reductions we've achieved there. I mean, when you look at kind of the $1.3 million of well in the Eagle Ford, the $1 million of wells that we've achieved in the Bakken, the $600,000 we've achieved per well in Oklahoma. Those capital efficiencies have in large parts and driven by the response of the service industry to participate in the downturn that we're experiencing. 
But even within that, there is a commercial element and efficiency element as well. Our most efficient frac crews can deliver a high number of stages on a monthly basis that's a win-win for both the operator as well as the service provider. And our ability to keep those most efficient crews running, even with this downturn in activity, I believe will be key to our ability to continue momentum as we see price improvements in the future.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

componenttext: And if I could ask -- and maybe to the first question is can you talk a little bit about the rationale behind the decision to drop the incremental rigs. And what that means for the trajectory of 2015 production. Previously you talked about the U.S. onshore showing kind of exit-to-exit incline. Is that still the case?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. Yes. Thanks, Ryan. Let me maybe start with the rationale around the further optimization and reduction of capital budget. I would really describe that decision and really driven by 2 things. First is just a continued focus on capital discipline
componenttext:
Yes. Okay. Yes. Thanks, Ryan. Let me maybe start with the rationale around the further optimization and reduction of capital budget. I would really describe that decision and really driven by 2 things. First is just a continued focus on capital discipline and financial flexibility in a period, where we still have uncertainty around the price environment. We're seeing some strengthening here as late, a lot of macro factors that have driven the downturn are still in place, so we need to recognize that. 
Secondly, with the enablers of both cost efficiency and cost reduction, we're still able to achieve our strategic objectives in each of the 3 U.S. resource plays. And hold good our guidance under that revised budget and drive those efficiencies and savings really down to the balance sheet. 
And if we start to see a sustainable price recovery. We can then reconsider, if we want to take some of that cash flow and redeploy it into the business. In terms of volumes targeting and trajectory, you've mentioned that we had communicated previously and exit-to-exit in the unconventional target  or unconventional production 4Q-to-4Q, 14 to 15 slightly up on an exit-to-exit basis. And we still feel that is consistent with the budget that we're reporting forward today.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

componenttext: Yes. Let me maybe describe it more from an activity perspective than I think the capital will then kind of follow Ryan. As we talked about, you use the word we came in high. We started that deceleration in activity in the first quarter. In fact, our capital -- we delivered essentially against our capital budget in the first quarter. But we did have a momentum affect as we came in from last year. That ramp down is continuing by the time we get to the end of second quarter. We will be at or 10 rig count that we will hold flat for the remainder of the year. And that will set the activity levels in our unconventional play.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Justed question around kind of capital allocation thoughts. As you guys continue to see positive improvements in the SCOOP and STACK. Can you talk about capital allocation decisions as think about heading into 2016. And how that may shift between kind of
componenttext: Justed question around kind of capital allocation thoughts. As you guys continue to see positive improvements in the SCOOP and STACK. Can you talk about capital allocation decisions as think about heading into 2016. And how that may shift between kind of the Bakken, Eagle Ford and Oklahoma asset base?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. absolutely. As we talked in the past, we look at capital allocation down really to a type curve level. And it is a competition for capital allocation amongst the 3 resource plays. Specifically, when we look at the SCOOP and the STACK and we think abo
componenttext:
Yes. absolutely. As we talked in the past, we look at capital allocation down really to a type curve level. And it is a competition for capital allocation amongst the 3 resource plays. Specifically, when we look at the SCOOP and the STACK and we think about incremental cash flows that coming available to reinvest in the business. We're going to drive those the highest return opportunities. 
Today, when you look at our single well economics that's really the Eagle Ford and Oklahoma. In the highest-quality of the Bakken, the Mrymidon, and as we integrate both the completion trial results and the downspacing results, we'll see how those pair in the capital allocation decision. But there is no doubt that as incremental capital becomes available that will be directed to the U.S. unconventional, and Eagle Ford and Oklahoma will be the strongest competitors for that capital.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just a follow-up to that question. You mentioned potential north $500 million in non-core asset sales. Just curious, as you kind of see affirming of the commodity price here and potential execution of those transactions. Should we expect t
componenttext: Great. And then just a follow-up to that question. You mentioned potential north $500 million in non-core asset sales. Just curious, as you kind of see affirming of the commodity price here and potential execution of those transactions. Should we expect to see that redeployed potentially into the ground in the back half of this year heading into 2016 in regards to activity. Or can you provide a bit of an update on how you're thinking about the capital allocation from those transactions?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, first maybe just a few thoughts on the transaction, the potential transaction themselves. In our view, portfolio management is part of what we do, it's an evergreen process. These are non-core assets that we're talking about. What that means to
componenttext: Yes. Well, first maybe just a few thoughts on the transaction, the potential transaction themselves. In our view, portfolio management is part of what we do, it's an evergreen process. These are non-core assets that we're talking about. What that means to us, these are assets that are not going to compete for capital allocation. And likely have higher value in someone else's portfolio. This process would be going on irrespective of the commodity stockholder we find ourselves. And because we think again, these assets will have appeal to the right portfolio. Assuming success in those divestment activities, then we'll look at that at that point in time and see how constructive the price environment is, then make a decision as whether or not we bring that to the balance sheet or redeploy it into our organic investment portfolio, which is very competitive.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up a little bit on some of the capital allocation questions in SCOOP, STACK and Springer you reallocated capital there. But can you talk to your preference on balancing non-operated spending versus accelerating your own spending. And sp
componenttext: I wanted to follow up a little bit on some of the capital allocation questions in SCOOP, STACK and Springer you reallocated capital there. But can you talk to your preference on balancing non-operated spending versus accelerating your own spending. And specifically, what the milestone you would be looking for between price, costs and well results for you to make a material acceleration in your operated activity levels?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Absolutely. Yes. Well, first of all, the 2 rig operated program beyond delivering very profitable and competitive wells is also allowing us to protect our pretty significant leasehold position in Oklahoma over 300,000 acres. So that is an important e
componenttext:
Yes. Absolutely. Yes. Well, first of all, the 2 rig operated program beyond delivering very profitable and competitive wells is also allowing us to protect our pretty significant leasehold position in Oklahoma over 300,000 acres. So that is an important element of our operated program and why we wanted to continue that commitment going into this year. 
There is no doubt, but there has been an activity uptick in Oklahoma in our non-operated portfolio, as those folks that are multi-basin operators direct more capital into Oklahoma. We walk to participate in the high-quality wells that because it simply expands a number of data points in our knowledge base around the resource potential that exist in Oklahoma. 
Having said that though, and kind of consistent with my previous comments, to the extent that we see a sustained strengthening in prices that we see incremental cash flow come available. Oklahoma our operated program very compete very favorably for those incremental dollars..

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, I have a somewhat new on to follow-up to, I think Ryan Todd's earlier question with regards to how you're thinking about year end. What I'm trying to figure out is or trying to figure out is whether on a going forward basis, you're sayin
componenttext: Got it. And then, I have a somewhat new on to follow-up to, I think Ryan Todd's earlier question with regards to how you're thinking about year end. What I'm trying to figure out is or trying to figure out is whether on a going forward basis, you're saying, you can do exactly the same as previously as we look into next year. But with fewer rigs. And so I guess my question is with your 1Q having beaten we expectation, you now have a little bit of a buffer to lower activity and get back to the same points in terms of year end production that you are at before. Is that just the case or is what you're saying, you're going to be on a growth trajectory from the year end point that was no different with a lower rig count than it was previously with a higher rig count?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think we want to make sure that we're well prepared to reengage and ramp-up in the unconventionals. Our base plan this year is to be at the 10 rig count by second quarter. We think that is the right answer from a capital discipline standpoint
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think we want to make sure that we're well prepared to reengage and ramp-up in the unconventionals. Our base plan this year is to be at the 10 rig count by second quarter. We think that is the right answer from a capital discipline standpoint. But we have the execution capacity to step into more activity as the macro environment supports that decision. And we'll be well-positioned to do that. And one of the advantages of course of holding onto our best rigs, our best crew that it does position you very favorably to step back into that high activity or higher activity period. So as we look ahead to 2016, we view that as an opportunity to a stat that ramp up again assuming that we see that constructive price environment in front of us. And within our course 2015 budget, we do have some items, some investment that will be either reduced or falling out of the '16 program that will provide us a little bit of accommodation space even on a flat budget outlook going into '16.

But at this point of time, we're still committed to that dividend John.

componenttext: That's helpful. And thinking about cadence. In each of you onshore resource plays and your second quarter guidance. Can you break out some idea of expectations of how you maintain the Eagle Ford of higher activity level. And then, I guess, Oklahoma. and what happens in the Bakken as you slowed more rapidly there. Just trying to get an idea of production in each of those as you go through the year.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, just in terms of cadence to places. It's really again driven by rig activity and frac crew activity. A case in point David, we're already at a single rig of activity in the Bakken. But within that single rig capacity, we are very confident that
componenttext:
Yes. Well, just in terms of cadence to places. It's really again driven by rig activity and frac crew activity. A case in point David, we're already at a single rig of activity in the Bakken. But within that single rig capacity, we are very confident that we will still be able to deliver on our downspacing pilots, which was a key strategic objective for this year in the Bakken. 
In Oklahoma, our 2 rig program, operated program was largely dictated by our desire to ensure we protected all of our high-quality leaseholds, while continuing to develop the SCOOP area as well. And then of course leverage to the extent that we can, the non-operated side of the business to leverage our capital very efficiently. And then on the Eagle Ford, it's really taking full advantage of some of the efficiencies that we are seeing on the drilling front. And hopefully being able to extrapolate those moving forward into the second half of the year.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, just to make simple math, if you take your gross operated wells in each area subtract first quarter and divide by 3. Is that a rough approximation of completed well cadence?
componenttext: I guess, just to make simple math, if you take your gross operated wells in each area subtract first quarter and divide by 3. Is that a rough approximation of completed well cadence?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it is a rough approximation as -- because as we get down to that -- we are a little bit in that, that still that transitional period, David as come out of the first quarter, where we're still kind of decelerating and ramping down. But as we k
componenttext: Yes. I think it is a rough approximation as -- because as we get down to that -- we are a little bit in that, that still that transitional period, David as come out of the first quarter, where we're still kind of decelerating and ramping down. But as we kind of hit back end of the second quarter. That really is setting the pace as we look forward in the second half of the year. Is that help?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Lee, I apologize for delivering this point. But on the topic of pivoting back toward increasing activity levels. You mentioned consistently that you want to see a sustainable price recovery before you begin the add rig. Can you just talk a little bit more
componenttext: Lee, I apologize for delivering this point. But on the topic of pivoting back toward increasing activity levels. You mentioned consistently that you want to see a sustainable price recovery before you begin the add rig. Can you just talk a little bit more about what that really means and what you want to see on prices were $65 a barrel in the forward curve later this year. Do you need to see a higher-price or is it more of a duration question or is it just a matter of you are becoming more comfortable with the macro internally. And then relatedly, you mentioned a number of times, you want to be well prepare to reengage. Are there any bottlenecks that you're aware that you can hinder in efficient ramp backup. And really just wondering, what risks your most focused on mitigating in a ramp-up scenario. And how you believe the company's is well-position to ramp up whenever you feel that the time is right?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, let me take the question on the kind of the price outlook and what we're really looking for their from a trigger point -- standpoint. And then maybe I'll defer the kind of the bottleneck question around our unconventional over to Lance. But on
componenttext: Yes. Well, let me take the question on the kind of the price outlook and what we're really looking for their from a trigger point -- standpoint. And then maybe I'll defer the kind of the bottleneck question around our unconventional over to Lance. But on the question of what is the trigger, what are the signs that we're looking for should it give us confidence to begin a ramp-up in our unconventionals For us, you're right, the forward curve is looking around 65. I think if we saw sustainment kind of 65-plus certainly going into the back half of the year in '16. To us, it's more about seeing that being a sustainable recovery and having the confidence to come back and begin to ramp up. But if we saw those levels, we felt that the macros were supported and constructive of a sustainable 65-plus kind of range. We feel very confident going into 2016 with a ramp-up in our unconventional. Let me kind of hand over to Lance to address more the question about execution bottlenect as start thinking about a ramp-up in the unconventional.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Guy, as we reduce activity, we have a clear focus on retaining the most efficient service providers crews and equipment, which naturally creates an efficiency drive on our existing activity that remains. But it also positions us well as we grow. Where exi
componenttext:
Guy, as we reduce activity, we have a clear focus on retaining the most efficient service providers crews and equipment, which naturally creates an efficiency drive on our existing activity that remains. But it also positions us well as we grow. Where existing relationships with those providers, many of those are going to be the most equip to bring equipment and people back into the sector is on the side. 
So we think, we're going to be comfortable there. and I think our drive to be really efficient, it's naturally a place, where service providers would want to work for us before others. And so I think, we'll have some opportunity there. Having said that, we do have some concern that labor forces leaving the energy space during this time. And it's going to make ramping up more challenging than ramping down. And I think that's something that not just us, but other will have to face in the market.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

componenttext: And our next question comes from Scott Hanold from RBC.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I might just and again to the same theme. And just maybe take it to protect. As you look into ramping up, if you do get a sustained price increase. Would you all be willing to utilize your credit facility to do that or do you have a tendency not to wan
componenttext: If I might just and again to the same theme. And just maybe take it to protect. As you look into ramping up, if you do get a sustained price increase. Would you all be willing to utilize your credit facility to do that or do you have a tendency not to want to, I guess add that to ramp up. And if I can on my second question right away, maybe this is one for J.R.. Is there any change in view on hedging, because it looks like you obviously now have some colors there with some floors. Can you just give us a sense of how that works into the equation.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. I talked before, I don't think it's necessarily a change in view. We always looked at commodity risk management much more broadly than just derivative usage. But I think, we've been clear and transparent that if we saw opportunities in the mar
componenttext: Yes, Scott. I talked before, I don't think it's necessarily a change in view. We always looked at commodity risk management much more broadly than just derivative usage. But I think, we've been clear and transparent that if we saw opportunities in the market to protect our cash flows, while still giving us a piece of that upside in the commodity price that we do willing to do that. And I think we've demonstrated it on a scale at least for 2015 as well as beginning to look at the 2016 market, all predominantly through this use of colors. Again, ensure that we're participating in that upside. I mean, in terms of the balance sheet, again, I arguably, I'm definitely leaning on the balance sheet this year. Although, I'm reinvesting the proceeds that we received from Norway in those high return North American unconventionals. And we've been very clear that we are willing to lean, but we're not willing to stress that balance sheet. So it definitely the balancing act, but don't forget, when those commodity prices do improve or as they do improve, the rest of my portfolio that 70% weighted for oil is going also increase my operating cash flows, but they are more further support our ability to reinvest in increase activity.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

So I'm wondering, if can you give us a very early outlook on what CapEx and what production might look like in 2016, under a $65 environment.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015

componenttext: Yes. Lastly, it is a bit early from a budget cycle perspective. But of course, we're continuing to think about what 2016 may look like under various pricing scenarios. But I think under the scenario that you describe, which is a confident kind of $65 firm market going into 2016. In that sense, we could take a flat budget into 2016 and still have a ramp-up in the unconventionals, due to the fact that we have other investments falling away in 2015. And that would of course be our planned. And then, we watch for other signals in terms of how far we would want to go beyond that flat budget to toward our ramp-up and activity. But we can absolutely ramp-up in the unconventionals on a flat 33 budget in 2016 in the environment that you just described.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: We haven't gotten a lot on international. So I thought I try a few on that front. In the U.K., you guys obviously had interest in the past in selling the assets. But then couple of months ago, we got a positive change in the tax treatment in the U.K. sect
componenttext: We haven't gotten a lot on international. So I thought I try a few on that front. In the U.K., you guys obviously had interest in the past in selling the assets. But then couple of months ago, we got a positive change in the tax treatment in the U.K. sector. So did that change your stance on whether that's something that you want to keep for the long run.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Pavel, thanks for the question. As you said, we did entertain a marketing effort last year. We did not receive offers that we thought represented full value for the assets. And so we've taken position that we're going to continue to operate those ass
componenttext: Yes. Pavel, thanks for the question. As you said, we did entertain a marketing effort last year. We did not receive offers that we thought represented full value for the assets. And so we've taken position that we're going to continue to operate those assets in a most efficient manner we can. And certainly, we are focused this year in this down environment on both commercial leverage extending some of our scale with strategic suppliers from North America across there and some structural changes. No doubt, you've seen some of the equal time rotation work we're doing, which is decreasing our overall cost structure focused on chemicals, logistics, all of those things. And of course, the tax reforms that have been introduced in the U.K. are helpful to us, but we're at a point in the asset life, where they are not as material to us as they might be to earlier life assets.

componenttext: I'd say just Pavel, we're just going back to our discussion around portfolio management. That's kind of part of what we do that includes our activities in Kurdistan as well. As you can imagine with the dynamics now in the KRG, even if we were to take a position of want to commoditize those assets, it might be relatively tough. But those are assets that when we look at the above ground risk, we'll  need to consider their long-term fit in our portfolio.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jason Gammel from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason Gammel from Jefferies.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask little bit about the stack-and-frac. Can you talk a little bit about the actual configuration of that. And if you're move into a program, what it would mean for something like inter lateral spacing within or Bakken. And then maybe talk a l
componenttext: I wanted to ask little bit about the stack-and-frac. Can you talk a little bit about the actual configuration of that. And if you're move into a program, what it would mean for something like inter lateral spacing within or Bakken. And then maybe talk a little bit about the cost efficiency that comes from the process.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jason. The stack-and-frac, we defined and I think, I can't remember the exact time we actually pull that out. But if look at the diagram, we put out in our previous press releases. We're showing that as a 4 interval co-development, 4 vertical interv
componenttext:
Sure, Jason. The stack-and-frac, we defined and I think, I can't remember the exact time we actually pull that out. But if look at the diagram, we put out in our previous press releases. We're showing that as a 4 interval co-development, 4 vertical intervals, which is Austin Chalk, Upper Eagle Ford, and then 2 wells in the lower Eagle Ford. We would actually broaden that to say that we'll have stack-and-frac pilots, but it'll just be 3, which is Austin Chalk Upper Eagle Ford as well as Lower Eagle Ford. So it's that vertical co-development. We like the rates from all 3 of those horizons, when they have been stack, we announced that first pilot in that. And we have some additional pilots flowing, we'll be able to talk about those as thney mature. But in terms of the efficiency you're referencing there, and this opportunity we really like the efficiency, because we're codeveloping all those horizons from the same pad. So we're spudding from rig to rig. And it gives us an opportunity to address those efficient. So if you look at those pilots, where you see is that in most of those cases, it's 40 wells -- 40-acre spacing in the same zone. 
In the lower Eagle Ford, where we have 2 Lower Eagle Ford wells, that's 40-acre vertical. But if you it's really 20-acre between them. So it's like a Chevron or a D pattern, if you will in that lower Eagle Ford, when you put 2 in there. But generally, same zone 40-acre with the exception of that. In the Lower Eagle Ford, we actually separated into, here it gets confusing the Upper Lower Eagle Ford, and Lower, Lower Eagle Ford. Creative names, I know. So it's generally 40-acre with the exception, when you put 2 in there in the Lower Eagle Ford, it gets what's effectively 20-acre spacing, but they are offsetting that pattern.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's really useful. If I could just ask one more question. Just on what the discussion about capital allocation over the course of the call. In a low price environment you really had to taking the stock was important to you. I'm just kind of wonde
componenttext: Okay. That's really useful. If I could just ask one more question. Just on what the discussion about capital allocation over the course of the call. In a low price environment you really had to taking the stock was important to you. I'm just kind of wondering, how Deepwater exploration now fits into your future plans just given that, even if you're successful the amount of capital that would be required for development and the rate of return on that may not be even be competitive, so what were you doing onshore.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think, there you're hitting upon really the contrast between the short cycle and the long cycle investments. And to be fair to the Deepwater, you need to look at it in terms of full cycle returns as well not incremental returns. So I guess
componenttext:
Yes. Well, I think, there you're hitting upon really the contrast between the short cycle and the long cycle investments. And to be fair to the Deepwater, you need to look at it in terms of full cycle returns as well not incremental returns. 
So I guess it really comes down to your view of that longer-term price outlook over time. If you take a view to where that longer-term outlook is constructive. Then Deepwater has a role to play in continuing to meet part of the future demand. 
And in our view, the high-quality Deepwater assets still have the stability to compete in that longer-term environment. I think the question for us becomes one of scale and cash flows and our ability to support the large investment dollars that are required in Deepwater development. And so we're going to be very selective and very focused this year's exploration program, as it's half of the spend that we were last year. So we're going to bring a very short focus to that program. That reflects the fact that these longer cycle investments can have a role to play in your portfolio.

componenttext: I wanted to ask you, if you could provide a little bit more color on the Oklahoma resource non activity. And what I'm really wondering is this just narrowing operated activity without rig or does it present an additional opportunity to perhaps compress the learning curve on areas about which you have a less defined vision?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, it clearly accelerates the opportunities you're describing. We are learning an enormous amount from all the offset operated activity. That activity is predominantly focused in the highest values areas within the SCOOP and in the STACK, where we have
componenttext:
Jeff, it clearly accelerates the opportunities you're describing. We are learning an enormous amount from all the offset operated activity. That activity is predominantly focused in the highest values areas within the SCOOP and in the STACK, where we have acreage. We clearly want to participate and capture that acreage and convert to it HPP. But we also want tot take in leverage all of the early production, the petrophysics and the learnings we can have from that. One of the things, we really appreciate about the Oklahoma Resource Basin is we're getting several multiples of data from the activity that we get from an operated activity for very few capital dollars. So we're learning tremendously at very lower risk, really accelerates our description of the resource to the well productivity, and allows us to design our own pilots and grow and get ready to grow scale activity much more rapidly. 
I think our increase in capital spend in that area reflects that as Oklahoma's continues to be resident in the returns that can deliver. The activity in Oklahoma is also been resilient. And we're just responding to make sure, we don't miss any valuable opportunity.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll aslo just ad dthat. Even though, we're excited about the incremental information that can be gained from leveraging into non-operate. We have a very good understanding of Oklahoma. I mean, we have already greater than 1 billion barrels oil equiva
componenttext: And I'll aslo just ad dthat. Even though, we're excited about the incremental information that can be gained from leveraging into non-operate. We have a very good understanding of Oklahoma. I mean, we have already greater than 1 billion barrels oil equivalent in 2P resource subscribe to Oklahoma. So this is really just continuing to move that and progress further. And doing that and essentially a low price environment.

Following on your earlier remarks about well performance was the decision to pull capital out of the Eagle Ford well increasing capital in Oklahoma. An example of capital competition or was it more that Oklahoma offered opportunity to increase activity without having to commit to another rig.

componenttext: Yes. I think it was one that Oklahoma does complete for capital very favorably. If you go back to our single well economics and you look at those even head-to-head with the Eagle Ford. Those wells are on strictly from an economic standpoint absolutely competitive. But we saw a unique opportunity in Oklahoma. I think as Lance very well described to really leverage our money there to continue to expand our knowledge and insights around the Oklahoma Resource Basin. So we felt that was a unique opportunity. It's largely being driven by Oklahoma continuing to attract more capital from other operators portfolios. And we want to participate in that.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again for a lot of reasons, we can't go into details on exactly what we would place in the non-core assets. But suffice to say, because of the definition of non-core, we view these as being not significant from a reserves and volume standpoint. So
componenttext:
Yes. Again for a lot of reasons, we can't go into details on exactly what we would place in the non-core assets. But suffice to say, because of the definition of non-core, we view these as being not significant from a reserves and volume standpoint. 
So we would not as being highly impactful to our forward guidance. And to the extent, we're successful on those transactions, we'll communicate both clearly and transparently into the market. But for now, I think suffice to say, we have identified a select list of non-core properties that we feel like will struggle to compete for capital, could potentially have higher value in someone else's portfolio. And we want to pursue those and accelerate those cash flows, either to the balance sheet or for redeployment.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, that's fair. I guess the last question I have is as you think about reducing rig count, reducing CapEx, maintaining production. And you're seeing different, different ways of testing wells and completion design. Is there anything you're doing differen
componenttext: No, that's fair. I guess the last question I have is as you think about reducing rig count, reducing CapEx, maintaining production. And you're seeing different, different ways of testing wells and completion design. Is there anything you're doing differently in terms of choking back to production or anything like that to sort of smooth out, I mean some companies are going for more the drill, but on completed to the backlog. Clearly, you're not net. But knows, we think about the exit rate for '15 and all the discussion about CapEx and future drilling activity in '16. If there was incentive to sort of let's call smooth out things little bit as you set yourself up for the next up cycle?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Roger, manage each of the individual wells to deliver the highest value in that investment. So we generally let the technical and operations teams manage those wells effectively. So rather than try for example, flow them on a smaller choke size and smooth
componenttext: Roger, manage each of the individual wells to deliver the highest value in that investment. So we generally let the technical and operations teams manage those wells effectively. So rather than try for example, flow them on a smaller choke size and smooth that out. We're looking for highest value on that investment return today. The wells we're investing in this quarter are generating good returns in current pricing. So we have confidence, we can do that. And decisions would really let the technical teams make. We've scaled our activity in North America in logical increments that make sense. So for example, on the Eagle Ford, we want to keep whole frac to rather than partial frac lease to drive efficiency or we scale the drilling activity to match that. Part of the reduction we've taken in activity there is actually not just related to capital spend, but just recognizing is the efficiencies continue to improve. We were going to have to let go 1 or more rigs anyway to make sure, we didn't over drill our plan for the year. And so we'll keep doing that. And I think as you noted also, we have not been building a backlog of drill, but uncompleted wells for use later in the year. We're really managing that as an operations to basket of wells to complete to manage our stimulation operations smoothly and efficiently.

And I think as we move that to scale that is going to allow us to really accelerate on that learning curve particularly when it comes to DNC cost.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil  Corporation's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations.  Also on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, CEO and President; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO;
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil  Corporation's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations.  Also on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, CEO and President; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Mitch Little, Vice President, International and Offshore Exploration and Production Operations; Lance Robertson, Vice President, North America Production Operations; and Zach Dailey, Director of Investor Relations. 
As has become our custom, we released prepared remarks last night in conjunction with the earnings release. You can find those remarks and the associated slides at marathonoil.com. 
As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. And our comments and answers to questions will contain forward-looking information subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. I refer you back to the aforementioned slides, where you can find our full safe harbor statement. 
With that, I will turn the call over to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 07, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris, and glad to have you back on the call. Let me add my good morning to everyone. I'd like to open with just a few comments regarding the elements of our business that we control, costs, efficiencies and execution, and discuss how our actions
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris, and glad to have you back on the call. Let me add my good morning to everyone. I'd like to open with just a few comments regarding the elements of our business that we control, costs, efficiencies and execution, and discuss how our actions will enhance returns and have us well positioned for the current environment as well as when commodity prices show a sustained improvement.
Rigorous cost control across all areas of our business is at the forefront of what we do each and every day, and the first quarter was no exception. We reduced our North America E&P production cost per oil equivalent barrel to $7.94, down 17% from fourth quarter 2014 and 28% below the year-ago quarter. Operating cost reduction is hard work, and our teams have taken on that challenge. There is no one magic bullet, but rather, there's a diverse range of drivers within these savings. A few examples include more coordinated deployment of contract labor, focus on compressor utilization, aggregating water production in the gathering systems and optimizing our chemical programs.  These types of savings are durable in nature and resilient to the commodity cycle. In parallel, we continue to work with our vendor base and supply chain experts to take full advantage of our scale to drive commercial savings.
On the service cost side, we increased our year-to-date captured U.S. unconventional D&C service cost by an additional $25 million, bringing that total to $250 million. That represents a 17% reduction from our revised activity levels, and we fully expect to secure more savings as the year progresses. 
And finally, on G&A, we have taken the necessary steps to scale our organizational capacity to match our activity level. And our first quarter workforce reductions are expected to generate annualized net savings of approximately $100 million. 
During the first quarter, we have also made significant progress enhancing our returns through efficiency gains. Our high-specification rigs in the Eagle Ford are a prime example and delivered pacesetter spud-to-TD results of under 7 days, drilling 2,800 feet per day, significantly above the quarterly average of about 1,600 feet per day. In the Eagle Ford, our EUR uplift was 26% for condensate wells and 79% for high-GOR oil wells relative to fall of last year, while completed well costs have fallen about 15%.
Finally, we are reallocating more than $25 million of capital to the Oklahoma Resource Basins to further advance our understanding of the resource potential, which already stands at over $1 billion oil equivalent barrels on a 2P basis. We are complementing our 2-rig operated program with incremental high-value, non-operated activity, which is a very efficient way to maximize the benefits of our capital dollars.
From an execution standpoint, our teams had a great first quarter. We grew production from our 3 U.S. resource plays 11% over the prior quarter and 49% year-over-year. Our total E&P net production, excluding Libya, also posted strong results, growing 4% and 20%, respectively. All this was accomplished within our planned first quarter capital budget. We recorded 98% average operational availability for company-operated assets during the first quarter, our most economic barrels. Yesterday, we announced a further optimization of our 2015 capital investment and exploration budget to $3.3 billion. This reduction is driven by a relentless focus on capital discipline and maintaining financial flexibility in this period of ongoing price uncertainty. We're adjusting activity levels to manage cash flows while still delivering on our strategic objectives in our 3 U.S. resource plays and with no change to full year E&P production guidance.
In addition, we are continuing our commitment to ongoing portfolio management regardless of commodity cycle and are targeting non-core asset sales to generate at least $500 million in proceeds. Portfolio management is simply part of what we do as an independent E&P company. 
At quarter-end, cash and cash equivalents were approximately $1.1 billion, which, combined with our revolving credit facility, resulted in a total liquidity of $3.6 billion. And in May, we amended the revolving credit facility to increase the available capacity from $2.5 billion to $3 billion and extended the maturity date to 2020. 
Our 2015 capital program was always designed to be front end-loaded, and the first quarter of 2015 has been a quarter of transition. We are efficiently ramping down to lower activity levels in our U.S. resource plays and will achieve our target of 10 rigs by the end of second quarter. Our current plan is to hold that activity level relatively flat for the remainder of the year, averaging a mid-teens rig count for the full year. But just to reiterate, our guidance of 5% to 7% year-over-year production growth for the total company, excluding Libya, and 20% growth for the U.S. unconventional plays have not changed. 
With the enablers of lower costs, improved efficiencies and strong execution, our strategic objectives in the 3 U.S. resource plays remain in full force, even at an overall reduced budget level. We will continue our successful Eagle Ford co-development, expanding beyond the Austin Chalk to the Upper Eagle Ford and our stack-and-frac pilots. Our first quad stack-and-frac pilot, which includes 1 Austin Chalk, 1 Upper Eagle Ford and 2 Lower Eagle Ford wells, is online, and early performance is encouraging. We also placed 5 Upper Eagle Ford wells online in the quarter.
In Oklahoma, we are executing our 2-rig operated program and brought 5 gross operated wells to sales this quarter, all in the SCOOP. We're also continuing to leverage the benefit of our high-value, outside-operated program and plan to participate in approximately 50 of those wells this year in the SCOOP Woodford, SCOOP Springer and STACK areas, thanks to our reallocation of budget to one of our most prospective areas.
The capital we've reallocated to Oklahoma is primarily focused on increasing our non-operated gross well exposure. This increase in capital demonstrates our belief that Oklahoma represents an exciting growth opportunity for Marathon Oil that competes very favorably with our existing portfolio. We continue to advance our technical work here to be positioned to step up our activity as prices improve.
And finally, in the Bakken, we've concluded our enhanced completion pilots and have incorporated the improved design into all wells drilled this quarter. Additionally, initial results from the first of our 4 downspacing pilots are encouraging. The second pilot is currently online but was fewer than 30 days, and the third just completed drilling. Our ultimate objective is to fully integrate the downspacing pilot results with the now concluded completion design trials into our future development plans.
Before we open the call up to questions, I'd like to reiterate that our strong operational execution, cost reductions, continued efficiency gains and capital discipline are enhancing our returns today, have us well positioned for the current price environment and well prepared for a sustained commodity price recovery. 
With that, I'll hand it back to Chris to begin the Q&A.
