headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also on the call this morning are Lee Tillman; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Mitch Little, Vice Pre
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also on the call this morning are Lee Tillman; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Mitch Little, Vice President, International and Offshore Exploration and Production Operations;  Lance Robertson, Vice President, North America Production Operations; and Zach Dailey, Director of Investor Relations.  
As has become our custom, we released prepared remarks last night in conjunction with the earnings release. You can find those remarks and the associated slides at marathonoil.com.  
As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. And our comments and answers to questions will contain forward-looking information subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. I refer  you back to the aforementioned slides, where you can find our full safe harbor statement.  
With that, I will turn the call over to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, thanks, Chris. Let me add my good morning. I'd like to open with just a few comments regarding the elements of our business that we control: cost, efficiencies and execution, and discuss our actions will enhance returns and have us positi
componenttext:
All right. Well, thanks, Chris. Let me add my good morning. I'd like to open with just a few comments regarding the elements of our business that we control: cost, efficiencies and execution, and discuss our actions will enhance returns and have us position for the current environment, as well as when commodity prices show a sustained improvement. 
We find ourselves in a continued low and volatility pricing environment. We've taken the 5 action consistent with our business plan released in first quarter, activity and CapEx reductions, capital efficiency and productivity gains, operating and G&A cost reductions and non-core asset divestments. We have successfully and efficiently achieved our planned activity reductions in the 3 resource plays to yield a program that will hold production volumes for the balance of 2015 while still progressing our strategic objectives in all 3 plays. Those objectives are codevelopment in the Eagle Ford, integration of completion and downspacing pilots in the Bakken and protecting our valuable lease holds in both our SCOOP and STACK positions, while investing our high return outside operating opportunities. 
Even with these planned reductions, we will still deliver on our growth targets of 5% to 7% for the overall company and 20% for the resource plays year-over-year. We've also raised the low end of our total company EMT full year production guidance, essentially increasing the midpoint despite that announced asset sale. Our planned deceleration and capital spend is evident in the sequential reduction in our capital program by almost $500 million and the significant decrease in wells to sales relative to the first quarter. We had already cut exploration spend by half from last year and are continuing to moderate Ford commitments as we reset our strategy, including withdrawal from new country entries that do not compete for capital allocation. 
For capital efficiency, we have captured greater than $300 million in DNC savings in the U.S. resource plays or about 20% and are driving for more. Our completed well costs continue to fall and are well productivity continues to improve. 
We have reduced unit operating cost in both of our E&P segments from the year ago quarter. More than 30% in North America and 25% in international ex- Libya and have reflected this in our forward full year guidance for unit cost lowering them $1.25 and $1 per boe, respectively. 
We were quick to address G&A cost in the first quarter as we finalize our activity plans and implemented a workforce reduction of about 400 people that is expected to generate annualized net savings of approximately $100 million. 
Our non-core asset sales are progressing with signed agreements for approximately $100 million toward our target of over $500 million. This recent transaction confirmed that the right assets will generate a competitive process and yield compelling deal metrics even in the current environment. All of these actions combined to give us confidence in driving toward cash flow neutrality in 2016 inclusive of non-core asset sales. 
We are only just beginning the budget process for 2016, but we'll focus capital allocation to the high return U.S. resource plays as several longer cycle investments run their course by the end of this year and exploration spend continues to decline. 
Our forward look positions us well below our 2015 $3.3 billion capital program. And while our 2015 quarterly exit rate will be in the range of $700 million and $750 million, we still have the ability to flex down or up as required. 
Additionally, we expect expense reduction and collateral efficiency to continue into 2016. We are optimizing our business around a lower cost structure, holding production levels and protecting our investment in our high return U.S. resource plays while challenging all other spend in excess of that. 
Our U.S. resource plays continue to deliver solid returns at current pricing with capital efficiency and enhanced productivity lowering breakeven prices. 
Our last disclosure on our 5-year drilling inventory showed 70% of our inventory profitable at $50 a barrel WTI, and that analysis did not incorporate our most recent completed well cost savings and productivity enhancements. 
We have multiple years of high-quality inventory that can deliver competitive returns in the current environment. 
We do not believe this is a time to be accelerating inventory in associated production from short cycle investments. We believe it's the time for discipline, continuous cost reduction, sustainable efficiency, maximizing returns and balance sheet protection. We continue to have a strong balance sheet with $5.5 billion in liquidity at quarter end. 
As we move into the second half of 2015, we look forward to providing more results from our codevelopment in the Eagle Ford, operated downspacing activity in Oklahoma and resource updates for the U.S. unconventional plays. 
I want to conclude by taking a moment to recognize our Marathon Oil employees who have been the driving force behind our results in this very dynamic environment. They have stepped forward to lead our efforts in cost reduction and efficiency gains and have kept their focus on execution despite the distraction of the macroenvironment. Our employees are committed to an enterprise first view for which I'm both thankful and proud. 
With that, I'll hand it back to Chris to begin the Q&A.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our first question comes from Ed Westlake.
componenttext: Our first question comes from Ed Westlake.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to touch base on completions in the Eagle Ford. I mean, obviously, the whole industry has been experimenting further with completion technology and seeing some incremental results. Just wanted to get a sense of how you see completions, where y
componenttext: Just wanted to touch base on completions in the Eagle Ford. I mean, obviously, the whole industry has been experimenting further with completion technology and seeing some incremental results. Just wanted to get a sense of how you see completions, where you are in terms of testing and what improvements that you see particularly in Eagle Ford?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ed, I would say for second quarter and actually the previous couple of quarters, the focus in the Eagle Ford has been to maintain the very high initial production and the high we have. We have a some of the highest in each of those at South Texas even tho
componenttext: Ed, I would say for second quarter and actually the previous couple of quarters, the focus in the Eagle Ford has been to maintain the very high initial production and the high we have. We have a some of the highest in each of those at South Texas even though we've taken, for example, in the second quarter have taken more than 1/3 of the total wells are outside of the lower Eagle Ford in either of the Austin Chalk or the Upper Eagle Ford. We really accelerated that codevelopment and multiple horizons 3 and in some cases, 4 horizons developed across our acreage position, particularly in Karnes County, to see how much vertical density in that total package we could create, as well as the 40-acre, and in some cases, 30-acre space that we have horizontally that. So what really most excited about is even as we materially increase the complexity of the codevelopment through the stack-and-frac pilots, what we've seen is that the production for well and the other horizons, specifically the Upper Eagle Ford and the Austin Chalk, have competed very favorably with the traditional lower Eagle Ford. So we're still getting great results in are competitive returns among the best in our portfolio from all 3 those horizons, which long-term inventory and really helps our capital efficiency as we can move to develop more wells per pad across the Eagle Ford.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that's clear and very helpful. So that's an optimization and a science phase, then perhaps as you go forward, use of all that, you go for more once you through the Eagle for more completion efficiency improvement. Is that a logical thought process?
componenttext: So that's clear and very helpful. So that's an optimization and a science phase, then perhaps as you go forward, use of all that, you go for more once you through the Eagle for more completion efficiency improvement. Is that a logical thought process?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're always looking for more efficiency, Ed, into that. We continue to get among the most stage for fleet in South Texas out of each of those fleet but very carefully planning our logistics, both in the water and the prop inside of managing those. And in
componenttext: We're always looking for more efficiency, Ed, into that. We continue to get among the most stage for fleet in South Texas out of each of those fleet but very carefully planning our logistics, both in the water and the prop inside of managing those. And in the release, you saw we indicated we're going to drill about 20 more wells this year within the same capital in Upper Eagle Ford or really just going to use the balance of those wells to manage full activity to drive highest efficiency on the completion side, which we have the most cost exposure, so we want to make sure that site is very well supplied with inventory and so they stay at maximum efficiency.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Evan Calio.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: In your prepared comments, you talked about $2.8 billion to $3 billion annual CapEx run rate 2015 exit. I know you mentioned it's early, but clearly, the market is focused on 2016. Philosophically, how do you think about relative outspend into 2016 and ki
componenttext: In your prepared comments, you talked about $2.8 billion to $3 billion annual CapEx run rate 2015 exit. I know you mentioned it's early, but clearly, the market is focused on 2016. Philosophically, how do you think about relative outspend into 2016 and kind of balancing your attractive returning assets on the current environment, your financial flexibility in the dividend? Is there -- any comments there on an outspend range or how you're thinking about approaching 2016?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Evan, let me maybe talk a little bit about our CapEx use as we exit '15 and look ahead to '16 and then perhaps I'll let JR maybe talk a little bit on the cash flow outspend question. But as we kind of think about the current prices and look ahead to '16,
componenttext: Evan, let me maybe talk a little bit about our CapEx use as we exit '15 and look ahead to '16 and then perhaps I'll let JR maybe talk a little bit on the cash flow outspend question. But as we kind of think about the current prices and look ahead to '16, we would envision a certainly material lower budget than where we are below that $3.3 billion. And certainly, as you mentioned, our run rates coming out of this year are certainly a south of $3 billion. We're honestly though, Evan, right in the beginning of our budget process for 2016 and clearly, any actions that we take, our capital allocation is going to be low governed in large part by what we see in the commodity price environment. But in general, our strategic approach is going to be to prioritize our available capital to those highest return investments that we have in the North America resource play. And the balance will go to any previously committed kind of nondiscretionary longer cycle requirements. I would also expect in '16 that our exploration CapEx is further reduced. It was cut in half this year. And as you think about kind of even for a flat to reduced budget into '16, the North America component of that will still grow in that context because we have some long cycle investments running the course in 2015. We have further reductions, as I mentioned, in exploration standards, and we also have some nonrecurring U.S. infrastructure investments this year in 2015 that are going to provide some accommodations space, if you will, for additional North America investments. Again, our goal is going to be to target as much investment as we can at the U.S. resource play based on the prevailing commodity environment and available cash flows. We still have the inventory to deliver strong and long-term growth, and we're going to protect that optionality as we move into 2016. With that, maybe I'll just offer it over to J.R. just to talk a little bit about cash flow.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Evan, this is JR. And I think Lee really kind of think summarize it really well. It is early in the process, but the philosophically from my standpoint, he referred to the balance sheet strength is going to remain a priority. Again, philosophically, I wan
componenttext: Evan, this is JR. And I think Lee really kind of think summarize it really well. It is early in the process, but the philosophically from my standpoint, he referred to the balance sheet strength is going to remain a priority. Again, philosophically, I want to see 2016 be as close to free cash flow neutral, including asset sales as we possibly can. Many variables to that equation. Capital -- clearly, capital activity, capital efficiency, capital spend, operating cost efficiency and, of course, our success on the ongoing asset sales programs are all variables in dialing up and down that prospective capital profile. But I think your takeaway should be that we continue to have a great deal of flexibility to manage that and to really achieve all of what we want to achieve in terms of protecting that balance sheet, in terms -- if the commodity price environment is supportive of it, we continue to put those North American unconventionals back kind of growth track going forward. The one point you did bring up and I'll go ahead brought up the question with regard to the dividend, and as you might imagine in this environment, it's a question we frequently get. Evan, it's still a very important element to when you think about the total shareholder return for our shareholders. Even more so, in this environment. And it does -- it continues to be that first call of capital in our capital allocation process. The board is very thoughtful and very considered when they address this issue each and every quarter. They're making sure that it's still meeting our long-term capital allocation objective and they'll continue to fulfill the role of each and every quarter. But honestly, sitting here today, I feel very good. Good solid balance sheet, $5.5 billion of liquidity, $2.5 billion of that in cash and cash equivalents. And I think we've got a tremendous amount of flexibility to still continue to deliver that important element to our shareholders.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. Let me ask the second question and segue and kind of an area, which I presume would continue to get an increased allocation of capital in Oklahoma. You've added your smaller interest of Koch larger number of wells into the second ha
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. Let me ask the second question and segue and kind of an area, which I presume would continue to get an increased allocation of capital in Oklahoma. You've added your smaller interest of Koch larger number of wells into the second half of the year versus prior spending plans and what is it -- what appears to be a very attractive neighborhood. Could you discuss how far away you think you are from putting Oklahoma particularly STACK into full development mode? And can you talk about, I guess, that shift in the non-op and whether that's planning to leverage a fuller data set in helping you to and/or lease or subsequently develop that resource?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Evan, let me maybe start on that one as well. I think we are still in the very early days in the development in Oklahoma in both the STACK and the SCOOP. And as we've said in the past, we certainly believe with well over 1 billion barrels of 2P resou
componenttext: Yes. Evan, let me maybe start on that one as well. I think we are still in the very early days in the development in Oklahoma in both the STACK and the SCOOP. And as we've said in the past, we certainly believe with well over 1 billion barrels of 2P resource that this is a tremendously important growth engine for the company going forward because, again, of capital constraints in the current environment, we're running a 2-rig operated program there. That's designed to ensure that we protect our very valuable leasehold in both the SCOOP and the STACK. And as you mentioned, what we're doing is we're participating at a lower interest in a nonoperated part of our portfolio to really leverage our funds to continue to grow our data set in Oklahoma in a very cost-effective manner. In fact, in total, we've redeployed about $60 million into the Oklahoma nonoperated business. And of course, we gained the information in the data from that investment in addition to the barrels, which allows us to continue to move toward that vision of what a full field development will look like ultimately in the SCOOP and the STACK. But I just emphasize that we are early days, but we are making good progress already. You've seen some movement in our completed well costs downward in Oklahoma, reflecting some good efficiency, as well as commercial work by the teams. And I think as we move to scale, we move out of leasehold mode, we've given the pad drilling, those efficiencies are simply going to increase over time and we could see even more reduction in those costs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I'm trying to think of how to word this question, so it doesn't count as 2. On the dividend, Lee, I understand you've been very clear in the past about your commitment to why you think the dividend is important. But when you talk about cash breake
componenttext: I guess I'm trying to think of how to word this question, so it doesn't count as 2. On the dividend, Lee, I understand you've been very clear in the past about your commitment to why you think the dividend is important. But when you talk about cash breakeven, does that include covering the dividend? And I guess what I'm really trying to get at is when you look at who your peer group nowadays, folks are generally don't have that dividend commitments or obligation been able to redeploy once $600 million or $517 mil in your case towards what exhilarating something like the stock of the SCOOP. Why is it better volume for shareholders to see that dividend payout in this environment as opposed to moving it towards those high-graded assets and if you could qualify the breakeven place and I have a follow-up.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Doug. No worries. Just on the cash breakeven that J.R. was addressing in his earlier comments, we view that is inclusive of the dividend. When we think about cash flow neutrality, we're certainly willing to cover all of our obligations from ca
componenttext: Absolutely, Doug. No worries. Just on the cash breakeven that J.R. was addressing in his earlier comments, we view that is inclusive of the dividend. When we think about cash flow neutrality, we're certainly willing to cover all of our obligations from capital allocation standpoint and the dividend as one of those. Obviously, with our dividend yield, we're just today, that's a bit different looking at that it was in a different commodity price environment. But we still feel that this is an important way to deliver value to our shareholder. And we tend to look at the dividend and in the context of our overall capital allocation and in conjunction with the growth that we can generate organically within our very strong North America resource plays. So we'll be those 2 things as leading to be viewed collectively from an investment standpoint. And I think in this lower price environment, although you're correct and that is perhaps puts a bit more pressure on some of those peers, I do believe that is a key element of the return that we offer in this type of environment. And as J.R. very well put it, we are sitting with $5.5 billion in liquidity. We do not feel that we need to make any alteration in the weighted dividend competes for capital allocation today.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: My follow-up is really a similar kind of the question this time and declaration because clearly, your by definition is onshore resource pilot, which by definition is lower risk. I'm wondering if you could touch on the big of an expected exploration charge
componenttext: My follow-up is really a similar kind of the question this time and declaration because clearly, your by definition is onshore resource pilot, which by definition is lower risk. I'm wondering if you could touch on the big of an expected exploration charge in the current quarter and how you see exploration as a strategy fitting in the lower for longer oil price environment? There.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me maybe take the high-level question first, which is more around exploration strategy, how does that fit into our portfolio. As we've shared previously, Doug, we've been assessing our conventional exploration strategy and really in the context o
componenttext: Yes. Let me maybe take the high-level question first, which is more around exploration strategy, how does that fit into our portfolio. As we've shared previously, Doug, we've been assessing our conventional exploration strategy and really in the context of its ability to compete for capital allocation within the current portfolio, which does include, as you well stated, the North America inventory. And it must compete really on a risk-adjusted return basis. And we really started this assessment some time ago. It really wasn't crossed by that current macroenvironment. It was really prompted by the depths and quality of the inventory that we saw the North America resource play. So we're bit ahead of the curve. We've already taken the steps to reduce exploration essentially by half in 2015 and we certainly see a path that will allow us to moderate that further into 2016. I also mentioned in my opening comments that we recently withdrew from the new country entries that we simply sell it in the current environment, did not compete for capital allocation. So when you consider the current commodity price environment, when you consider the depth of our resource inventory North America and the limited capital to invest, it's just simply getting tougher and tougher for conventional exploration to compete for capital on a risk-adjusted basis. Back to your specific question on kind of the uptick in exploration expense, we did have a write-down in Birchwood, which is our in situ property in Canada, which contributed to that, Doug.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ryan Todd.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ryan Todd.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could maybe with my first question follow up a little bit on CapEx. You talk about -- you're showing in the presentation effect flatlining of production in the second half of 2015. Is it reasonable -- I know you can't give 2016 outlook, but is it rea
componenttext: If I could maybe with my first question follow up a little bit on CapEx. You talk about -- you're showing in the presentation effect flatlining of production in the second half of 2015. Is it reasonable -- I know you can't give 2016 outlook, but is it reasonable to think of that level of that $700 million to $750 million CapEx level as kind of a reasonable idea of maintenance capital -- CapEx and its ability to hold the production flat for longer? And you also mentioned the rollout of long cycle spend exploration reduction potential and nonrecurring infrastructure spend? Could maybe put some numbers around those that we could get maybe a bit of a better pro forma estimate for what the run rate on CapEx looks like into 2016?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, let me maybe start with addressing what I think is more a question around maintenance capital. And I think first and foremost, Ryan, of course, the $700 million, $750 million run rate includes the full portfolio. When we talk about the maintena
componenttext: Yes. Well, let me maybe start with addressing what I think is more a question around maintenance capital. And I think first and foremost, Ryan, of course, the $700 million, $750 million run rate includes the full portfolio. When we talk about the maintenance capital, we tend to focus in on the resource plays themselves in aggregate. And our best estimate of CapEx required to hold those resource plays flat is around $2 billion to $2.1 billion. Of course, as capital efficiencies and productivity activities kick in, there'll be actually downward pressure on that maintenance capital. And so when you think about looking ahead and how long could maintenance levels be sustained, my answer to that really would be that we have multiple years of high quality, high return resource play inventory that could sensibly drive a maintenance levels program even in a $50 barrel WTI environment. Again, you'll recall, as I mentioned in my opening comments, that they took a lot of in our most recent disclosure and 5-year drilling inventory, over 70% of our wells were profitable at $50-barrel per WTI. So you're right, we have had this rapid deceleration from first to second quarter in our overall capital program that $500 million that I quoted. We've now kind of settled in to I'd say a maintenance capital mode in the resource plays. But bear in mind, riding on top of that, are some of other investments that will be a little bit more lumpy and bumpy, including we may even see a little bit of an up in third quarter because of some nonrecurring infrastructure investments and a few other nonrecurring items in our international portfolio. But as you look through that lumpiness in the second half of the year, that $700 million, $750 million exit rate feels about right with some plus or minus there. Your other question was around how much of some of these longer cycle investments may run their course in 2015. And the items there that we talked about when we mentioned those things to make the work that we're doing is currently other EG compression project, which is now heavily in fabrication mode, the work that we did in the EG drilling program, the work that we did also in the U.K. drilling program, those are the types of items that we talked about. And so when we look kind of on a net-net basis as those kind of come off in 2016, there'll be some puts and takes, but you're probably in the couple of hundred million kind of dollar range in terms of the accommodation space that that might create within the budget.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And maybe if I could ask a follow-up in -- if we switch over to maybe resource in the Bakken. You've got some results out there of 180-day update in intensity completion, some pilot test results. Can you talk a little bit about maybe
componenttext: That's very helpful. And maybe if I could ask a follow-up in -- if we switch over to maybe resource in the Bakken. You've got some results out there of 180-day update in intensity completion, some pilot test results. Can you talk a little bit about maybe your thoughts on the results of the test on the pilot test for spacing and the implication for spacing going forward and whether the high intensity completion whether 180 days is long enough to maybe start impacted type curve or whether you're still waiting to see and eventually you are impact.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ryan. I think in general, I'd say we're really, really pleased with the progress broadly from the Bakken completion pilots. You should step back and look at what we've accomplished over the last several quarters, that material improvement in initial
componenttext: Sure, Ryan. I think in general, I'd say we're really, really pleased with the progress broadly from the Bakken completion pilots. You should step back and look at what we've accomplished over the last several quarters, that material improvement in initial production now with accumulative production level both wells reaching 180 days, you start to see that improvement hold up over time. We've consistently taken those new designs and application despite across our entire portfolio. I would add that even as we've demonstrated these results of our kind of rearview mirror looking, we're continuing to progress even more intensive simulations. I think we noted in the notes of that this group you're looking at has 40% more profit and about 10% more completion stages. We continue to see opportunity even beyond that for more intensity to drive those results further. I think based on the results you're seeing and referencing, there are certainly some pressure on us to look at overall EURs and talk about those perhaps later this year, perhaps some more color and context of that. And obviously with more EUR combined, with the Bakken well cost trending down to plus or minus $6 million in material reduction there, I think you can see the value implication of the portfolio of Bakken from that. So again, very pleased with it. And by all means, we expect that momentum to continue.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe if I could just add, too. On our last update on completed well kind of performance, our single well economics, we had reflected some of the early IP results that we were seeing from the Bakken completion trials, but we, as of yet, have not intro
componenttext: And maybe if I could just add, too. On our last update on completed well kind of performance, our single well economics, we had reflected some of the early IP results that we were seeing from the Bakken completion trials, but we, as of yet, have not introduced the full EUR benefits that potentially we can go under from those wells. So that's still yet to come.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Bryan Singer.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Bryan Singer.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the couple of diet and surrounding free cash flow and capital allocation priorities. You mentioned earlier the potential for free cash neutrality after asset sales. Wanted to just check whether that was before dividend or after di
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the couple of diet and surrounding free cash flow and capital allocation priorities. You mentioned earlier the potential for free cash neutrality after asset sales. Wanted to just check whether that was before dividend or after dividend. And then if that dividend is priority #1, just how you're thinking about the secondary priorities of growing production versus letting it decline, allowing leverage to increase or -- and I think you know the answer to the question when issuing equity.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is JR. I mean, those are all the variables that we're trying to balance to achieve the optimal outcome that we're trying to reach. In response to the question my comments with regard to trying to target as close to free cash flow neutrality as
componenttext: Brian, this is JR. I mean, those are all the variables that we're trying to balance to achieve the optimal outcome that we're trying to reach. In response to the question my comments with regard to trying to target as close to free cash flow neutrality as possible with dividend. I mean, at the end of the day, I think that's vitally important that we manage the business to where we're not overextending the balance sheet. That balance sheet strength is going to remain important. But if you and I talk about before I think, Brian, during this low commodity price environment, I'm definitely leaning on it and I want to lean on the balance sheet during this period. I just want to make sure I don't stress it too much. So we're not look forward and just an early forward view of 2016, we'll be in terms of the leaning on that balance sheet, we'll be, I'd say, impacted by the timing of ultimately our asset sales programs. There'll be periods in which we're leaning on it more than not. But that at the end of the day, I want to try and ensure that when we get through the year in 2016 that we still have a good solid balance sheet when we get to the end of the year.

componenttext: Yes, Brian, this is Mitch Little. I think just in terms of thinking about where Kurdistan fits, it's -- we've got 3 blocks there as I'm sure you know at different levels of maturity. The operated block at Harir, we've completed testing of our appraisal wells, the well results were largely in line with pre-drill expectations. And so at this point, we've demobilized the rig. We've substantially compute of our work commitments there. And we're integrating that data into the rest of the technical database and commercial assessment headed towards the commerciality decision on that block later this year. you're probably also familiar the Atrush Block Phase 1 development is progressing towards the 30,000 barrel a day gross facility. Should come online in 2016. And then our interest in the sourcing that is progressing towards approval of the field development plan, which will be a phase development ramp-up over time.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015

componenttext: Yes, Brian, I should have stepped an earlier answer that the farmers but on the reality is that I think we have generated an asset to the work that Mitch of the team have done -- had very solid subsurface expense success. I think the question we have to continue to ask ourselves is as we think about future investments in Kurdistan and whether or not they compete for capital for the rest of the portfolio and if the answer to that is no, we want to ensure that we can actually capture the value that's been generated by the team in order to redeploy that capital someplace else. So it's that trying to not be exquisite with regard to what particular assets so I don't put myself at a competitive disadvantage in the process. But you should expect that we're looking across the entire portfolio for Canada.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I think about the comparable at $50 oil, are you using a well level economic or is that asset level inclusive of all costs or how do you define that inventory and metrics for profitable at $50 oil?
componenttext: If I think about the comparable at $50 oil, are you using a well level economic or is that asset level inclusive of all costs or how do you define that inventory and metrics for profitable at $50 oil?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We tend to look at single well economics from an external standpoint, which allows us to benchmark, I think, more effectively with what others put out into the public domain, David. I think internally, though, we also want to look and see from a full
componenttext: Yes. We tend to look at single well economics from an external standpoint, which allows us to benchmark, I think, more effectively with what others put out into the public domain, David. I think internally, though, we also want to look and see from a fully burden level what is the return not only down the well level, but as a programm or even rig line in the particular area and a particular play. We want to make sure that we fully understand the fully burden economics of those wells. So there's an aspect of it, which is we want to be able to make sure that we can compare externally, but certainly, internally, we want to make absolutely sure we want to understand the total return from those investments.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015

componenttext: Yes. Just to be clear, what Lee's point is, is when you get there completed well costs, that truly is just completed well costs. But when you look at the returns that we share, those have been burdened by facilities, at least individual well facilities necessary for flow, not to the extent of broad central facilities, but individual well facilities.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. But the last disclosure that we offered up that when we kind of showed the economics of the relative economics of the various plays from a single well economic standpoint, it's clear that Eagle Ford in Oklahoma were at the most competitive portion of
componenttext: Yes. But the last disclosure that we offered up that when we kind of showed the economics of the relative economics of the various plays from a single well economic standpoint, it's clear that Eagle Ford in Oklahoma were at the most competitive portion of that plot. The higher quality in the Bakken was also in that same ZIP code, and that's really is what drove our capital allocation as we came into 2015. I think what you've heard is that the Eagle Ford, as well as Oklahoma, have continued to also improve from a single well economic standpoint from cost and productivity standpoint, but also the Bakken has continued to improve its competitiveness as well. And will hopefully be able to share a little bit more color on that a bit later in the year as we're able to roll in some of the specific updates on EURs and single well economics. But I think that order in terms of capital allocation is exactly what you see in our current portfolio, which is the Eagle Ford wells, particularly condensate and highly to a certain extent, are still very strong from a return standpoint. Both the SCOOP and the STACK still compete very favorably as well. And then in higher quality areas of Bakken such as the Myrmidon, they're also competing for capital allocation.

componenttext: David, I just think what you assume is what we talked about greater than $500 million haven't been really explicit on timing. I thought give it 12 months from when we announced it again. But we wouldn't have put a target out there if we didn't have some degree of confidence, but you should expect that program to continue not necessarily stop if we cross the $500 million level.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have quick ones. When you look at your portfolio, Lee, I want to get back to the short cycle, long cycle type activity. What do you think is kind of an idea balance and if you have more of an emphasis in short cycle, is it time to revisit hedging?
componenttext: I have quick ones. When you look at your portfolio, Lee, I want to get back to the short cycle, long cycle type activity. What do you think is kind of an idea balance and if you have more of an emphasis in short cycle, is it time to revisit hedging?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me -- I'll maybe that jump in the hedging question. Versus sort cycle. Right now, the bulk of our investment dollars were flowing into North America short cycle, then the driver there is they have the highest risk-adjusted returns in the portfoli
componenttext: Yes. Let me -- I'll maybe that jump in the hedging question. Versus sort cycle. Right now, the bulk of our investment dollars were flowing into North America short cycle, then the driver there is they have the highest risk-adjusted returns in the portfolio that we have today. So for us, it's probably a little bit less about short cycle, long cycle than it is about where can we generate a highest risk-adjusted return. And to the extent that they continue to see long cycle or longer cycle opportunities, great example are the things that we done in Equatorial Guinea and the U.K. this year in terms of the program drilling that we've done there that are very strong from a capital allocation standpoint and have added very profitable barrels to the portfolio. So in no way are we necessarily turning our back on longer cycle type investments, but the balance is going to be dictated by the opportunities that we have in the portfolio and being driven by generating those highest risk-adjusted return. From a hedging standpoint, certainly, we view that as just an element of overall commodity risk management. And maybe I'll let JR comment on that.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, you talked before. It's definitely a tool that we need to be using. We are using. we've been far more active and I think Marathon has been in the past. What I'd like to have had more hedges on today, yes, but we have probably at least for the balanc
componenttext: John, you talked before. It's definitely a tool that we need to be using. We are using. we've been far more active and I think Marathon has been in the past. What I'd like to have had more hedges on today, yes, but we have probably at least for the balance of '15 and I know the markets more concerned about '16, we probably get about 35,000 barrels a day hedged for the balance of '15 and we really just were able to begin to establish a position in '16 before the market kind of fell on us. But it is steadily going to be a tool we're going to continue to use.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other one for me. In Eagle Ford, you had incredible drilling efficiency. Are you changing cruise? Are you getting different rigs? How can you have this level of improvement in your well design or execution?
componenttext: One other one for me. In Eagle Ford, you had incredible drilling efficiency. Are you changing cruise? Are you getting different rigs? How can you have this level of improvement in your well design or execution?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I think what you're seeing is just a recognition by a team who refuses to accept it. They've done their best work already. They continue to see in the future they can be innovative and thoughtful. In this case, part of the change is that we've -- as
componenttext: John, I think what you're seeing is just a recognition by a team who refuses to accept it. They've done their best work already. They continue to see in the future they can be innovative and thoughtful. In this case, part of the change is that we've -- as we have moderated activity, we've certainly kept the best rates of the best cruise because helps both our operational efficiencies, as well as our environmental safety performance. We've retained with a higher specification, so the right types of capability that we moved to in that gratefully that would really drive it and those unique attributes of those rigs allow us to use other types of downhole tools. The combination of those technologies together has really delivered this performance. And I would say, well, 1,800 feet per day was materially better in the year ago quarter. Our best rigs are at 2,600, 2,700 feet per day already, which shows you the gap, right, that we can get the whole fleet to there. There's still room to improve that overall. We see that as sustainable. And in fact, as we move to the stack-and-frac pilots and the codevelopment of multiple horizons, we actually thing that enables that type of efficiency further and will want to drill more wells in each as we go to development.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, John, too, it's probably important to note that when we look at the true pace setter drilling performance in the Eagle Ford, where we had one of our best rigs deliver 3,100 feet per day, it's just gives you a feel for just how much more room we h
componenttext: I think, John, too, it's probably important to note that when we look at the true pace setter drilling performance in the Eagle Ford, where we had one of our best rigs deliver 3,100 feet per day, it's just gives you a feel for just how much more room we have to drive for if we're averaging 1,800 feet for the quarter. So it does show that there is continuing efficiency gains that we can be made. Now when we get that immediately across the whole fleet, no. But it does set that marker out there of what can be achieved with the best cruise, the bestequipment being brought to bear.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Scott Hanold.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Scott Hanold.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could step back again kind of focus on big picture, where Marathon's going at this point in time be somewhat agnostic to current low commodity prices. with the resource potential that you're building in some of the North American resource plays, is t
componenttext: If I could step back again kind of focus on big picture, where Marathon's going at this point in time be somewhat agnostic to current low commodity prices. with the resource potential that you're building in some of the North American resource plays, is there transformation occurring where Marathon is going to become more focused on these lower risks potentially higher returning short cycle opportunities? And again, being somewhat diagnostic to low prices right now.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. That transformation is underway, has been underway. I think as we have made this very decided pivot to North America resource plays for clearer economic reasons, you're seeing that. And where our investment dollars are flowing and you're right
componenttext: Yes, Scott. That transformation is underway, has been underway. I think as we have made this very decided pivot to North America resource plays for clearer economic reasons, you're seeing that. And where our investment dollars are flowing and you're right. We have this incredible 3 billion barrels of 2P resource inventory and the 3 core U.S. resource plays that affords us a tremendous amount of future opportunity and our challenge is assuring that we get the appropriate investment levels driven to those 3 core plays and bring those up to scale development. I mean, we're really at scale in the Eagle Ford. Certainly, we've been in Bakken and skill for some time as well. But Oklahoma is still an area where we would like to see more capital invested and not just the nonoperating, but also the operated program. And certainly, as we think about that incremental amount of capital coming available to invest, we absolutely see that flowing to places like the Eagle Ford and Oklahoma.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up and I don't know if you all in this industry for quite some time in the over or some of your past. With the low price environment we are right now, can you discuss from an industry consolidation perspective your view on what could occur
componenttext: And as a follow-up and I don't know if you all in this industry for quite some time in the over or some of your past. With the low price environment we are right now, can you discuss from an industry consolidation perspective your view on what could occur and how Marathon fits into that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, it's always tough to speculate, I think, for -- on the M&A space. I think right now, with the the dynamics that we're seeing in the marketplace, it's a very challenging, I think, to see a lot of deal activity. And in fact, that's really what's
componenttext: Yes. Well, it's always tough to speculate, I think, for -- on the M&A space. I think right now, with the the dynamics that we're seeing in the marketplace, it's a very challenging, I think, to see a lot of deal activity. And in fact, that's really what's played out. There's been a few one-off opportunities that will probably taken -- the decisions they have been taken in a slightly different environment than we find ourselves today. But with equities very depressed, I think with everyone kind of reacting to another dramatic downtick in pricing, it's hard to imagine there's going to be a lot of that type of activity, at least in the near term. Now, as you look further ahead and we see a more persistent kind of lower for longer price environment, then I think the concept that there will be additional consolidation, additional opportunities come available to those that are prepared to take advantage of those, then absolutely, I would agree with that.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Guy Baber.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Guy Baber.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: You know that better than David did in the last thing that's right, I have been called the numerous times. I was hoping to clarify a few comments. Images made earlier in the Q&A, Lee. But you mentioned in this price environment, capital spending would be
componenttext: You know that better than David did in the last thing that's right, I have been called the numerous times. I was hoping to clarify a few comments. Images made earlier in the Q&A, Lee. But you mentioned in this price environment, capital spending would be down from the current year. You also said that even with a flat to lower budget in 2016 that the North American production component would grow. So could you just elaborate on that comment a bit? Want to make sure that we have that right. And really, just trying to understand that assertion and square that with our understanding that the unconventional production would exit this year below the full year average. And then on maintenance CapEx levels, you could hold that 4Q exit rates flat through '16. So just want to make sure we understand that trajectory in some of the moving parts that we might be missing.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, no. Absolutely. I tried to address -- again, honestly, we're not -- we're very early in the planning cycle for 2016. But just thinking about it conceptually, we know that our capital budget will be less than where we stand in 2015. In fact, the run r
componenttext: Yes, no. Absolutely. I tried to address -- again, honestly, we're not -- we're very early in the planning cycle for 2016. But just thinking about it conceptually, we know that our capital budget will be less than where we stand in 2015. In fact, the run rate that you mentioned as we exit 2015 kind of that 29-ish kind of run rate certainly less than the 3 billion barrel -- $3 billion, that really does entail an ability to direct more capital deployment to the North America resource plays. So for a bit smaller part, we're able today dedicate a much larger slice to the North America resource plays even in that scenario. And so the ability to have that optionality to move for more of a maintenance capital mode in the resource plays to more of a growth mode, we still have that optionality within a reduced budget in 2016. Did that get clarify, Guy?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Phillip Jungwirth.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Phillip Jungwirth.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the Eagle Ford, you noted the 40% sequential decline in activity as the reason for lower production. Looking at the expected wells to sales of the second half, it looks like the quarterly average is going to be a little bit lower than what you had in 2
componenttext: On the Eagle Ford, you noted the 40% sequential decline in activity as the reason for lower production. Looking at the expected wells to sales of the second half, it looks like the quarterly average is going to be a little bit lower than what you had in 2Q. So is the current activity run rate below maintenance CapEx or this as a volume still be held flat on better well productivity in the second half or a shallower decline given that you probably a lot of flush production coming into the year?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Phil, I think you're seeing that actually burial. Compared to the previous several quarters where we had in excess of 90 wells per sale, in the second quarter, we have 52 wells per sale, which is driving that production in Eagle Ford downward. Really
componenttext: Yes, Phil, I think you're seeing that actually burial. Compared to the previous several quarters where we had in excess of 90 wells per sale, in the second quarter, we have 52 wells per sale, which is driving that production in Eagle Ford downward. Really, the wave of those higher productivity wells that are very early in their life coming down is kind of overwhelmed the number of new wells to sales. I think from a perspective of activity across North America, including Eagle Ford has come down to about 45% for us. What you really see we're managing that downward to a point of stability. We will have roughly the same number of wells, plus or minus in the third and fourth quarter in Eagle Ford, specifically. And any given quarter, our interest move within that so that number grows also that wells can move a bit. So I think in general, we're guiding to what relatively flat production quarter-over-quarter and we're managing that large activity downward in the quarter. I would say, too, some context of that is even as we said that was to sales were lower Eagle Ford, I think it's important to note we went from 5 frac fleets to 2 by April. So we were down that lowest level of wells to sales driven activity by very early in the second quarter, which kind of added to that deceleration impact.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And can you discuss the results from the 1O stage well brought on during the quarter. I think Marathon might be the first to drill in that zone. Based on what you know today, why would you also compare that emerging place to both the Meramec
componenttext: Okay, great. And can you discuss the results from the 1O stage well brought on during the quarter. I think Marathon might be the first to drill in that zone. Based on what you know today, why would you also compare that emerging place to both the Meramec and Woodford?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Phil. Last year, we started an exploration program in STACK focused on the Meramec and the Osage. That Osage well was the last well of the initial group are sort of our initial foray into the in an operated basis. I think you may recall in the secon
componenttext: Sure, Phil. Last year, we started an exploration program in STACK focused on the Meramec and the Osage. That Osage well was the last well of the initial group are sort of our initial foray into the in an operated basis. I think you may recall in the second half of last year, we actually increased activity in Oklahoma up to 6 rigs. And that well was drilled effectively starting right after Christmas and sort of the last well in that program. We've evaluated for the results from all of those. We continue to see the Meramec as the most valuable is on that area in general. I don't see Osage activity anytime in the near term.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: You're talking about selling some assets in an extremely depressed environment where there are plenty of distress sellers that are in far worse shape than you are. Isn't it kind of leaving money on the table if you're monetizing just about anything right
componenttext: You're talking about selling some assets in an extremely depressed environment where there are plenty of distress sellers that are in far worse shape than you are. Isn't it kind of leaving money on the table if you're monetizing just about anything right now?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, I don't view our number as a seeing distressed. So the reason I said it probably is that when you think about the type of assets that we will put in the market, we believe that there's still a very strong competitive environment for tho
componenttext: Yes, first of all, I don't view our number as a seeing distressed. So the reason I said it probably is that when you think about the type of assets that we will put in the market, we believe that there's still a very strong competitive environment for those assets. And I'll use the East Texas, North Louisiana, Wilberton as an example. We had a very strong response to the data room. We had well over 20 proposals for the property. When you look at the deal metrics, they were very compelling on a cash flow multiple basis, over 9x. And so we feel like for the right type of assets, there is still a ready market out there. And I would not want to leave the impression that we're selling anything at reduced value or low value to our shareholders. I mean, we did don't view this as distressed asset. We simply view them as part of our ongoing portfolio management and if we can capture fair value, then we'll continue to operate. In the case of the East Texas, North Louisiana, Wilberton deal, and less gassy asset. It was no longer competing for capital allocation, relatively high unit cash cost. We had a strong competitive environment for it. And the deal metrics were very competitive in this pricing environment our others. So I think we feel very good about our ability to continue to transact at fair values.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just to clarify, it's not your assets I was calling distressed. Plenty of other than the market that are in that state. Now my follow-up is you talk about flexing the balance sheet into 2016. That cap is currently at 29%. How high would yo
componenttext: Understood. And just to clarify, it's not your assets I was calling distressed. Plenty of other than the market that are in that state. Now my follow-up is you talk about flexing the balance sheet into 2016. That cap is currently at 29%. How high would you be comfortable letting that metric go up?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. What I would tell you is I've always tried to be careful to draw hard and fast rules. But when I think of looking period 2015, when I take into consideration all my -- I'm sorry, 2016, when they take into consideration what I said before a lot of var
componenttext: Yes. What I would tell you is I've always tried to be careful to draw hard and fast rules. But when I think of looking period 2015, when I take into consideration all my -- I'm sorry, 2016, when they take into consideration what I said before a lot of variables around capital, operating cost structure, asset sales programs, I still want to ultimately manage the balance sheet through '16 to let's call it as close to 2.5x net debt-to-EBITDA as I can in this low commodity price environment. Now that's going -- it's going to be lumpy rate. It's going to be dependent upon the timing of various asset sales. And so that will become a bit higher than that, but that's ultimately one of the variables I'm trying to manage to. And as commodity prices then begin to stabilize, whether that's early '17 or you decide win, that ultimately will see that leverage get back to its more traditional levels of 2x and below.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015

componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question regards the Oklahoma resource plays, the increased non-op participation. Just wondering are the choices driven by any specific operator performance or is it driven by more geography?
componenttext: My first question regards the Oklahoma resource plays, the increased non-op participation. Just wondering are the choices driven by any specific operator performance or is it driven by more geography?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeffrey, I think overall, we're focused on value. We have a substantial core acreage position in both the SCOOP and in the STACK. When we see activity that core high-value acreage, where we've seen great historical results and for recent data, we expect t
componenttext: Jeffrey, I think overall, we're focused on value. We have a substantial core acreage position in both the SCOOP and in the STACK. When we see activity that core high-value acreage, where we've seen great historical results and for recent data, we expect those results to be greater than other areas, we're chosen to participate in those well to capture the data and leverage our both the collection of that data and integration of it to drive toward development. And to some extent, if you didn't participate in those valuable acreage, it's an opportunity loss. We certainly want to capture all those opportunities. So it's not really driven by an operator. It's driven by our perceived value of the acreage and the opportunity. I'd say within the context of that, we see more, I'd say, more execution-friendly operators and others. And as you can imagine, based on that, we make economic decisions based on how we feel they can execute.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And my other question was on Slide 17 regarding the Bakken spacing pilots to this point. The ranges appear less prolific in some of the non-spacing data that's provided yet. A large production uplift was identified out to 180 days. S
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And my other question was on Slide 17 regarding the Bakken spacing pilots to this point. The ranges appear less prolific in some of the non-spacing data that's provided yet. A large production uplift was identified out to 180 days. So I'm wondering if you can help me to understand how to interpret the date that's being presented and as well, if you could indicate how you feel the pilots are performing relative to your expectations at this point.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. With 3 spacing pilots, I feel like we've made a lot of progress at moving forward on an operated basis and kind of start work south to north, if you will. Those are -- spacing pilots are in 3 different areas, starting the south, it's Middle Bakken,
componenttext: Sure. With 3 spacing pilots, I feel like we've made a lot of progress at moving forward on an operated basis and kind of start work south to north, if you will. Those are -- spacing pilots are in 3 different areas, starting the south, it's Middle Bakken, so it's in a 6-well per Middle Bakken pattern overall. There is a wide range of result, and I think in the case of that pilot in the when you look at the aggregate, all of the wells on there, you'll see some of them type curve, you see some a little below. But when you put them together, they did make their performing very in line with our early expectations for that despite being a closer spacing in the stand-alone wells. So that gives us a lot of encouragement. We expected some differentiation. In some cases, what we'll find is when we go in and there's more than 1 parent well or older well in the area, you'll see some impact in the new well that's near that older well will be impacted modestly by that. But in aggregate, we tend to look at the entire unit, how many wells, how many total dollar invested, what's the total production coming out of that. And so that Ajax pilot, for example, is performing very much in line with those expectations. Moving further north to Hector in that pilot, again, we see a diversity of results. But in aggregate, they're performing very similarly to our expectations for the early production. Some of the wells in other groups are more mature than others, so several of those are at 90 or 120 days and they're continuing to perform well. So we're very pleased with that result overall. And these pilots -- some of the wells vintage wise had more aggressive simulations than others based on when they were drilled and completed. And then lastly, in Myrmidon, we see a wide range there, too. I think in the case of that 1 pilot, we intentionally looked at that pilot and said there are 4 older parent wells between those 2 sections or units that were developed together. And so the wells near -- those new wells near the parent wells are showing lesser production than the wells that are further outlined. And that's not unexpected. In our case, we want to test that as we have parent well we need to work around. And I think in general, we're still very pleased with the overall production and continue to see that as a validation of our spacing assumptions moving forward.

Just to clarify, do these spacing pilots have any cost advantages over a more difficult production patterns? Just purely about trying to capture the maximum resource?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015

componenttext: For anytime we have the opportunity to pad develop groups of wells, we have a great opportunity on the drilling efficiency side to capture those cost savings similar in the completion soft where we can leave frac fleet on 1 pad side and drill -- excuse me, complete multiple wells. On both of those fronts, we gained tremendous efficiency. And then lastly, on the surface facility, the ability to share those surface facilities also create a scale efficiency. So we constantly seek and desire the opportunity for pad development because it really does positively influence our capital.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, CEO and President; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; M
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, CEO and President; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Mitch Little, Vice President, International and Offshore Exploration and Production Operations; Lance Robertson, Vice President, North America Production Operations; and Zach Dailey, Director of Investor Relations.  
As has become our custom, we released prepared remarks last night in conjunction with the earnings release. You can find those remarks and the associated slides at marathonoil.com.  
As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. And our comments and answers to questions will contain forward-looking information subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. I refer you back to the aforementioned slides, where you can find our full safe harbor statement.  
With that, I will turn the call over to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, thanks, Chris. Let me add my good morning. I'd like to open with just a few comments regarding the elements of our business that we control, cost, efficiencies and execution, and discuss how our actions will enhance returns and have us po
componenttext:
All right. Well, thanks, Chris. Let me add my good morning. I'd like to open with just a few comments regarding the elements of our business that we control, cost, efficiencies and execution, and discuss how our actions will enhance returns and have us positioned for the current environment as well as when commodity prices show a sustained improvement. 
We find ourselves in a continued low and volatile pricing environment. We have taken a decisive action consistent with our business plan released in first quarter, activity and CapEx reductions, capital efficiency and productivity gains, operating and G&A cost reductions and noncore asset divestments. We have successfully and efficiently achieved our planned activity reductions in the 3 resource plays to yield a program that will hold production volumes for the balance of 2015 while still progressing our strategic objectives in all 3 plays. 
Those objectives are co-development in the Eagle Ford, integration of completion and downspacing pilots in the Bakken and protecting our valuable leasehold in both our SCOOP and STACK positions while investing in high-return, outside-operated opportunities. Even with these planned reductions, we will still deliver on our growth targets of 5% to 7% for the overall company and 20% for the resource plays year-over-year. We've also raised the low end of our total company E&P full year production guidance, essentially increasing the midpoint despite that announced asset sale. 
Our planned deceleration in capital spend is evident in the sequential reduction in our capital program by almost $500 million and the significant decrease in wells to sales relative to the first quarter. We had already cut exploration spend by half from last year and are continuing to moderate forward commitments as we reset our strategy, including withdrawal from new country entries that do not compete for capital allocation. 
For capital efficiency, we have captured greater than $300 million in D&C savings in the U.S. resource plays or about 20% and are driving for more. Our completed well costs continue to fall, and our well productivity continues to improve. We have reduced unit operating cost in both of our E&P segments from the year-ago quarter, more than 30% in North America and 25% in international ex Libya, and have reflected this in our forward full year guidance for unit costs, lowering them $1.25 and $1 per BOE, respectively. We were quick to address G&A costs in the first quarter as we finalized our activity plans and implemented a workforce reduction of about 400 people that is expected to generate annualized net savings of approximately $100 million. 
Our noncore asset sales are progressing with signed agreements for approximately $100 million toward our target of over $500 million. This recent transaction confirm that the right assets will generate a competitive process and yield compelling deal metrics even in the current environment. All of these actions combine to give us confidence in driving toward cash flow neutrality in 2016 inclusive of noncore asset sales. 
We are only just beginning the budget process for 2016, but we'll focus capital allocation to the high-return U.S. resource plays as several longer-cycle investments run their course by the end of this year and exploration spend continues to decline. Our forward-look positions us well below our 2015 $3.3 billion capital program. And while our 2015 quarterly exit rate will be in the range of $700 million and $750 million, we still have the ability to flex down or up as required. Additionally, we expect expense reductions and capital efficiency to continue into 2016. 
We are optimizing our business around a lower cost structure, holding production levels and protecting our investment in our high-return U.S. resource plays while challenging all other spend in excess of that. Our U.S. resource plays continue to deliver solid returns at current pricing with capital efficiency and enhanced productivity lowering breakeven prices. Our last disclosure on our 5-year drilling inventory showed 70% of our inventory profitable at $50 a barrel WTI, and that analysis did not incorporate our most recent completed well cost savings and productivity enhancements. We have multiple years of high-quality inventory that can deliver competitive returns in the current environment. 
We do not believe this is a time to be accelerating inventory and associated production from short-cycle investments. We believe it's a time for discipline, continuous cost reduction, sustainable efficiency, maximizing returns and balance sheet protection. We continue to have a strong balance sheet with $5.5 billion in liquidity at quarter end. As we move into the second half of 2015, we look forward to providing more results from our co-development in the Eagle Ford, operated downspacing activity in Oklahoma and resource updates for the U.S. unconventional plays. 
I want to conclude by taking a moment to recognize our Marathon Oil employees who have been the driving force behind our results in this very dynamic environment. They have stepped forward to lead our efforts in cost reduction and efficiency gains and have kept their focus on execution despite the distraction of the macro environment. Our employees are committed to an enterprise-first view, for which I'm both thankful and proud. 
With that, I'll hand it back to Chris to begin the Q&A.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
