componenttextpreview: Correct. Artificial lift, et cetera.
componenttext: Correct. Artificial lift, et cetera.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Basically, the life cycle cost of the well ex any main, centralized facilities, David.
componenttext: Yes. Basically, the life cycle cost of the well ex any main, centralized facilities, David.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is there any particular area where the other 30% falls? I mean, is it Williston, STACK, Eagle Ford, in that order? It's probably what I would do, but...
componenttext: Is there any particular area where the other 30% falls? I mean, is it Williston, STACK, Eagle Ford, in that order? It's probably what I would do, but...

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the last disclosure that we offered that when we kind of showed the economics of -- the relative economics of the various plays from a single-well economic standpoint. It's clear that Eagle Ford and Oklahoma were at the most competitive portion
componenttext: Yes. Well, the last disclosure that we offered that when we kind of showed the economics of -- the relative economics of the various plays from a single-well economic standpoint. It's clear that Eagle Ford and Oklahoma were at the most competitive portion of that plot. The higher quality in the Bakken was also in that same zip code, and that really is what drove our capital allocation as we came into 2015. I think what you've heard is that the Eagle Ford as well as Oklahoma have continued to also improve from a single-well economic standpoint, from a cost and productivity standpoint. But also the Bakken has continued to improve its competitiveness as well. And we'll hopefully be able to share a little bit more color on that a bit later in the year as we're able to roll in some of the specific updates on EURs and single-well economics. But I think that order in terms of capital allocation is exactly what you see in our current portfolio, which is the Eagle Ford wells, particularly condensate and high-GOR wells, to a certain extent, are still very strong from a return standpoint. Both the SCOOP and the STACK still compete very favorably as well. And then in the higher-quality area of the Bakken, such as the Myrmidon, they're also competing for capital allocation.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then asset sales around $500 million next year as well is a reasonable assumption?
componenttext: And then asset sales around $500 million next year as well is a reasonable assumption?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, David, I just think what you ought to assume is what we've talked about is greater than $500 million. We haven't been real explicit on timing. I thought give it 12 months from when we announced it, again. But we wouldn't have put a target out t
componenttext: Yes. Well, David, I just think what you ought to assume is what we've talked about is greater than $500 million. We haven't been real explicit on timing. I thought give it 12 months from when we announced it, again. But we wouldn't have put a target out there if we didn't have some degree of confidence, but you should expect that program to continue and not necessarily stop if we cross the $500 million level.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from John Herrlin.
componenttext: And our next question comes from John Herrlin.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just have some quick ones. When you look at your portfolio, Lee, I want to get back to the short-cycle, long-cycle type activity. What do you think is kind of an ideal balance? And if you have more of an emphasis on short cycle, is it time to revisit he
componenttext: I just have some quick ones. When you look at your portfolio, Lee, I want to get back to the short-cycle, long-cycle type activity. What do you think is kind of an ideal balance? And if you have more of an emphasis on short cycle, is it time to revisit hedging?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, yes, let me -- I'll maybe let J.R. jump in on the hedging question. But let me first kind of talk about long cycle versus short cycle. Right now, the bulk of our investment dollars are flowing into North America short cycle. Then the driver the
componenttext: Yes. Well, yes, let me -- I'll maybe let J.R. jump in on the hedging question. But let me first kind of talk about long cycle versus short cycle. Right now, the bulk of our investment dollars are flowing into North America short cycle. Then the driver there is they have the highest risk-adjusted returns in the portfolio that we have today. So for us, it's probably a little bit less about short cycle/long cycle than it is about where can we generate the highest risk-adjusted return. And to the extent that we continue to see long cycle -- or longer-cycle opportunities -- and great examples are the things that we've done in Equatorial Guinea and the U.K. this year in terms of the program drilling that we've done there that are very strong from a capital allocation standpoint and have added very profitable barrels to the portfolio. So in no way are we necessarily turning our back on longer-cycle type investments, but the balance is going to be dictated by the opportunities that we have in the portfolio and being driven by generating those highest risk-adjusted return. From a hedging standpoint, certainly, we view that as just an element of overall commodity risk management. And maybe I'll let J.R. comment on that.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, you and I have talked before. It's definitely a tool that we need to be using, we are using. We've been far more active than, I think, Marathon has been in the past. Would I like to have more hedges on today? Yes, but we have probably at least for t
componenttext: John, you and I have talked before. It's definitely a tool that we need to be using, we are using. We've been far more active than, I think, Marathon has been in the past. Would I like to have more hedges on today? Yes, but we have probably at least for the balance of '15 -- and I know the market is more concerned about '16. We probably have about 35,000 barrels a day hedged for the balance of '15, and we really just were able to begin to establish a position in '16 before the market kind of fell on us. But it is definitely going to be a tool we're going to continue to use.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. One other one for me. In the Eagle Ford, you have incredible drilling efficiency. Are you changing crews? Are you getting different rigs? How can you have this level of improvement in your well design or execution?
componenttext: Okay, great. One other one for me. In the Eagle Ford, you have incredible drilling efficiency. Are you changing crews? Are you getting different rigs? How can you have this level of improvement in your well design or execution?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I think what you're seeing is just a recognition by a team who refuse to accept that they've done their best work already. They continue to see in the future they can be innovative and thoughtful. In this case, part of the change is that we've -- as
componenttext: John, I think what you're seeing is just a recognition by a team who refuse to accept that they've done their best work already. They continue to see in the future they can be innovative and thoughtful. In this case, part of the change is that we've -- as we have moderated activity, we've certainly kept the best rigs and the best crews because it helps both our operational efficiency as well as our environmental safety performance. We've retained rigs with the highest specification, so the right types of capabilities that we move to in that rig fleet that can really drive it. And those unique attributes of those rigs allow us to use other types of downhole tools. The combination of those technologies together has really delivered this performance. And I would say, while 1,800 feet per day was materially better than the year-ago quarter. Our best rigs are at 2,600, 2,700 feet per day already, which shows you the gap, right, that if we can get the whole fleet to there there's still room to improve that overall. We see that as sustainable. And in fact, as we move to stack and frac pilots in the co-development of multiple horizons, we actually think that enables that type of efficiency further because we're going to drill more wells on each pad as we go to development.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, John, too, it's probably important to note that when we look at the true pacesetter drilling performance in the Eagle Ford, where we had one of our best rigs deliver 3,100 feet per day, it just gives you a feel for just how much more room we have
componenttext: I think, John, too, it's probably important to note that when we look at the true pacesetter drilling performance in the Eagle Ford, where we had one of our best rigs deliver 3,100 feet per day, it just gives you a feel for just how much more room we have to drive toward if we're averaging 1,800 feet for the quarter. So it does show that there is continuing efficiency gains that we -- that can be made. Now will we get that immediately across the whole fleet? No, but it does set that marker out there of what can be achieved with the best crews, the best equipment being brought to bear.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Scott Hanold.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Scott Hanold.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could step back and again kind of focus on big picture, where Marathon is going at this point in time, being somewhat agnostic to current low commodity prices. With the resource potential that you all are building in some of the North American resour
componenttext: If I could step back and again kind of focus on big picture, where Marathon is going at this point in time, being somewhat agnostic to current low commodity prices. With the resource potential that you all are building in some of the North American resource plays, is there a transformation occurring where Marathon is going to become more focused on these lower-risk and potentially higher-returning, short-cycle opportunities and again, being somewhat agnostic to low prices right now?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, absolutely, Scott. I mean, that transformation is underway, has been underway. I think as we have made this very decided pivot to North America resource plays for clear economic reasons, you're seeing that in where our investment dollars are fl
componenttext: Yes. Well, absolutely, Scott. I mean, that transformation is underway, has been underway. I think as we have made this very decided pivot to North America resource plays for clear economic reasons, you're seeing that in where our investment dollars are flowing. And you're right, we have this incredible 3 billion barrels of 2P resource inventory in the 3 core U.S. resource plays that affords us a tremendous amount of future opportunity, and our challenge is ensuring that we get the appropriate investment levels driven to those 3 core plays and bring those up to scale development. I mean we're really at scale in the Eagle Ford. Certainly, we've been in Bakken at scale for some time as well. But Oklahoma is still an area where we would like to see more capital invested and not just the nonoperated but also the operated program. And certainly, as we think about that incremental amount of capital coming available to invest, we absolutely see that flowing to places like the Eagle Ford and Oklahoma.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And as a follow-up -- and I know both of you all have been in this industry for quite some time, and J.R., you obviously experienced it in some of your past firms. With the low price environment we are in right now, can you discuss, from an in
componenttext: Okay, good. And as a follow-up -- and I know both of you all have been in this industry for quite some time, and J.R., you obviously experienced it in some of your past firms. With the low price environment we are in right now, can you discuss, from an industry consolidation perspective, your view on what could occur and how Marathon fits into that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, it's always tough to speculate, I think, for -- on the M&A space. I think right now, with the dynamics that we're seeing in the marketplace, it's very challenging, I think, to see a lot of deal activity. And in fact, that's really what's played
componenttext: Yes. Well, it's always tough to speculate, I think, for -- on the M&A space. I think right now, with the dynamics that we're seeing in the marketplace, it's very challenging, I think, to see a lot of deal activity. And in fact, that's really what's played out. There's been a few one-off opportunities that were probably taken -- the decisions may have been taken in a slightly different environment than we find ourselves today. But with equities very depressed, I think with everyone kind of reacting to another dramatic downtick in pricing, it's hard to imagine there's going to be a lot of that type of activity, at least in the near term. Now as you look further ahead and we see a more persistent kind of lower-for-longer price environment, then I think the concept that there will be additional consolidation, additional opportunities come available to those that are prepared to take advantage of those, then absolutely, I would agree with that.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Guy Baber.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Guy Baber.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to clarify a few comments you just made earlier in the Q&A, Lee. You mentioned that in this price environment, capital spending would be down from the current year. You also said that even with a flat to lower budget in 2016, that the North A
componenttext: I was hoping to clarify a few comments you just made earlier in the Q&A, Lee. You mentioned that in this price environment, capital spending would be down from the current year. You also said that even with a flat to lower budget in 2016, that the North American production component would grow. So could you just elaborate on that comment a bit? I wanted to make sure that we have that right. And really, just trying to understand that assertion and square that with our understanding that the unconventional production would exit this year below the full year average, and then on maintenance CapEx levels, you could hold that 4Q exit rate flat through '16. So just want to make sure we understand that trajectory and some of the moving parts that we might be missing.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, absolutely. I tried to address -- again, honestly, we're not -- we're very early in the planning cycle for 2016. But just thinking about it conceptually, we know that our capital budget will be less than where we stand in 2015. In fact, the run r
componenttext: Yes. No, absolutely. I tried to address -- again, honestly, we're not -- we're very early in the planning cycle for 2016. But just thinking about it conceptually, we know that our capital budget will be less than where we stand in 2015. In fact, the run rate that you mentioned as we exit 2015, kind of that $2.9 billion-ish kind of run rate, certainly less than the 3 billion barrel -- or $3 billion, that really does entail an ability to direct more capital deployment to the North America resource plays. So for a bit smaller pie, we're able to dedicate a much larger slice to the North America resource plays even in that scenario. And so the ability to have that optionality to move from more of a maintenance capital mode in the resource plays to more of a growth mode, we still have that optionality within a reduced budget in 2016. Was that -- did that get it clarified, Guy?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. That helps a ton.
componenttext: Yes. That helps a ton.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Phillip Jungwirth.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Phillip Jungwirth.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the Eagle Ford, you noted the 40% sequential decline in activity as the reason for lower production. Looking at the expected wells to sales in the second half, it looks like the quarterly average is going to be a little bit lower than what you had in 2
componenttext: On the Eagle Ford, you noted the 40% sequential decline in activity as the reason for lower production. Looking at the expected wells to sales in the second half, it looks like the quarterly average is going to be a little bit lower than what you had in 2Q. So is the current activity run rate below maintenance CapEx? Is that -- or can volumes still be held flat on better well productivity in the second half or a shallower decline, given that you probably had a lot of flush production coming into the year?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Phil, I think you're seeing that actually very well. Compared to the previous several quarters where we've had in excess of 90 wells to sales, in the second quarter, we had 52 wells for sales, which is driving that production in the Eagle Ford downwa
componenttext: Yes. Phil, I think you're seeing that actually very well. Compared to the previous several quarters where we've had in excess of 90 wells to sales, in the second quarter, we had 52 wells for sales, which is driving that production in the Eagle Ford downward. Really, the wave of those higher-productivity wells that are very early in their life coming down has kind of overwhelmed the number of new wells to sales. I think from a perspective of activity across North America, including Eagle Ford, has come down to about 45% for us. What you really see is we're managing that downward to a point of stability. We will have roughly the same number of wells, plus or minus, in the third and fourth quarter in Eagle Ford, specifically. In any given quarter, our working interest moves around a little bit within that, so the number of gross wells and net wells can move a bit. So I think in general, we're guiding toward relatively flat production quarter-over-quarter, and we're managing that large activity downward in the quarter. I would say, too, some context on that. Even as we said the wells to sales were lower in Eagle Ford, I think it's important to note we went from 5 frac fleets to 2 by April. So we were down to that lowest level of wells to sales-driven activity by very early in the second quarter, which kind of added to that deceleration impact.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then can you discuss any results from the 1 Osage well brought on during the quarter. I think Marathon might be the first to drill a well in this zone. Based on what you know today, how would you also compare this emerging play to both th
componenttext: Okay, great. And then can you discuss any results from the 1 Osage well brought on during the quarter. I think Marathon might be the first to drill a well in this zone. Based on what you know today, how would you also compare this emerging play to both the Meramec and the Woodford?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Phil. We've -- last year, we started an exploration program in STACK focused on the Meramec and the Osage. That Osage well was the last well of the initial group, our -- sort of our initial foray into the STACK in an operated basis. I think you may
componenttext: Sure, Phil. We've -- last year, we started an exploration program in STACK focused on the Meramec and the Osage. That Osage well was the last well of the initial group, our -- sort of our initial foray into the STACK in an operated basis. I think you may recall in the second half of last year, we actually increased activity in Oklahoma up to 6 rigs. And that well was drilled effectively starting right after Christmas and is sort of the last well in that program. We've evaluated the results from all of those. We continue to see the Meramec as the most valuable zone in that area in general. I don't think we foresee a more Osage activity any time in the near term.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: You're talking about selling some assets in an extremely depressed environment, where there are plenty of distressed sellers that are in far worse shape than you are. Isn't it kind of leaving money on the table if you're monetizing just about anything rig
componenttext: You're talking about selling some assets in an extremely depressed environment, where there are plenty of distressed sellers that are in far worse shape than you are. Isn't it kind of leaving money on the table if you're monetizing just about anything right now?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, first of all, I don't view our noncore assets as being distressed sales, and the reason I said it, Pavel, is that when you think about the type of assets that we will put in the market, we believe that there's still a very strong competitive en
componenttext: Yes. Well, first of all, I don't view our noncore assets as being distressed sales, and the reason I said it, Pavel, is that when you think about the type of assets that we will put in the market, we believe that there's still a very strong competitive environment for those assets. And I'll use the East Texas, North Louisiana, Wilburton transaction as an example. We had a very strong response to the data room. We had well over 20 proposals for the property. When you look at the deal metrics, they were very compelling on a cash flow multiple basis, over 9x. And so we feel like for the right type of assets, there is still a ready market out there. And I would not want to leave the impression that we're selling anything at reduced value or low value to our shareholders. I mean, we don't view these as distressed assets. We simply view them as part of our ongoing portfolio management. And if we can't capture fair value, then we'll continue to operate. In the case of the East Texas, North Louisiana, Wilburton deal, it was a gassy asset. It was no longer competing for capital allocation, a relatively high unit cash cost. We had a strong competitive environment for it. And the deal metrics were very competitive in this pricing environment or others. So I think we feel very good about our ability to continue to transact at fair value.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just to clarify, it's not your assets I was calling distressed. It's plenty of others in the market that are in that state. Now my follow-up is, you talk about flexing the balance sheet into 2016. Debt-to-cap is currently at 29%. How high
componenttext: Understood. And just to clarify, it's not your assets I was calling distressed. It's plenty of others in the market that are in that state. Now my follow-up is, you talk about flexing the balance sheet into 2016. Debt-to-cap is currently at 29%. How high would you be comfortable letting that metric go up?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. What I would tell you is I've always tried to be careful to draw hard and fast rules. But when I think of looking through 2015, when I take into consideration all my -- I'm sorry, 2016, when I take into consideration what I said before about the vari
componenttext: Yes. What I would tell you is I've always tried to be careful to draw hard and fast rules. But when I think of looking through 2015, when I take into consideration all my -- I'm sorry, 2016, when I take into consideration what I said before about the variables around capital, operating cost structure, asset sales programs, I still want to ultimately manage the balance sheet through '16 to, let's call it, as close to 2.5x net debt-to-EBITDA as I can in this low commodity price environment. Now that's going -- it's going to be lumpy.  It's going to be dependent upon the timing of various asset sales. And so that will become a bit higher than that, but that's ultimately one of the variables I'm trying to manage to. And as commodity prices then begin to stabilize, whether that's early '17 or you decide when, then ultimately you'll see that leverage get back to its more traditional levels of 2x and below.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question regards to the Oklahoma resource plays, the increase in nonop participation. I was just wondering are the choices driven by any specific operator performance. Or is it driven more by geography?
componenttext: My first question regards to the Oklahoma resource plays, the increase in nonop participation. I was just wondering are the choices driven by any specific operator performance. Or is it driven more by geography?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Jeffrey, I think, overall, we're focused on value. We have a substantial core acreage position in both the SCOOP and in the STACK. When we see activity in that core high-value acreage where we've seen great historical results, and from recent data, w
componenttext: Yes. Jeffrey, I think, overall, we're focused on value. We have a substantial core acreage position in both the SCOOP and in the STACK. When we see activity in that core high-value acreage where we've seen great historical results, and from recent data, we expect those results to be great than other areas, we're choosing to participate in those wells to capture the data and leverage our -- both the collection of that data and integration of it to drive toward full field development. And to some extent, if you didn't participate in those valuable acreage, it's an opportunity lost, and we certainly want to capture all those opportunities. So it's not really driven by an operator. It's driven by our perceived value of the acreage and the opportunity. I'd say within the context of that, we see more -- I'd say, more execution-friendly operators than others. And as you'd imagine, we -- based on that, we make economic decisions based on how we feel they can execute.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And my other question was on Slide 17 regarding the Bakken spacing pilots to this point. The ranges appear less prolific than some of the non-spacing data that's provided, yet a large production uplift was identified out to 180 days.
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And my other question was on Slide 17 regarding the Bakken spacing pilots to this point. The ranges appear less prolific than some of the non-spacing data that's provided, yet a large production uplift was identified out to 180 days. So I'm wondering if you can help me to understand how to interpret the data that's being presented and as well, if you could indicate how you feel the pilots are performing relative to your expectations at this point.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So with 3 spacing pilots online, I feel like we've made a lot of progress at moving that forward on an operated basis, kind of start work south to north, if you will. Those are -- spacing pilots are in 3 different areas, starting in the south. It's
componenttext: Sure. So with 3 spacing pilots online, I feel like we've made a lot of progress at moving that forward on an operated basis, kind of start work south to north, if you will. Those are -- spacing pilots are in 3 different areas, starting in the south. It's Middle Bakken, so it's on a 6-well per Middle Bakken pattern overall. There is a wide range of results there. I think in the case of that pilot in the Ajax area, when you look at the aggregate or all of the wells on there, you'll see some above type curve, you'll see some a little below. But when you put them together, they look like they're performing very in line with our early expectations for that despite being at closer spacing than stand-alone wells. So that gives us a lot of encouragement. We expected some differentiation. In some cases, what we'll find is, when we go in and there's more than 1 parent well or older well in the area, you'll see some depletion impact in the new well that's near that older well will be impacted modestly by that. But in aggregate, we tend to look at the entire unit, how many wells, how many total dollars invested, what's the total production coming out of that. And so that Ajax pilot, for example, is performing very much in line with those expectations. Moving further north to Hector in that pilot. Again, we see a diversity of results. But in aggregate, they're performing very similarly to our expectations for the early production. Some of the wells in those groups are more mature than others. So several of those are at 90 or 120 days, and they're continuing to perform well. So we're very pleased with that result overall. And these pilots -- some of the wells, vintage-wise, had more aggressive stimulations than others based on when they were drilled and completed. And then lastly, in Myrmidon, we see a wide range there, too. I think in the case of that one pilot, we intentionally looked at that pilot and said there are 4 older parent wells between those 2 sections or units that were developed together. And so the wells near  those -- the new wells near the parent wells are showing lesser production than the wells that are further outlying, and that's not unexpected in our case. We want to test that as we have parent wellbores we need to work around. But I think in general, we're still very pleased with the overall production and continue to see that as a validation of our spacing assumptions moving forward.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's fantastic color. If I could just add a little follow-up because the question was long enough to begin with. Just to clarify, do these spacing pilots have any cost advantages over a more typical production patterns? Is this just purely about t
componenttext: Well, that's fantastic color. If I could just add a little follow-up because the question was long enough to begin with. Just to clarify, do these spacing pilots have any cost advantages over a more typical production patterns? Is this just purely about trying to capture the maximum resource?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeffrey, any time we have the opportunity to pad develop groups of wells, we have a great opportunity on the drilling efficiency side to capture those cost savings, similarly on the completion side, where we can leave a frac fleet on 1 pad and drill -- or
componenttext: Jeffrey, any time we have the opportunity to pad develop groups of wells, we have a great opportunity on the drilling efficiency side to capture those cost savings, similarly on the completion side, where we can leave a frac fleet on 1 pad and drill -- or excuse me, complete multiple wells. On both of those fronts, we gained tremendous efficiency. And then lastly, on the surface facility, the ability to share those surface facilities also creates a scale efficiency. So we constantly seek and desire the opportunity for pad development because it really does positively influence our capital.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for the questions and interest in Marathon Oil. I'd like to thank everyone again for their participation this morning. Please contact Zach Dailey or myself if you have any follow-up questions. Operator, thank you. This concludes today's conferen
componenttext: Thank you for the questions and interest in Marathon Oil. I'd like to thank everyone again for their participation this morning. Please contact Zach Dailey or myself if you have any follow-up questions. Operator, thank you. This concludes today's conference call, and you may now disconnect.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2015 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sylvia, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call ov
componenttext:
Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2015 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sylvia, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I will now turn the call over to Chris Phillips. Mr. Phillips, you may begin.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sylvia. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's third quarter 2015 earnings call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, CEO and President; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice Pr
componenttext:
Thank you, Sylvia. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's third quarter 2015 earnings call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, CEO and President; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Mitch Little, Vice President, International Offshore Exploration Production Operations; Lance Robertson, Vice President, North America Production Operations; and Zach Dailey, Director of Investor Relations.
As has become our custom, we released prepared remarks last night in conjunction with the earnings release. You can find those remarks and the associated slides at marathonoil.com.
As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. And our comments and answers to questions will contain forward-looking information subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. I refer you back to the aforementioned slides, where you can find our full safe harbor statement.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, good morning. Thank you, Chris. Our priority this year has been exercising capital discipline, reducing cost, capturing efficiencies, progressing our noncore asset sales and protecting the balance sheet, and our most recent actions have b
componenttext:
All right. Well, good morning. Thank you, Chris. Our priority this year has been exercising capital discipline, reducing cost, capturing efficiencies, progressing our noncore asset sales and protecting the balance sheet, and our most recent actions have been fully consistent with those objectives. Last Thursday, we announced a decision by the Board of the Directors to adjust our quarterly dividend from $0.21 per share to $0.05 per share. We felt that this action was prudent and the best interest of all shareholders and appropriately addresses the uncertainty of a lower-for-longer commodity price environment. It will increase annual free cash flow by more than $425 million and aligns with our priority of maintaining a strong balance sheet through the cycle. The initial capital flexibility is essential to support growth from our deep inventory of investment opportunities in the U.S. resource plays when commodity prices improve. 
Further, it is another step in the transformation of Marathon Oil from its integrated legacy to becoming a leading independent E&P company focused on capturing value in the U.S. unconventional resource plays.
Turning to the third quarter. We delivered operational results that reflected consistent execution, efficiency gains and lower costs. The third quarter capital investment in exploration program came in below expectations, down 7% sequentially to $623 million.
We've been able to reduce our 2015 program by $200 million to $3.1 billion, primarily through a combination of U.S. resource play efficiency gain and phasing of international projects.
Total company net production from continuing operations excluding Libya averaged 434,000 oil equivalent barrels per day, a 6% increase over the year ago quarter and a 7% increase over the prior quarter.
Record production from Oil Sands Mining and higher production from Equatorial Guinea contributed to the increase from the prior quarter. We're on pace to achieve the high end of our total company 2015 production growth guidance at 7% year-over-year, and U.S. resource play growth at 20%, even with the $200 million reduction to our 2015 program.
In the U.S. resource plays net production averaged 212,000 oil equivalent barrels per day, up 12% over the year ago quarter and down 4% over the prior quarter. Our quarterly variance was driven primarily by lower sequential production from the Eagle Ford, due to timing of well to sales late in the third quarter and step-out in delineation drilling test. Our asset teams target the right balance of high-confidence development activity and continued resource delineation that positions us for growth as we look through the current cycle. In the case of the Eagle Ford this quarter, the team was focused on development drilling in core Karnes County, while also testing the limits of delineated acreage. 
We had another quarter of solid reduction and completed well cost, faster feet per day drill and more frac stages completed per month. We also previously announced additions to Eagle Ford 2P resource of 165 million oil equivalent barrels driven by the Upper Eagle Ford and Austin Chalk.
Though our operated Oklahoma Resource Basin's program is still dominated by leasehold activity, we bought our first SCOOP Woodford downspacing pilot online late in the third quarter. Early results are in line with our type curve and supportive of 107-acre spacing. Importantly, the learning curve improvement as we drilled and completed the wells illustrate the potential for Oklahoma to become significantly more efficient when we move into development mode. During the quarter, we announced a 35% increase in SCOOP and STACK 2P resource, adding 400 million oil equivalent barrels.
The Bakken team had an exciting quarter despite reduced completion activity, delivering 61,000 net oil equivalent barrels per day, in line with second quarter volumes. Results were driven by continued outperformance from the Doll pad wells in West Myrmidon, enhanced uptime as well as consistent performance from our 3 downspacing pilots. The team continue to aggressively attack cost, lowering direct expense in the quarter from a variety of factors, reduce water handling cost and contract services, getting more of our product on pipelines and greater efficiency gains from workover rigs.
International production and sales volumes were higher in the quarter primarily as a result of the performance of the new Alba C-21 well, the EG wire-line intervention program and high operational availability. The EG compression project achieved mechanical completion during the third quarter, and is preparing for transportation from the Netherlands to site. Installation and startup is set for mid-2016. 
Oil Sands Mining reported outstanding operational results in the third quarter, recording the highest level of production in the history of the asset as well as the lowest operating cost ever per synthetic barrels. These results were driven by increased reliability and uptime as well as an intense focus on reducing cost. We made great strides so far this year focusing on those elements of the business of that we control by reducing activity levels and capturing capital efficiencies. We've also reduced total company E&P production expenses and G&A cost excluding special items by about $136 million or 28% for third quarter 2015 compared to the same quarter in 2014. Similarly, on a year-to-date basis, the savings amount to over $290 million, over 20%. Drilling efficiency remains a focus across our U.S. unconventional plays with our best Eagle Ford rig drilling a well that averaged 3,000 feet per day in the third quarter, similar to the exceptional pace and our performance in the previous quarter. This performance was achieved while maintaining our geo-steering accuracy to land in the target window, 98% of the time. 
Our other 2 areas, the Bakken and Oklahoma Resource Basins also continue to show sustained improvements in their drilling efficiency.
Portfolio management ranged front and center, and we continue to make progress advancing our plan at divesting at least $500 million of noncore assets. What we've identified for sale are non-core E&P and Midstream asset, operator and non-operated, and simply do not compete for capital today, given the depth and breadth of our inventory in the U.S. resource plays, and will likely have higher value in someone else's portfolio.
During the quarter, we announced our strategic intent to scale back our conventional exploration business as the success of our U.S. resource play has continued to raise the bar for capital allocation. Commensurate with this decision, we signed an agreement to divest our exploration acreage in East Africa.
Last week, we provided initial guidance on our 2016 capital investment and exploration program as we continue to progress through the planning process with the overarching goal of living within our means next year inclusive of dividend and noncore asset sales.
Based on our current outlook and preliminary plan discussions, we would anticipate a total company 2016 program of up to $2.2 billion, which would give us the flexibility to deliver 2016 annual average production in the U.S. resource plays flat to 2015 exit rate. This represents a significant reduction from our $3.1 billion program in 2015, but at least 3 quarters of our 2016 program is expected to be directed towards the U.S. resource plays, which is also our highest risk-adjusted returns. We expect our 2016 budget to be approved by the Board of Directors later this year.
There's no doubt that the macro environment continues to challenge the industry. But one thing remains clear, Marathon Oil, is not opportunity limited. We are profitable inventory even in a lower-for-longer commodity price scenario as lower cost, capital efficiency and enhanced productivity continue to reduce breakeven prices and improve our economics.
Our priority remains balance sheet strength and capital flexibility in 2016. And we have a workforce that is responding to the challenge and positioning our company for success today and through the cycle.
I want to pause and personally thank and recognize our dedicated employees and contractors who continue to execute and deliver results while protecting our license to operate each and every day despite the distractions and uncertainties of the current environment.
With that, I'll hand it back to Chris to begin the Q&A.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Elia. Evan got [indiscernible] finding calls. I'm going to fill in for him. You put out the up to $2.2 billion CapEx guidance for '16 out there last week. What is the primary governor on your activity next year? Are you trying to keep res
componenttext: This is actually Elia. Evan got [indiscernible] finding calls. I'm going to fill in for him. You put out the up to $2.2 billion CapEx guidance for '16 out there last week. What is the primary governor on your activity next year? Are you trying to keep resource play production flat? Are you trying to limit spending to a certain level? Or I mean is the primary goal to reach certain specific target, specific goals in individual basins?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, of course, for us, as we stated, the objective for us in 2016 particularly in the current pricing environment will be balance sheet protection. And of course, balancing our cash flows and living within our means, that is our primary objective.
componenttext: Yes. Well, of course, for us, as we stated, the objective for us in 2016 particularly in the current pricing environment will be balance sheet protection. And of course, balancing our cash flows and living within our means, that is our primary objective. We're still very much in the planning cycle. The numbers we presented are preliminary. The work is ongoing, but we felt it important as we communicated the change or the adjustment in the dividend to also pair that up with at least an early view of 2016 outlook.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And kind of a follow-up. I mean, what does your Oklahoma program looks like in 2016? Maybe in -- I mean, both in terms of an account in more qualitative terms. I mean, how are you thinking in sort of -- how are you thinking about operated versus non opera
componenttext: And kind of a follow-up. I mean, what does your Oklahoma program looks like in 2016? Maybe in -- I mean, both in terms of an account in more qualitative terms. I mean, how are you thinking in sort of -- how are you thinking about operated versus non operated, et cetera? To what extent is it going to be driven by HBP? I mean, will we expect to see more Woodford wells because you're trying to hold in tight gaps?So can you kind of give some color on that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thus far, of course, because we are still very early in the planning process, we haven't provided quite that level of granularity down to the basin level. But that will be coming as we finalize the plan. However, now what I will share that is as incr
componenttext: Yes. Thus far, of course, because we are still very early in the planning process, we haven't provided quite that level of granularity down to the basin level. But that will be coming as we finalize the plan. However, now what I will share that is as incremental cash flow comes available, and we think about our program in 2016, due to the return and the growth potential in Oklahoma, we expect it to compete very favorably in the capital allocation process. So I would just say more to come on that point as we finalize our plan.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Lee, I just wonder if I could ask a little bit about how you're preparing the portfolio for, let's be optimistic for a second, some kind of rebound in the commodity over time? You've obviously rightsized the dividend, and you've got clearly significant de
componenttext: Lee, I just wonder if I could ask a little bit about how you're preparing the portfolio for, let's be optimistic for a second, some kind of rebound in the commodity over time? You've obviously rightsized the dividend, and you've got clearly significant depths in the Oklahoma Basin in particular. So I'm just kind of thinking as you look at incremental capital allocation going forward, where would you see the priorities? And if I may tag an add-on there, how do you see reallocating capital from your noncore assets? Can you maybe quantify how much capital may be associated with the noncore stuff as well? I've got a follow-up, please.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very good. Well, thanks, and good morning, Doug. Of course, our decision around the adjustment and the dividend, one of the aspects of that was in fact the capital flexibility that it provides as we think about driving more allocation into the resou
componenttext: Okay. Very good. Well, thanks, and good morning, Doug. Of course, our decision around the adjustment and the dividend, one of the aspects of that was in fact the capital flexibility that it provides as we think about driving more allocation into the resource plays as we see more constructive pricing. But as we think about where that first incremental capital may be directed, by the way, I think about it as it's going to be driven by economics, which today says that capital would be targeted toward incremental activity in both the Eagle Ford as well as ultimately Oklahoma, expanding our operated program in Oklahoma. In terms of the noncore assets question, maybe let me step back and just address that in general, first and foremost. We have high confidence in our $500 million target that we have put out on the noncore assets. We have before shared that we have, in fact, closed the earlier announced deal in East Texas, North Louisiana. We have many of those opportunities in process today, and continue to feel that there is a market out there for the right type of assets. So our confidence in that remains very high. There well, no doubt, the implications as we are successful in those transactions from a capital avoidance standpoint,point but it's probably bit premature to get into those numbers until we actually are able to execute deals.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. My follow-up is really in your I guess, [indiscernible] we see talked about the 2.2 holding the exit rate and the unconventionals flat. I guess, I know it's a little early for 2016 yet, but 1 of your peers or 1 of your partners rather h
componenttext: I appreciate that. My follow-up is really in your I guess, [indiscernible] we see talked about the 2.2 holding the exit rate and the unconventionals flat. I guess, I know it's a little early for 2016 yet, but 1 of your peers or 1 of your partners rather has talked about the fairly hefty maintenance you have at Equatorial Guinea. So I wonder if you can give us some just order of magnitude as to how you see the portfolio production outlook with that level of spending going into next year? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, let me, I believe what you're referring to, Doug, as we look out into 2016, there will naturally be associated scheduled and planned downtime as we do the installation of the compression project. That, of course, is fully accounted for in th
componenttext: Yes. I think, let me, I believe what you're referring to, Doug, as we look out into 2016, there will naturally be associated scheduled and planned downtime as we do the installation of the compression project. That, of course, is fully accounted for in the preliminary numbers that we have shared thus far. So that work is integrated into that. So as we think about that 4Q exit that we talked about, which was really talking about the resource play 4Q exit to full year '16 average, that's really outside of the total company. But when you think about it from a total company perspective, given that we have provided direct guidance from our resource play, I'd like to think about it and really if you kind of large buckets. One is, of course, Equatorial Guinea, which will largely be flat x the downtime I just address. Two, Oil Sands Mining, which will have largely again a flat profile ex-planned maintenance turnarounds, we do have some other North America onshore assets that will have relatively shallow the clients. And then, of course, our conventional Dawn and mature U.K. business which albeit relatively small volumes, we'd expect those to have typical mature declines. So as you put that overlay on it, I just want to try to give a feel for what volumes might feel like in their totality in 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

componenttextpreview: I've got, I guess, 2 questions. Looking at perhaps further out. The first one is on the Eagle Ford. Folks are worried that about your Tier 1 Eagle Ford inventory relative to Tier 2. So maybe just a reminder of how much Tier 1 years we're drilling, you thi
componenttext: I've got, I guess, 2 questions. Looking at perhaps further out. The first one is on the Eagle Ford. Folks are worried that about your Tier 1 Eagle Ford inventory relative to Tier 2. So maybe just a reminder of how much Tier 1 years we're drilling, you think you have. And then what sort of degradation there is in the portfolio as you get out towards the French?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, good morning. This is Lance. I think as we look out perhaps I'll start with this. Earlier in this quarter, we actually disclosed an unconventional resource portfolio in North America of 5,500 wells. And of that portfolio, I think we described the fir
componenttext: Yes, good morning. This is Lance. I think as we look out perhaps I'll start with this. Earlier in this quarter, we actually disclosed an unconventional resource portfolio in North America of 5,500 wells. And of that portfolio, I think we described the first 5 years of it, 77% of that returns better than breakeven at $50 flat oil. And of that inventory, Eagle Ford is, by far, the largest components. And I think we have confidence we have many years of what you described is Tier 1 or high-quality development left in that asset, Ed.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then switching to the SCOOP and probably on the same kind of topic. Really, it's only the XLs on the current economics that really looked like they can compete with some of the best shale that's in another basins. So where do you think you can get the
componenttext: And then switching to the SCOOP and probably on the same kind of topic. Really, it's only the XLs on the current economics that really looked like they can compete with some of the best shale that's in another basins. So where do you think you can get the DNC cost down to perhaps for the shorter laterals? I mean, how many XLs I think you can drill as a percent of the total? And then where do we think we are in the completion cycle in terms of optimization to boost the EURs? I'm just trying to get a sense of how much momentum there can be in that play in terms of recycle ratios and returns.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think I'd start maybe at the last end of that question first. I think we have a lot of confidence that we're so early the development cycle in both the Oklahoma resource basin plus SCOOP and STACK that we're nowhere near the highest efficiency, best com
componenttext: I think I'd start maybe at the last end of that question first. I think we have a lot of confidence that we're so early the development cycle in both the Oklahoma resource basin plus SCOOP and STACK that we're nowhere near the highest efficiency, best completion yet. So we expect well productivity to continue to increase over time, particularly as we get to scale and we have more opportunity to experiment in a structured way. Similarly, maybe perhaps best illustrated by the Smith pilot that was in our earnings deck, we also expect that more mature development cycle as it unfolds for us to really be able to materially impact the capital cost. I think that example we're down 33% from the front-end to the back-end of that pad is implemented we, we expect on a full cycle basis. So I have complete confidence that we're going to continue to deliver both better cost and better productivity in Oklahoma and that's going to help both the XL wells and the SL wells complete favorably for capital cost to cycle.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next version comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And the next version comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: For investors who have looked to Marathon historically in part for that dividends, now that you've made the tough decision to cut that dividend, is there an offsetting metric that you in the board are looking to improve or bolster as a result of that cut?
componenttext: For investors who have looked to Marathon historically in part for that dividends, now that you've made the tough decision to cut that dividend, is there an offsetting metric that you in the board are looking to improve or bolster as a result of that cut? It could be production growth, maybe corporate returns. Or does the dividend cuts just help you to maintain your balance sheet objectives, which would potentially argue for a dividend increase if oil prices were to rise?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, Brian, I believe our board is looking at it quite holistically, they're looking at it at an aggregate for all shareholders, what is the model based on our portfolio that will deliver the best total shareholder returns. When I think about the logi
componenttext: I think, Brian, I believe our board is looking at it quite holistically, they're looking at it at an aggregate for all shareholders, what is the model based on our portfolio that will deliver the best total shareholder returns. When I think about the logic, I believe, that the board went through with the leadership team, it was really looking at the dividend in the context of appropriately addressing this lower-for-longer environment, and the uncertainty that's associated with it. It was really making certain that we could protect our balance sheet through the cycle. And then finally, and I think most importantly, it provides us that capital flexibility going forward as we see more constructive pricings to drive more investment at a higher return into the U.S. resource play. And of course, it gave us an increase in our free cash flows by greater than $425 million. So I believe the board looked at it holistically, and looked at in the context of the preliminary plan data that we had to share with them at the time, and it was really that collective logic that went into it.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Then follow-up is with regard to the earlier question on the Eagle Ford and the tiering. I noticed the oil as a percent of the total in the mix has come down a bit here. Can you talk to whether that is timing -- based on the timing of completions?
componenttext: Great. Then follow-up is with regard to the earlier question on the Eagle Ford and the tiering. I noticed the oil as a percent of the total in the mix has come down a bit here. Can you talk to whether that is timing -- based on the timing of completions? And how the oiliness looks at the remaining inventory and the remaining locations there, and how that translates to the '16 program?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, our Eagle Ford asset has a substantial oil component, a substantial condensate component, and so wet condensate, a little bit of that as well. And so in this environment, the lower-for-longer would, in a disciplined way, we're choosing the highest
componenttext: Brian, our Eagle Ford asset has a substantial oil component, a substantial condensate component, and so wet condensate, a little bit of that as well. And so in this environment, the lower-for-longer would, in a disciplined way, we're choosing the highest return opportunities at current pricing. The condensate has generally been providing those returns. And so we're a small change in mix to a little bit less oil overall. We still have large inventory in the oil and in the condensate left to develop in the future. And depending on commodity prices, we're going to consistently choose those highest return opportunities. As large as the base is overall, we don't expect them, the mix, to change very much over the -- on the long-haul basis.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Heikkinen, Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Heikkinen, Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: On your second quarter update to your third quarter update in the Eagle Ford, your met wells to sales increased, can you talk about how that -- the increase for this year? And kind of what the expectation is now for fourth quarter versus net wells drilled
componenttext: On your second quarter update to your third quarter update in the Eagle Ford, your met wells to sales increased, can you talk about how that -- the increase for this year? And kind of what the expectation is now for fourth quarter versus net wells drilled didn't change?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think one of the things we've seen, David, over the balance of this year is we continue to get more and more efficient overall both on the completion cycle and in the drilling cycle. I think we've illustrated that in the deck. And we continue to a
componenttext: Sure. I think one of the things we've seen, David, over the balance of this year is we continue to get more and more efficient overall both on the completion cycle and in the drilling cycle. I think we've illustrated that in the deck. And we continue to avoid building in inventory of drilled but uncompleted wells. So what you're seeing is us manage as we get more efficient with those rigs and we do it at lower cost. We have more opportunity to investment versus managing that inventory in an efficient operational bases overall. No intent to build inventory or to deplete it. We want to keep it relatively constant, and so we're managing that actively, David.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in your -- just one quick question on ET. How much downtime will you have for the compression project? How long will that take?
componenttext: Okay. And then in your -- just one quick question on ET. How much downtime will you have for the compression project? How long will that take?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, this is Mitch Little. We have the installation campaign for the new compression platform that Lee spoke to earlier. And we would look at on the order of a couple of weeks to facilitate the initial installation of the jacket and topsides. We also ha
componenttext: David, this is Mitch Little. We have the installation campaign for the new compression platform that Lee spoke to earlier. And we would look at on the order of a couple of weeks to facilitate the initial installation of the jacket and topsides. We also have scheduled planned maintenance, it's part of delivering our high reliability in those assets. So there will be some partial downtime associated with that, that will also occur in the first quarter. But going into the second half of the year, of course, we'll have the benefits from that compression project that will bring rates back up to above even current rates.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one quick one on the Meramec wells, e.g. 1 that's just to fit in. The well results, kind of thinking about rates and well design. Can you talk about who would've thought that area would've been a little gassier, looks a little oilier, just my opi
componenttext: And just one quick one on the Meramec wells, e.g. 1 that's just to fit in. The well results, kind of thinking about rates and well design. Can you talk about who would've thought that area would've been a little gassier, looks a little oilier, just my opinion. Can you go through your thoughts on what happened in that part of[indiscernible]

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, David. I think as we're working through this early part of the Meramec, it's important to realize that we're focusing primarily on leasehold drilling, so we're covering a diverse area of several counties to convert these term leases to held by produ
componenttext: Sure, David. I think as we're working through this early part of the Meramec, it's important to realize that we're focusing primarily on leasehold drilling, so we're covering a diverse area of several counties to convert these term leases to held by production. We expect to see some diversity in those early well results. We're still working on the best designs and the completion and how we manage those wells in their early days. So I think while our results aren't or perhaps as much as we desired, we expect this diversity, it's early days. We're excited about seeing the continued momentum in the basin. The IP has continued to get better. The productivity is improving overall. And importantly, the cost improvements over the last year have been very material. And on top of that, you've seen us continue to be opportunistic and adding acres in this area at attractive pricing because we continue to see this as a great place to invest in the future.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from John Herrlin from Societe Generale.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most things have been asked, but I was just curious with Shenandoah. Is that an asset strategically that would be better off with 1 of your partners in terms of taking that cash flow for future CapEx? And then dedicate it more towards the resource plays?
componenttext: Most things have been asked, but I was just curious with Shenandoah. Is that an asset strategically that would be better off with 1 of your partners in terms of taking that cash flow for future CapEx? And then dedicate it more towards the resource plays?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Now, a good question. On Shenandoah, of course, we're still very much early in the appraisal phase. We've seen some excellent results from the last appraisal well. And I think the -- those as well as the operator share of those. We haven't reached an
componenttext: Yes. Now, a good question. On Shenandoah, of course, we're still very much early in the appraisal phase. We've seen some excellent results from the last appraisal well. And I think the -- those as well as the operator share of those. We haven't reached an investment decision, of course, around Shenandoah in the base case. Ultimately, it will need to compete for capital allocation head-to-head with the rest of our opportunities. But until we see the final development plan, and can make a, I would say, a thoughtful decision around that, I think that's an open question.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I apologize if some of these have been asked. I did get on the call a little bit late. In the unconventionals here, when you announced the dividend reduction, the initial CapEx for '16, the expectation to U.S. unconventionals could be flattish, I think, i
componenttext: I apologize if some of these have been asked. I did get on the call a little bit late. In the unconventionals here, when you announced the dividend reduction, the initial CapEx for '16, the expectation to U.S. unconventionals could be flattish, I think, is the right way to think about it in '16 with the '15 exit rate. Is there a -- and we've heard these questions asked other places, is there a rationale to keep that flat because of the challenges of recovering once oil prices come up and you start drilling more in terms of fighting decline curves? Or should we think of it as in a $45 to $50 oil environment, that really is a reasonable way to invest in terms of just the returns of those wells today?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the way that we have thought about that very preliminary guidance that we've provided, Roger, is really rooted in our overarching objective of balance sheet protection. And in the current environment, it's a $50 environment, we are not solving for
componenttext: I think the way that we have thought about that very preliminary guidance that we've provided, Roger, is really rooted in our overarching objective of balance sheet protection. And in the current environment, it's a $50 environment, we are not solving for growth at that point. We are really looking at living within our means, inclusive of both the dividend as well as our noncore asset program. The preliminary guidance we provided, we believe, provides us a pathway to that cash flow neutrality. But as we see more constructive pricing or more constructive outlook, certainly, we'll take a thoughtful approach to how we allocate that and the number one allocation will be our U.S. resource play. But I'd just emphasize that we're still very early, still in the planning cycle.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And kind of as a follow-up to that. Is there anything that you've changed? You mentioned earlier the shift towards maybe a little more of the NGL condensates because that's where the economics are. Is there anything you've changed in the sort of ini
componenttext: Okay. And kind of as a follow-up to that. Is there anything that you've changed? You mentioned earlier the shift towards maybe a little more of the NGL condensates because that's where the economics are. Is there anything you've changed in the sort of initial production of your wells? The first 30 days, 90 days, something like that in terms of choking them back to -- why, in other words, sell all your production upfront when the prices aren't particularly impressive. And whether or not you've considered anything on the hedging side.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Roger, I'd say operationally, we continue to bring the wells back in each basin based on the flow back parameters that drive the best well productivity. We're not managing those lower -- I think with the way you're describing, just to manage the productio
componenttext: Roger, I'd say operationally, we continue to bring the wells back in each basin based on the flow back parameters that drive the best well productivity. We're not managing those lower -- I think with the way you're describing, just to manage the production profile. We're doing it to drive best well productivity. In some small cases, basin to basin, where there -- we may have a, once in a while, a limitation on gas capture, for example, in North Dakota. Or we may build a facility that's slightly undersized to minimize our spending [indiscernible] but those tend to be short term and those are the exception, not the rule. So overall, we're continuing to manage the chokes and flowback to drive best well productivity.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And hedging, any thoughts on that?
componenttext: Thanks. And hedging, any thoughts on that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Roger, this is J.R. I think you should consider the fact that hedging will be an element of a broader commodity risk management strategy going forward. And as opportunities present themselves in the market, we'll continue to look at ways to protect m
componenttext: Yes, Roger, this is J.R. I think you should consider the fact that hedging will be an element of a broader commodity risk management strategy going forward. And as opportunities present themselves in the market, we'll continue to look at ways to protect more the downside commodity price risk in the portfolio.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: At the risk of sounding like a CNBC debate moderator, I got to push you a little bit on the dividend. 3 months ago, you have very, very strong language in explaining why the dividend is the first call on cash flow. And I guess I'm just curious, what in th
componenttext: At the risk of sounding like a CNBC debate moderator, I got to push you a little bit on the dividend. 3 months ago, you have very, very strong language in explaining why the dividend is the first call on cash flow. And I guess I'm just curious, what in the last 90 days, what was the specific trigger for shifting from it is the first call in cash flow to cutting it 76%?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pavel, I mean, first of all, I would still say, even with our current dividend levels, that is -- it remains our first call on cash flow. But in terms of the why now question, which I believe is what you're asking around the adjustment to the dividen
componenttext: Yes, Pavel, I mean, first of all, I would still say, even with our current dividend levels, that is -- it remains our first call on cash flow. But in terms of the why now question, which I believe is what you're asking around the adjustment to the dividend. The way I we would describe that is, first of all, it's really been a further and continued volatility and weakness in the commodity pricing environment. I would say secondly, it's been a growing confidence in the quality but most importantly, the depth of our U.S. resource play base, which we just added in the past quarter 600 million oil equivalent barrels of 2P resource there. And then I would say the third factor that really was the trigger point is that we were able to share a preliminary view of our plan at the board level, so there was -- we had the ability to put that dividend adjustment in the context of our forward outlook and plans. So those were really the 3, I would say, triggers, Pavel, in terms of the why now question.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, fair enough. And then kind of '15 to 2016, I know you said you haven't finalized the specific geographic components of the CapEx. But do you envision there being any kind of carveouts from the CapEx curtailment? And I'm thinking Oklahoma perha
componenttext: Okay, okay, fair enough. And then kind of '15 to 2016, I know you said you haven't finalized the specific geographic components of the CapEx. But do you envision there being any kind of carveouts from the CapEx curtailment? And I'm thinking Oklahoma perhaps, any areas that will get special treatment or protection from the overall 30% cut?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we're going to follow our rigorous capital allocation process, Pavel, so that it's going to be driven by economics. But there are cases, and Lance alluded to them -- to 1 earlier, where there are wells opportunity aspects to some of the plays
componenttext: Well, again, we're going to follow our rigorous capital allocation process, Pavel, so that it's going to be driven by economics. But there are cases, and Lance alluded to them -- to 1 earlier, where there are wells opportunity aspects to some of the plays, specifically in Oklahoma, where we still have significant term lease that we need to hold. We are going to be looking to protect that as a top priority. So I wouldn't necessarily call that special treatment. I would just call that being smart about our business.
