componenttext: And the next question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Lee, I wonder if I could ask a little bit about how you're preparing the portfolio for, let's be optimistic for a second, some kind of rebound in the commodity over time? You've obviously rightsized the dividend, and you've got clearly significant depths
componenttext: Lee, I wonder if I could ask a little bit about how you're preparing the portfolio for, let's be optimistic for a second, some kind of rebound in the commodity over time? You've obviously rightsized the dividend, and you've got clearly significant depths in the Oklahoma Basin in particular. So I'm just kind of thinking as you look at incremental capital allocation going forward, where would you see the priorities? And if I may tack on an add-on there, how do you see reallocating capital from your noncore assets? Can you, maybe, quantify how much capital may be associated with the noncore stuff as well? I've got a follow-up, please.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very good. Well, thanks, and good morning, Doug. Of course, our decision around the adjustment and the dividend, one of the aspects of that was in fact the capital flexibility that it provides as we think about driving more allocation into the resou
componenttext: Okay. Very good. Well, thanks, and good morning, Doug. Of course, our decision around the adjustment and the dividend, one of the aspects of that was in fact the capital flexibility that it provides as we think about driving more allocation into the resource plays as we see more constructive pricing. But as we think about where that first incremental capital may be directed, the way I think about it is it's going to be driven by economics, which today says that capital would be targeted toward incremental activity in both the Eagle Ford as well as ultimately Oklahoma, expanding our operated program in Oklahoma. In terms of the noncore asset question, maybe let me step back and just address that in general, first and foremost. We have high confidence in our $500 million target that we have put out on the noncore assets. We have fore shared that we have, in fact, closed the earlier announced deal in East Texas, North Louisiana. We have many of those opportunities in process today, and continue to feel that there is a market out there for the right type of assets. So our confidence in that remains very high. There will, no doubt, be implications as we are successful in those transactions from a capital avoidance standpoint, but it's probably a bit premature to get into those numbers until we actually are able to execute deals.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that, Lee. My follow-up is really in your -- I guess, at earlier press release, you talked about the $2.2 billion holding the exit rate and the unconventionals flat. I guess, I know it's a little early for 2016 yet, but one of your peers or o
componenttext: I appreciate that, Lee. My follow-up is really in your -- I guess, at earlier press release, you talked about the $2.2 billion holding the exit rate and the unconventionals flat. I guess, I know it's a little early for 2016 yet, but one of your peers or one of your partners rather has talked about the fairly hefty maintenance you are going to have at Equatorial Guinea. So I wonder if you could give us some just order of magnitude as to how you see the portfolio production outlook with that level of spending going into next year? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, let me, I believe what you're referring to, Doug, as we look out into 2016, there will naturally be associated scheduled and planned downtime as we do the installation of the compression project. That, of course, is fully accounted for in th
componenttext: Yes. I think, let me, I believe what you're referring to, Doug, as we look out into 2016, there will naturally be associated scheduled and planned downtime as we do the installation of the compression project. That, of course, is fully accounted for in the preliminary numbers that we have shared thus far. So that work is integrated into that. So as we think about that 4Q exit that we talked about, which was really talking about the resource plays 4Q exit to full year '16 average, that's really outside of the total company. But when you think about it from a total company perspective, given that we have provided direct guidance on the resource play, I'd like to think about it and really a few kind of large buckets. One is, of course, Equatorial Guinea, which will largely be flat x the downtime that I just addressed. Two, Oil Sands Mining, which will have largely again a flat profile ex-planned maintenance and turnarounds. We do have some other North America onshore assets that will have relatively shallow declines, and then, of course -- and our conventional Guam and mature U.K. businesses, which albeit relatively small volumes. We'd expect those to have typical mature declines. So as you put that overlay on it, I just want to try to give a feel for what volumes might feel like in their totality in 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congrats on lot of tough decisions so far this year for the Downturn. I've got, I guess, 2 questions looking at perhaps further out. The first one is on the Eagle Ford. Folks are worried that about your Tier 1 Eagle Ford inventory relative to Tier 2. So m
componenttext: Congrats on lot of tough decisions so far this year for the Downturn. I've got, I guess, 2 questions looking at perhaps further out. The first one is on the Eagle Ford. Folks are worried that about your Tier 1 Eagle Ford inventory relative to Tier 2. So maybe just a reminder of how much Tier 1 years of drilling you think you have. And then what sort of degradation you think there is in the portfolio as you get out towards the fringe?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, good morning. This is Lance. I think as we look at it -- perhaps where I'd start with this. Earlier in this quarter, we actually disclosed an unconventional resource portfolio in North America of 5,500 wells. And of that portfolio, I think we describ
componenttext: Yes, good morning. This is Lance. I think as we look at it -- perhaps where I'd start with this. Earlier in this quarter, we actually disclosed an unconventional resource portfolio in North America of 5,500 wells. And of that portfolio, I think we described the first 5 years of it, 77% of that returns better than breakeven at $50 flat oil. And of that inventory, Eagle Ford is, by far, the largest component. And I think we have confidence we have many years of what you described is Tier 1 or high-quality development left in that asset, Ed.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then switching to the SCOOP and probably on the same kind of topic. Really, it's only the XLs on the current economics that really looked like they can compete with some of the best shale that's in another basins. So where do you think you can get the
componenttext: And then switching to the SCOOP and probably on the same kind of topic. Really, it's only the XLs on the current economics that really looked like they can compete with some of the best shale that's in another basins. So where do you think you can get the DNC cost down to perhaps for the shorter laterals? I mean, how many XLs do you think you can drill as a percent of the total? And then where do we think we are in the completion cycle in terms of optimization to boost the EURs? I'm just trying to get a sense of how much momentum there can be in that play in terms of recycle ratios and returns.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think I'd start, maybe, at the last end of that question first. I think we have a lot of confidence that we're so early in the development cycle in both the Oklahoma resource basin plus SCOOP and STACK that we're nowhere near the highest efficiency, bes
componenttext: I think I'd start, maybe, at the last end of that question first. I think we have a lot of confidence that we're so early in the development cycle in both the Oklahoma resource basin plus SCOOP and STACK that we're nowhere near the highest efficiency, best completion yet. So we expect well productivity to continue to increase over time, particularly as we get to scale and we have more opportunity to experiment in a structured way. Similarly, maybe perhaps best illustrated by the Smith pilot that was in our earnings deck, we also expect that more mature development cycle as it unfolds for us to really be able to materially impact the capital cost. I think that example we're down 33% from the front-end to the back-end of that pad is emblematic of what we expect on a full-cycle basis. So I'm -- I have complete confidence that we're going to continue to deliver both better cost and better productivity in Oklahoma and that's going to help both the XL wells and the SL wells complete favorably for capital cost to cycle.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: For investors who have looked to Marathon historically in part for that dividends, now as you've made the tough decision to cut that dividend, is there an offsetting metric that you and the board are looking to improve or bolster as a result of that cut?
componenttext: For investors who have looked to Marathon historically in part for that dividends, now as you've made the tough decision to cut that dividend, is there an offsetting metric that you and the board are looking to improve or bolster as a result of that cut? It could be production growth, maybe corporate returns. Or does the dividend cut just help you to maintain your balance sheet objectives, which would potentially argue for a dividend increase if oil prices were to rise?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, Brian, I believe our board is looking at it quite holistically. They're looking at it in an aggregate for all shareholders, what is the model based on our portfolio that will deliver the best total shareholder return. When you think about the log
componenttext: I think, Brian, I believe our board is looking at it quite holistically. They're looking at it in an aggregate for all shareholders, what is the model based on our portfolio that will deliver the best total shareholder return. When you think about the logic, I believe, that the board went through with the leadership team, it was really looking at the dividend in the context of appropriately addressing this lower-for-longer environment and the uncertainty that's associated with it. It was really making certain that we could protect our balance sheet through the cycle. And then finally, and I think most importantly, it provides us that capital flexibility going forward as we see more constructive pricings to drive more investment at a higher return into the U.S. resource play. And of course, it gave us an increase in our free cash flows by greater than $425 million. So I believe the board looked at it holistically. It looked at it in the context of the preliminary plan data that we had to share with them at the time, and it was really that collective logic that went into it.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then follow-up is with regards to one of the earlier questions on Eagle Ford and on the tiering, that is the oil as a percent of the total in the mix has come down a bit here. Can you talk to whether that is timing, based on the timing of compl
componenttext: Great. And then follow-up is with regards to one of the earlier questions on Eagle Ford and on the tiering, that is the oil as a percent of the total in the mix has come down a bit here. Can you talk to whether that is timing, based on the timing of completions? And how the oiliness looks of the remaining inventory and the remaining locations there? And how that translates to the '16 program?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, our Eagle Ford asset has a substantial oil component, a substantial condensate component, and some wet condensate, a little bit of that as well. And so in this environment, the lower-for-longer would, in a disciplined way, we're choosing the highes
componenttext: Brian, our Eagle Ford asset has a substantial oil component, a substantial condensate component, and some wet condensate, a little bit of that as well. And so in this environment, the lower-for-longer would, in a disciplined way, we're choosing the highest return opportunities at current pricing. The condensate has generally been providing those returns, and so we're seeing a small change in mix to a little bit less oil overall. We still have large inventory in the oil and in the condensate left to develop in the future, and depending on commodity prices, we're going to consistently choose those highest return opportunities. As large as the base is overall, we don't expect the mix to change very much over the -- on the long-haul basis.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Heikkinen, Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Heikkinen, Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: From your second quarter update to your third quarter update in the Eagle Ford, your net wells to sales increased. Can you talk about how that -- the increase for this year? And kind of what the expectation is now for fourth quarter versus net wells drill
componenttext: From your second quarter update to your third quarter update in the Eagle Ford, your net wells to sales increased. Can you talk about how that -- the increase for this year? And kind of what the expectation is now for fourth quarter versus net wells drilled didn't change?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think one of the things we've seen, David, over the balance of this year is we continue to get more and more efficient overall both on the completion cycle and in the drilling cycle. I think we've illustrated that in the deck. And we continue to a
componenttext: Sure. I think one of the things we've seen, David, over the balance of this year is we continue to get more and more efficient overall both on the completion cycle and in the drilling cycle. I think we've illustrated that in the deck. And we continue to avoid building an inventory of drilled but uncompleted wells. So what you're seeing is us manage as we get more efficient with those rigs and if we do it at lower cost, we have more opportunity to invest. We're just managing that inventory in an efficient operational basis overall. No intent to build inventory or to deplete it. We want to keep it relatively constant, and so we're managing that actively, David.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in your -- just one quick question on EG. How much downtime will you have for the compression project? How long will that take?
componenttext: Okay. And then in your -- just one quick question on EG. How much downtime will you have for the compression project? How long will that take?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, this is Mitch Little. And we have the installation campaign for the new compression platform that Lee spoke to earlier. And we would look at on the order of a couple of weeks to facilitate the initial installation of the jacket and topsides. We als
componenttext: David, this is Mitch Little. And we have the installation campaign for the new compression platform that Lee spoke to earlier. And we would look at on the order of a couple of weeks to facilitate the initial installation of the jacket and topsides. We also have scheduled planned maintenance, it's part of delivering our high reliability in those assets. And so there will be some partial downtime associated with that, that will also occur in the first quarter. But going into the second half of the year, of course, we'll have the benefits from that compression project that will bring rates back up to above even current rates.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one quick one on the Meramec wells, the EG one was just to fit in. The well results, kind of thinking about rates and well design. Can you talk about I would've thought that area would've been a little gassier, looks a little oilier, just my opin
componenttext: And just one quick one on the Meramec wells, the EG one was just to fit in. The well results, kind of thinking about rates and well design. Can you talk about I would've thought that area would've been a little gassier, looks a little oilier, just my opinion. Can you go through your thoughts on what happened in that part of kingfisher.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, David. I think as we're working through this early part of the Meramec. It's important to realize that we're focusing primarily on leasehold drilling, so we're covering a diverse area of several counties to convert these term leases to held by produ
componenttext: Sure, David. I think as we're working through this early part of the Meramec. It's important to realize that we're focusing primarily on leasehold drilling, so we're covering a diverse area of several counties to convert these term leases to held by production. We expect to see some diversity in those early well results. We're still working on the best designs and the completion and how we manage those wells in their early days. So I think while our results aren't or perhaps as much as we desired, we expected this diversity, it's early days. We're excited about seeing the continued momentum in the basin. The IPs continue to get better. The productivity is improving overall. And importantly, the cost improvements over the last year have been very material. And on top of that, you've seen us continue to be opportunistic in adding acres in this area at attractive pricing because we continue to see this as a great place to invest in the future.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Herrlin from Societe Generale.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Herrlin from Societe Generale.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most things have been asked, but I was just curious with Shenandoah. Is that an asset strategically that would be better off with one of your partners in terms of taking that cash flow for future CapEx and then dedicate it more towards the resource plays?
componenttext: Most things have been asked, but I was just curious with Shenandoah. Is that an asset strategically that would be better off with one of your partners in terms of taking that cash flow for future CapEx and then dedicate it more towards the resource plays?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Now, a good question. On Shenandoah, of course, we're still very much early in the appraisal phase. We've seen some excellent results from the last appraisal well. And I think the -- those as well as the operator share of those. We haven't reached an
componenttext: Yes. Now, a good question. On Shenandoah, of course, we're still very much early in the appraisal phase. We've seen some excellent results from the last appraisal well. And I think the -- those as well as the operator share of those. We haven't reached an investment decision, of course, around Shenandoah in the base case. Ultimately, it will need to compete for capital allocation head-to-head with the rest of our opportunities. But until we see the final development plan, and can make a, I would say, a thoughtful decision around that, I think that's an open question.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I apologize if some of these have been asked. I did get on the call a little bit late. In the unconventionals, when you announced the dividend reduction, the initial CapEx for '16, the expectation to U.S. unconventionals could be flattish, I think, is the
componenttext: I apologize if some of these have been asked. I did get on the call a little bit late. In the unconventionals, when you announced the dividend reduction, the initial CapEx for '16, the expectation to U.S. unconventionals could be flattish, I think, is the right way to think about it in '16 with the '15 exit rate. Is there a -- and we've heard these questions asked other places, is there a rationale to keep that flat because of the challenges of recovering once oil prices come up and you start drilling more in terms of fighting decline curves? Or should we think of it as in a $45 to $50 oil environment, that really is a reasonable way to invest in terms of just the returns of those wells today?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the way we have thought about that very preliminary guidance that we've provided, Roger, is really rooted in our overarching objective of balance sheet protection. And in the current environment, it's a $50 environment. We are not solving for grow
componenttext: I think the way we have thought about that very preliminary guidance that we've provided, Roger, is really rooted in our overarching objective of balance sheet protection. And in the current environment, it's a $50 environment. We are not solving for growth at that point. We are really looking at living within our means, inclusive of both the dividend as well as our noncore asset program. The preliminary guidance we provided, we believe, provides us a pathway to that cash flow neutrality. But as we see more constructive pricing or a more constructive outlook, certainly we'll take a thoughtful approach to how we allocate that and the number one common allocation will be our U.S. resource plays. But I'd just emphasize that we're still very early, still in the planning cycle.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And kind of as a follow-up to that. Is there anything that you've changed? You mentioned earlier the shift towards, maybe, a little more of the NGL condensates side, because that's where the economics are. Is there anything you've changed in the sor
componenttext: Okay. And kind of as a follow-up to that. Is there anything that you've changed? You mentioned earlier the shift towards, maybe, a little more of the NGL condensates side, because that's where the economics are. Is there anything you've changed in the sort of initial production of your wells, the first 30 days, 90 days, something like that in terms of choking them back? Why, in other words, sell all your production upfront when the prices aren't particularly impressive? And whether or not you've considered anything on the hedging side?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Roger, I'd say, operationally, we continue to bring the wells back in each basin based on the flow back parameters that drive the best well productivity. We're not managing those lower. I think with the way you're describing, just to manage the production
componenttext: Roger, I'd say, operationally, we continue to bring the wells back in each basin based on the flow back parameters that drive the best well productivity. We're not managing those lower. I think with the way you're describing, just to manage the production profile, we're doing it to drive best well productivity. In some small cases, basin-to-basin, where there -- you may have a -- once in a while, a limitation on gas capture, for example, in North Dakota. Or we may build a facility that's slightly undersized to minimize our spending and will peak [ph], but those tend to be short term and those are the exception, not the rule. So overall, we're continuing to manage the chokes and the flowback to drive best well productivity.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And hedging, any thoughts on that?
componenttext: Thanks. And hedging, any thoughts on that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Roger, this is J.R. I think you should consider the fact that hedging will be an element of a broader commodity risk management strategy going forward. And as opportunities present themselves in the market, we'll continue to look at ways to protect m
componenttext: Yes, Roger, this is J.R. I think you should consider the fact that hedging will be an element of a broader commodity risk management strategy going forward. And as opportunities present themselves in the market, we'll continue to look at ways to protect more the downside commodity price risk in the portfolio.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: At the risk of sounding like a CNBC debate moderator, I got to push you a little bit on the dividend. 3 months ago, you used very, very strong language in explaining why the dividend is the first call on cash flow. And I guess I'm just curious, what in th
componenttext: At the risk of sounding like a CNBC debate moderator, I got to push you a little bit on the dividend. 3 months ago, you used very, very strong language in explaining why the dividend is the first call on cash flow. And I guess I'm just curious, what in the last 90 days, what was the specific trigger for shifting from it is the first call in cash flow to cutting it 76%?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pavel, I mean, first of all, I would still say, even with our current dividend levels, that is -- it remains our first call on cash flow. But in terms of the why-now question, which I believe is what you're asking around the adjustment to the dividen
componenttext: Yes, Pavel, I mean, first of all, I would still say, even with our current dividend levels, that is -- it remains our first call on cash flow. But in terms of the why-now question, which I believe is what you're asking around the adjustment to the dividend, the way I would describe that is, first of all, it's really been a further and continued volatility and weakness in the commodity pricing environment. I would say, secondly, it's been a growing confidence in the quality, but most importantly, the depth of our U.S. resource play base which we just added in the past quarter 600 million oil equivalent barrels of 2P resource there. And then, I would say, the third factor that really was the trigger point is that we were able to share a preliminary view of our plan at the board level, so there was -- we had the ability to put that dividend adjustment in the context of our forward outlook and plans. So those were really the 3, I would say, triggers, Pavel, in terms of the why-now question.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, fair enough. And then kind of shifting to 2016, I know you said you haven't finalized the specific geographic components of the CapEx. But do you envision there being any kind of carveouts from the CapEx curtailments? And I'm thinking, Oklahom
componenttext: Okay, okay, fair enough. And then kind of shifting to 2016, I know you said you haven't finalized the specific geographic components of the CapEx. But do you envision there being any kind of carveouts from the CapEx curtailments? And I'm thinking, Oklahoma, perhaps, any areas that will get special treatment or protection from the overall 30% cut?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we're going to follow our rigorous capital allocation process, Pavel, so that it's going to be driven by economics. But there are cases, and Lance alluded to them -- to one earlier, where there are lost opportunity aspects to some of the play
componenttext: Well, again, we're going to follow our rigorous capital allocation process, Pavel, so that it's going to be driven by economics. But there are cases, and Lance alluded to them -- to one earlier, where there are lost opportunity aspects to some of the plays, specifically in Oklahoma, where we still have significant term lease that we need to hold. We are going to be looking to protect that as a top priority. So I wouldn't necessarily call that special treatment, I would just call that being smart about our business.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have no further questions at this time.
componenttext: We have no further questions at this time.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for your questions and interest in Marathon Oil. I'd like to thank, everyone, again for all their participation this morning. Please contact Zach Dailey or myself if you have any follow-up questions. Operator, thank you. This concludes today's c
componenttext: Thank you for your questions and interest in Marathon Oil. I'd like to thank, everyone, again for all their participation this morning. Please contact Zach Dailey or myself if you have any follow-up questions. Operator, thank you. This concludes today's conference call. And you may now disconnect.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This concludes today's conference. Thank you for participating. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This concludes today's conference. Thank you for participating. You may now disconnect.
